combined_text: Shumber Waterfalls Waterfall Shumber waterfall is 22 Kms and 45 minutes drive from Islamabad. First, you drive towards Murree Highway and turn left from Shah Dara Road before Bara Kahu and drive towards the Shahdara picnic spot. is half an hour hike from the Shahdara picnic spot. Shumber Waterfall  A Quiet Gem Near Islamabad Tucked away in the Margalla Hills near Shahdara Valley, Shumber Waterfall is one of those lesser-known spots that feels like a quiet escape  especially if you time your visit well. The short drive from Islamabad (roughly 3040 minutes depending on traffic) leads to a dirt trailhead near Hidden Terrace, after which its about a 1520 minute walk to reach the waterfall. The hike itself is relatively manageable  not too steep, with some shaded patches and beautiful greenery all around. The waterfall is seasonal, so its best visited after the monsoon. We went during the monsoon, and the flow of the water was quite strong and steady  definitely added to the experience. However, Id strongly recommend checking the weather forecast before heading out. Monsoon can be unpredictable, and what starts as a fun, relaxing hike could quickly turn risky if you get caught in the rain  especially given the flooding incidents seen in 2025. Best to go on a dry day with clear skies. What stood out was the natural setting  rocky pools, forested trails, and relatively minimal crowding compared to other, more well-known picnic spots. It helped that we started early, around 78AM; the trail was quiet and peaceful on the way in, but we noticed it starting to get crowded on our way back. The water is clear and cool, great for a refreshing dip if youre careful. The rocks can be slippery, so proper shoes are a must. Also, theres no formal infrastructure  no food stalls or restrooms  which adds to the raw feel of the place but means youll need to come prepared. All in all, a rewarding short escape from the city. Go early, go light, and dont forget to carry your trash back. Oh and given how cold the water was in July even, carry a towel to dry off after the dip in the water and spare shirt to avoid catching a cold. Very peaceful and beautiful location. Currently Roads are damaged due to rain but its a patch. Overall good experience. Just short drive approx 5 mintues from shahdra. Roads are perfect. Park the bikes or car. Nice tracking easy than bruti. Families can go for picnic there.

combined_text: Sonmiani Beach Coastal Sonmiani Beach is a beach located in the Lasbela District of the Balochistan state of Pakistan. It is located in Sonmiani Bay. The beach is a two-hour drive from Karachi and is very popular among tourists. The beach is home to Portuguese Man of Wars, and various species of fish. The perfect beach. Nice and cozy huts and rooms, only 1.5 hours away from Karachi. A great place to have a beach picnic with your family. Unlike most public beaches in Karachi this one is clean, no litter just peace and wonderful beach vibes. Totally recommended to anyone who wants a good beach experience. Although you would need to make a reservation before coming here, and there are 5 persons per room limit as well, more than that and you will be required to pay extra charges. All in all, its wonderful Located on coast line in Balochistan. 2 hours drive from Karachi. Only for armed forces. Civilians can visit through booking with families. They have rooms available for night stay. Very peaceful, clean and maintained. You can see crabs all along the coast line. They have nice sitting areas around the sea. You also can order the food and enjoy the view with it. Water is also very clean and a bit warm. Overall a must visit place for families. Good for picnics. Room charges are 6500 for 9 hours and 7500 for a night stay. Food prices are also very reasonable. The beach experience was absolutely magnificent, earning a perfect 10/10 rating. The sandy shores were impeccably clean, providing a beautiful and inviting atmosphere. The service we received was truly exceptional; the staff were attentive, friendly, and went above and beyond to ensure our comfort. The food was delightful, featuring a variety of delicious dishes that were both flavorful and beautifully presented. Overall, it was a fantastic day at the beach, and I can't wait to return!

combined_text: Taxila Museum Museum Taxila Museum is located at Taxila, Punjab, Pakistan. The museum is home to a significant and comprehensive collection of Gandharan art dating from the 1st to the 7th centuries CE. Most objects in the collection were excavated from the ruins of ancient Taxila. It's a heaven for history and culture lovers.. Properly maintained museum. All the field sites are worth visiting. Guides are extremely knowledgeable and cooperative. Could interact with them about the site for hours and they won't be tired of sharing their knowledge... Field sites are nearby the museum. Chingchi rickshaw are easily available to commute in a very reasonable rate. For soviniers, I would recommemd to buy from the gift shop inside the museum. They have variety of items and rates are reasonable. Work of craftmen on the field sitesais appreciated however their rates would just blew off our minds... I visited the Taxila Museum and was truly impressed by this mind-blowing place. It stands as a remarkable effort by Sir John Marshall, and as a Pakistani, I am deeply thankful to him for his great work in preserving our heritage. Every artifact, even the smallest pearl discovered from the ancient civilization of Taxila, has been carefully and securely displayed. The museum itself is like a priceless ancient gem. It is a large building with five spacious halls, each filled with history. Visiting this museum is a historical and awe-inspiring experience  truly a place worth seeing. Taxila Museum is a must-visit for history lovers. It has a remarkable collection of artifacts and sculptures that showcase the rich Gandhara civilization. The museum is well maintained, and the experience was both educational and enjoyable.

combined_text: Thal Desert Desert The Thal desert is situated in Punjab, Pakistan. The vast expanse is located between the Jhelum and Sindh rivers near the Pothohar Plateau, with a total length from north to south 190 miles, and a maximum breadth of 70 miles (110 km) and minimum breadth 20 miles. The desert covers the districts of Bhakkar, Khushab, Mianwali, Layyah, Muzaffargarh as well as Jhang, from the left bank of the river Jhelum. combined_text: The Lahore Museum Museum The Lahore Museum, is a museum located in Lahore, Pakistan. Founded in 1865 at a smaller location and opened in 1894 at its current location on 'The Mall' in Lahore during the British colonial period, Lahore Museum is one of Pakistan's most visited museums and one of the major museums in South Asia The Lahore Museum on Mall Road is one of the finest and most historic museums in Pakistan, offering a fascinating glimpse into the regions rich cultural, artistic, and religious heritage. Established in the 19th century during the British era, the building itself is a landmark  a beautiful red-brick structure with Indo-Saracenic architecture that immediately catches the eye. Inside, the museum houses an impressive and well-organized collection. Highlights include Gandhara sculptures of the Buddha, Mughal and Sikh-period artifacts, ancient manuscripts, miniature paintings, Islamic calligraphy, coins, arms, and ethnographic displays from across Pakistan. Each gallery is labeled with informative panels, making it easier for visitors to understand the historical context. The museum also displays relics from the Indus Valley Civilization and rare pieces like the Fasting Buddha statue, which is world-famous. I visited the Lahore Museum a few years ago, and it was truly a wonderful experience. Its a great place full of history, culture, and knowledge. The museum has a vast collection of ancient artifacts, coins, sculptures, paintings, and manuscripts that beautifully reflect the rich heritage of Pakistan. The building itself is historic and well-maintained, with detailed exhibits that make learning enjoyable for visitors of all ages. Its an ideal place for students, history lovers, and anyone interested in discovering the past. I highly recommend visiting the Lahore Museum  its one of the most informative and inspiring places in the city. An excellent museum where you can see the history of Pakistan from the prehistoric era to modern times. They have a huge collection of the artifacts from different ruling periods. Even they have the pocket diary of Queen Victoria. A good place to pass 2-3 hours indulged in history

combined_text: Bagh-e-Jinnah A historical park A large, historical park in Lahore featuring gardens, a library, and an amphitheater. An amazing public park situated in the center of Lahore City. This park is grand and has something for everyone. There is free public parking on all entrances of the park. The area of the park is huge as it contains full size cricket ground, a large jogging track, different walking tracks, free football arena, badminton courts, table tennis balls, skating arena, public toilets, prayer areas, chilled water dispensers, and dense forests. This is truly a place for families to enjoy time outdoors, for athletes to exercise, and horticulture experts to study plants and trees. The park is very safe and equally well maintained. Highly recommended for a visit. Went here after nearly 32 years and was absolutely stunned at the botanical history of it. Creepy old trees, eerily peaceful in the midst of the busy city centre. Enjoyed the 5kms run, if only the idle people not stare at men wearing decent shorts and females in sports attire ! Bagh-e-Jinnah is one of the most peaceful and refreshing places in the city. I had a great time walking through its beautifully maintained gardens and enjoying the calm environment. The historical architecture, old trees, and natural beauty make it a perfect place to relax. Its ideal for morning walks, reading, or spending quality time with family. I truly felt happy and relaxed after my visit. I highly recommend this park for anyone who loves nature and serenity.

combined_text: Tomb of Abdullah Shah Ghazi Religious shrine (Sufi Tomb) The shrine of a revered 8th-century Sufi saint, offering spiritual solace and panoramic views of the Karachi coastline. Visiting Baba Abdullah Shah Ghazi (RA) shrine is always a heart-touching experience. The moment you step inside, you feel a deep sense of peace and calmness, as if the worries of daily life stay outside. The soothing recitation, the fragrance of flowers, and the gentle sound of people praying create an environment that truly connects you to spirituality. The shrine sits on a small hill near Clifton, and from there you can feel the cool sea breeze  it adds to the feeling of serenity. No matter how crowded it gets, theres still a sense of inner calm when standing by the tomb. Offering prayers here gives a feeling of closeness to Allah and refreshes the soul. Around the shrine, youll find people from every background, all united in respect and devotion. I found the environment welcoming, filled with peace, blessings, and hope. Its a reminder that Karachi, despite its rush, has such spiritual sanctuaries that bring comfort to the heart. A must-visit for anyone looking for spiritual strength, peace of mind, and blessings. truly a place of spirituality, and peace. Your love with ahle beyat should be never ending. The Sindh government has transformed this place into an architectural wonder. I have been visiting this shrine since I was a kid and recently went there with my family. I remember how hectic it was to reach all the way to the top where the saint's grave was located. I was pleasantly surprised to see how much it had changed. Most of all, it has wheelchair accessibility all the way to the grave. Now, that is an amazing feat. The langar (free food distribution) is still there, but more orderly now.

combined_text: Jilani Park (Race Course Park) Public Park One of Lahore's largest and most popular recreational parks, famous for its lush greenery, boating lake, and children's play areas. This park is a wonderful urban retreat in Lahore. Whether youre going for a casual family picnic, a morning jog, or simply want to sit and unwind in nature, this place delivers. The combination of greenery, walks/tracks, water features, and floral displays makes it one of the top picks for recreation in the city. I would highly recommend a visitespecially on a weekday morning for some peaceful time, or during one of the seasonal flower exhibitions for a more vibrant experience. Tip: Visit early in the morning (around 68 AM) if you want to avoid the crowds and have a quieter time. Bring comfortable shoes for the track. A peaceful green space in the heart of Lahore, perfect for early morning walks, jogging, or relaxing with family. combined_text: Lal Haveli Historical Landmark The famous and politically significant "Red Mansion" of the Shah family, a major landmark in the heart of Rawalpindi. It is capable of more than 5 stars because We have met Sheikh Rashid who make us to visit whole lal haveli LAL HAVELI ( ) is a historic building in Rawalpindi, Pakistan, known for its striking red facade and political significance. Located near Raja Bazaar, it has served as the residence and political office of Sheikh Rashid Ahmed, a prominent Pakistani politician. The Haveli's architecture reflects a blend of Mughal and colonial influences, attracting visitors interested in history and culture. Over the years, it has become a symbol of political activity and public gatherings in the city. Despite modern developments, Lal Haveli retains its historical charm and remains an iconic landmark of Rawalpindi. Lal Haveli, located in the Saddar area of Rawalpindi, is a historical landmark celebrated for its architectural charm and cultural significance. Built during the British Raj, its red brick structure combines Mughal and colonial styles, making it a unique attraction. Over time, it has gained fame as the residence and political headquarters of Sheikh Rashid Ahmed, a prominent Pakistani politician. Many admire Lal Haveli for its historical value and its role in preserving Rawalpindi's heritage. Locals and tourists appreciate its old-world charm and accessibility, making it a popular cultural and historical site. The haveli is also a hub for community engagement, hosting religious and cultural events that foster inclusivity and strengthen its connection to the local population. However, its strong political association polarizes opinions. While Sheikh Rashid's supporters see it as a symbol of political resilience and grassroots activism, critics argue that its political use overshadows its historical importance. Controversies over ownership and maintenance issues have further tarnished its image for some. Concerns about preservation are frequent, as parts of the haveli show signs of neglect. Many suggest that restoration efforts and enhanced tourist facilities, such as guided tours and informational displays, could elevate its status as a heritage site. In summary, Lal Haveli is a symbol of Rawalpindis history and culture but needs focused preservation efforts to fully realize its potential as a heritage landmark, independent of its political associations.

combined_text: Depalpur Fort Historical Fort A historical fort located in the town of Depalpur, with significance dating back to the Mughal era. Historical Background of Depalpur Fort. Ancient Origins Depalpur is one of South Asia's oldest continuously inhabited cities, with settlement traces dating back to the Kushan era (circa 40 CE to 172 CE) and perhaps even earlier during the Indo-Scythian period around 100 BCE, as evidenced by archaeological finds . I visited Depalpur Fort, also known as Dhaki, and was sad to see its condition. This old fort, located higher than Depalpur city, is now mostly ruined. Only two gates remain, and they don't look as good as they used to, even after repairs. Walking around the fort, I felt a strong sense of loss. This place was once very important, dating back to the 13th century. Now, people have built homes inside the fort, and there's no proper system for waste and sewage. The area is dirty and neglected. It's heartbreaking to see this historic site in such bad shape. Depalpur Fort is a big part of Pakistan's history and culture. combined_text: Karachi Port Trust Building Historical Architecture An iconic colonial-era building that serves as the headquarters for the port authority, a landmark in Karachi. Here are some images of the Karachi Port Trust (KPT) Building, a splendid colonial-era landmark in Karachi showcasing its architectural magnificence and its timeless presence by the waterfront. Inside, you'll find spacious rooms with high ceilings, richly adorned teak woodwork, a wooden open-cage elevator, a boardroom under the dome, a conference room, and a records room preserving original documents dating back to 1893 . The floors feature black-and-white cement tiles, and large green-painted arch windows add to its elegant aesthetic . Heritage, History & Visitor Sentiment Serves as the headquarters for the Karachi Port Trust, it stands as an enduring symbol of Karachis maritime heritage . The construction of the Karachi Port Trust Building dates back to the early 20th century during the British colonial era. Designed by the renowned architect James Strachan, the building's construction began in 1912 and was completed in 1915. James Strachan, an architect of Scottish descent, played a significant role in shaping the architectural landscape of Karachi during that period. The Karachi Port Trust Building stands as a prime example of the architectural influences prevalent in the early 1900s, combining elements of both colonial and Islamic styles. Its construction was integral to the expansion and development of the Karachi port, serving as the administrative headquarters for the Karachi Port Trust, a vital institution responsible for managing and overseeing the operations of the port. The association with James Strachan adds a historical dimension to the building, as his architectural contributions extended beyond Karachi, leaving an indelible mark on the city's urban fabric. The Karachi Port Trust Building, with its timeless design and historical significance, stands as a testament to the collaborative efforts of architects, engineers, and administrators who shaped the maritime infrastructure of Karachi during a pivotal era in its history. combined_text: Umar Hayat Mahal Library (Gulzar Manzil) Historical Palace / Museum A famous and visually stunning wooden palace/mansion from the British era, known for its intricate woodwork. Amazing Place For History Discover. Must Visit. There is A History Of A Family. If You Are A Piece Lover Must Go There. a library is Also There. The Umer Hayat Mahal in Chiniot, Pakistan! The Umer Hayat Mahal is a magnificent example of Mughal and Sikh architectural styles, built in the 19th century. It's a beautiful palace that showcases the rich cultural heritage of Chiniot. The palace was built by Sheikh Umer Hayat, a wealthy merchant of Chiniot, and features intricate wooden carvings, ornate tile work, and stunning architecture. The Umer Hayat Mahal is considered one of the most impressive and well-preserved examples of a traditional Punjabi mansion. It has been beautifully restored and now serves as a museum, showcasing the art, culture, and history of the region. Sheikh Omar Hayat Vohra migrated fromChiniottoCalcuttain the late 19th century after being ostracised for marrying against his family's will.Large numbers of Chiniot's Sheikh tribe had settled in Calcutta during the British era. Sheikh Omar's first son, Gulzar Vohra, was born in 1920, prompting Sheikh Omar's decision to return to his hometown,where he decided to construct a magnificent palace that would feature the best of Chiniot's craftsmanship. Syed Hassan Shah was assigned the task of the mansion's construction. He gathered the best artisans from Chiniot, as well as from other places, who continued working for 10 ten years to complete the structure. Rahim Bakhsh Pirjha and Elahi Bakhsh Pirjha, masters in themanabat karistyle of wood carving, carried out much of the mansion's woodwork.Ahmad Din completed the brickwork, while the celebrated artist Niaz Ahmad Jalandari did the stucco-work.Another celebrated artist, Jan Muhammad, painted the mansion'sfrescoes. The mansion was habitable by 1930, and described as a 'local wonder' by the British authors of theDistrict Gazeteer of Jhang.It was completed in 1935- at a cost of 200,000 rupees.Sheikh Omar died shortly after its completion in 1935. Sheikh Omar Hayat's only son, Gulzar Vohra, was married in the mansion in an extravagant ceremony in 1937.Gulzar was found dead in the palace the very next day of his marriage, possibly due to carbon monoxide poisoning as a result of large volumes of coal that had been burned for the celebration.He was buried in the courtyard of the ground floor of the palace, alongside the grave of his mother Fatima who later passed. Hayat Vohra's relatives abandoned the mansion, associating it with bad luck.Servants continued living there for a couple of years, though no family members laid claim to the building.In 1940, theAnjuman-e-Islamiaorganisation opened a school in the building. An orphanage was established in 1948 by Sheikh Muhammad Amin, though it was shifted in 1950, leaving the building abandoned once again.Local scavengers dismantled some of the mansion's decorative elements, and sold them to collectors in other cities. Two levels of the mansion was removed in the 1970s due to its state of dangerous disrepair, while another level had to be abandoned following severe rains in 1993.The building was brought under government control in 1989, with large portions repaired by the mid-1990s with funds raised by the local community.The mansion is now used as a cultural centre and library. Historical places but very poorly managed

One of the best park in lahore **Sukhchain Park (Lahore)  Review** Sukhchain Park is a well-known public park in Lahore, located near **sukj Chain Center** (a facility for Sikh pilgrims) in **canal road **. It is a popular recreational spot for families, joggers, and visitors looking for a peaceful green space. ### **Key Features & Facilities**  **Lush Greenery & Landscaping**  Well-maintained lawns, trees, and flower beds.  **Walking/Jogging Tracks**  Paved pathways suitable for morning/evening walks.  **Childrens Play Area**  Swings, slides, and play equipment.  **Sikh Chain Center Nearby**  Convenient for pilgrims visiting religious sites.  **Seating & Shade**  Benches and shaded areas for relaxation.  **Basic Amenities**  Clean washrooms and drinking water facilities. ### **Visitor Experience**  **Pros:** - Peaceful atmosphere, good for relaxation. - Family-friendly environment. - Well-maintained cleanliness (compared to other Lahore parks). - Safe for women and children.  **Cons:** - Limited food stalls (better to bring snacks). - Can get crowded on weekends. - Some areas need renovation. A beautiful and spacious family park. A lot of scenic views here. If you visit Sukh Chayn, do pay a visit to this park. You will feel more connected to mother nature. Also, they have all kinds of birds there and some deer as well. A great place to spend family time. Wonderful park with a zoo of birds, near a Turkish mosque. The walking path and gardens are ideal for exercise and meditation. Very safe, looking forward to my next visit!

combined_text: Ayub National Park National Park One of the oldest and largest national parks in Rawalpindi, featuring a lake, gardens, and an amusement park. Ayub National Park is a massive and beautiful park located in Rawalpindi. It is easily one of the best places in the city to go for a long walk, a jog, or just to relax because it covers so much area. The park is very green, with lots of big trees and open grassy areas, which makes the air feel clean and fresh. I often visit early in the morning on weekends, and the atmosphere is always very peaceful and calm. It is a great escape from the noise and rush of the busy city life. There are also a few extra attractions inside, like the small lake where you can rent a boat, and some food stalls for snacks and drinks. It is a perfect spot for families to spend a whole weekend afternoon, especially since there is plenty of safe space for children to run and play. The park management clearly does a good job keeping the area tidy and clean. I highly recommend visiting if you are in the Rawalpindi area. Five stars for this excellent public space! Park offers something for everyone. Jardinfriendly walking & jogging tracks, nice lakes with paddle boats, a wellmaintained zoo plus a fun amusement area (rides, Mystery House etc.). Plenty of picnic lawns, vintage warvehicles display, and cafes. Can get busy on weekends. Overall, great for family outing or a relaxing day outdoors.Can get crowded on holidays. Clean environment and a peaceful place for a weekend. Ayub National Park is a vast and beautifully maintained recreational spot located in the heart of Rawalpindi. It offers a refreshing environment filled with lush greenery and natural beauty that words can hardly capture. The park is highly recommended for families, especially children, as it provides ample space to play and explore. Visitors can enjoy a wide range of facilities, including designated picnic areas, food courts, and attractions such as parrots, deer, horses, and even zebras. With its peaceful surroundings and diverse amenities, Ayub National Park is truly an ideal destination forrrelaxation and family outings.

combined_text: Dehli Gate Historical Landmark One of the six remaining historic gates of the Walled City of Lahore, leading into a bustling bazaar. Delhi Gate is one of the most iconic entrances to the Walled City of Lahore and a must-visit for anyone exploring the citys heritage. The gate itself is centuries old and full of character, giving you a glimpse of Mughal-era grandeur. Walking through it feels like stepping back in time. Inside, youll find a bustling bazaar with shops selling everything from fabrics, handicrafts, spices, to traditional food. The energy here is unmatched  its lively, colorful, and truly captures the essence of old Lahore. Its also home to some amazing historical landmarks nearby, like Masjid Wazir Khan and Shahi Hammam, which makes the visit even more worthwhile. The narrow streets, traditional architecture, and local culture make it a perfect spot for history lovers and photographers. The only downside is the traffic and crowd, but thats part of the authentic old-city experience. Highly recommended if you want to see the real heart of Lahore. Delhi Gate in Lahore is a remarkable historical landmark that beautifully captures the essence of the citys rich cultural heritage. The area around the gate is vibrant and full of life, with traditional architecture, local markets, and authentic street food that offers a glimpse into the old walled city of Lahore. Visiting Delhi Gate feels like stepping back in time, surrounded by centuries of history and charm. It's a must-visit spot for anyone interested in exploring the historical and cultural depth of Lahore. Truly a gem in the heart of the city Delhi Gate is one of the most amazing historical spots in Lahore. Its part of the old Walled City and has been nicely restored. When you walk through the gate, it really feels like youve gone back in time. The old streets, the atmosphere, everything gives a true Lahori vibe. Right nearby is the famous Wazir Khan Mosque  seriously beautiful and worth seeing! There are also old havelis, small shops, and tasty street food all around. combined_text: Shakarparian National Park National Park A large park and hill area in Islamabad known for the Pakistan Monument and panoramic city views.  Shakarparian Park is one of the most beautiful and peaceful spots in Islamabad!  The park offers breathtaking views of the entire city, especially from the top viewpoint where you can see the Faisal Mosque and the Margalla Hills. Its a perfect place for families, couples, and nature lovers who want to relax and enjoy calm surroundings. The park is clean, well-maintained, and full of greenery. There are plenty of sitting areas, walking tracks, and shaded spots to enjoy picnics or evening tea. The fresh air and cool breeze make every visit refreshing and memorable.  Its also an excellent place for photography and sightseeing, with nearby attractions like the Pakistan Monument and Lok Virsa. The management and security are good, and the environment feels safe for everyone. Highly recommended to anyone visiting Islamabad  Shakarparian Park is pure peace and natural beauty combined!  Shakarparyan National Park is truly the green heart of Islamabad, offering much more than just a park experienceit's a blend of stunning natural beauty, panoramic city views, and immense national history. My recent visit reaffirmed why this spot is a mandatory stop for both locals and tourists. The most compelling feature is undoubtedly the Shakarparyan View Point. Situated on a central hill, it provides breathtaking, uninterrupted 360-degree views of the entire capital. You can clearly see the iconic Faisal Mosque shimmering in the distance, the vast expanse of Rawal Lake, and the Red Zone buildings, all framed by the beautiful Margalla Hills. Visiting in the late afternoon for the sunset is highly recommended; the city lights gradually twinkling to life beneath you are simply magical. Adjacent to the park is the spectacular Pakistan Monument and Museum, which adds profound cultural significance to the location. The monument itself is a work of art, and the museum offers an insightful journey through the nation's history. It's fantastic that you can combine a serene nature walk with a valuable educational experience in a single visit. The park itself is well-maintained, featuring wide, clean walking and jogging tracks perfect for an early morning stroll or an evening walk. There are ample, shaded picnic spots and the famous 'Head of State Tree' plantation area, where international dignitaries have planted treesa unique touch. While parking can sometimes be a bit limited during peak hours, the general atmosphere is peaceful, clean, and secure. If you are seeking an escape from the city hustle without leaving the city, Shakarparyan National Park offers the perfect retreat. Its a wonderful place to relax, reflect, take amazing photographs, and appreciate the vision behind Islamabads beautiful design. Highly recommended for families, nature lovers, and history enthusiasts alike. A refreshing spot with lots of greenery and trees planted by the hands of famous personalities. We had dinner at Tahir Khan Restaurant (TKR), and the food was delicious with a nice place to sit and relax.

combined_text: Amri Jo Daro    Archaeological Site The archaeological site of Amri, an ancient pre-Harappan settlement dating back to 36003300 BCE. Amri jo Daro (Mound of Amri) is one the most earliest archaeological sites of Pre matured Indus Valley Civilization. There are baked bricks with home structures, where lot of broken pottery is visible on the mound. Archaeologist believe that Amri was inter linked with oldest sites of the IVC. It is now completely under the mud. Amri is an Ancient settlement, Amri is earlier farming communities from 6000BC to 4000BC ultimately led to Urbanization. Like other Pre-Harappa towns, on writings were found at this site. Evidence indicates widespread fire at the town around 2500BCE. Alas! Totally neglected. I think deliberately left unprotected. Archeological treasure. I am not asking for excavation. It is better left un excavated than bluntly dug out by naive & unprofessional 'experts'. But at least the buried ruins can be protected from further damage by unchecked trespassing and weather conditions. Located near Indus highway (N55) and river Indus. Aamri village nearby. #PoorMaintenance #ArcheologicalSiteSindh #HeritageSindh #HighwayNearby #RiverNearby

combined_text: Akrand Fort Historical Fort A historical fort located in the Khushab district, though not as widely known as other forts. Local is a must, or as someone else wrote earlier, you may lost the way to the remains of the fort. The fort is no more there, only the remains of the walls. Take a bottle of water with you because there is hiking involved as well. Nice historical place for archaeology lovers. Akrand fort in Soon Valley was built by the men of Raja Tataar Khan in order to defend the areas of Soon and Pakhar. The fort is covered with thick and dense forest. Only one way leads to the fort which is along the way toKanhatti garden. The fort had stables for horses, residential houses and weapon stores which have now turned into ruins. There is also a grave on the way to the fort which is supposed to be of Raja Tataars. The fort is thought to be of immense historical as well as architectural value for the archaeologists, not to mention the marvellous scenery it holds within itself. We tried to capture the ruins from every angle but they could not be captured the same on the cam. So, anyone who has an interest in history must visit this place himself/herself. A guide is must to visit this place. Historical Fort on the top of mountain having only one entrance. Ruins of settlements still exist and was very unique for defence during wars.

combined_text: View Point Park Mirpur (A.K) Scenic Viewpoint A park offering scenic views of Mangla Lake and the surrounding area in Mirpur, Azad Kashmir. View Point Park in Mirpur is an absolute gem! If you're looking for a place to escape the hustle and bustle of the city and immerse yourself in nature's beauty, this is the perfect spot. The park is strategically located, offering panoramic views of the surrounding landscape. Whether you visit at sunrise, sunset, or any time in between, the vistas are simply breathtaking. The rolling hills, the serene lake, and the lush greenery make for a picturesque backdrop that's perfect for nature lovers and photographers alike. The park is well-maintained, with clean walking paths and seating areas where you can relax and take in the scenery. I particularly enjoyed the well-placed benches that allowed me to sit and contemplate the stunning view. Birdwatchers will also appreciate the diverse birdlife in the area, adding an extra layer of charm to the park. Don't forget your binoculars! View Point Park is an excellent place for a family picnic or a peaceful solo escape. The facilities are clean, and there's plenty of space for children to play and explore. The picnic areas are equipped with grills, making it an ideal spot for a barbecue. Parking is ample and convenient, and I found the park staff to be friendly and helpful. The entrance fee is reasonable, especially considering the experience you get in return. In conclusion, View Point Park in Mirpur is a hidden paradise for nature enthusiasts. It's a place where you can relax, unwind, and connect with the natural world. I highly recommend a visit to this beautiful park if you're in the area. You won't be disappointed! Good place for children's and family, many people come for the evening time walk, it's old park but restoration has been done . It is situated on haul Road sector F1 in mid of city you can enjoy the views of Mangla Dam and city. Very beautiful and clean city. Good roads , shops, beautiful weather.. beautiful cooperative people. Visited this coty after 11 years. Very beautiful..

_key: Major Raja Aziz Bhatti Shaheed Memorial
combined_text: Major Raja Aziz Bhatti Shaheed Memorial Monument / Memorial A memorial dedicated to a recipient of the Nishan-e-Haider, Pakistan's highest military award. It is the memorial place our shuhada of indo pak war . The place where we can see the sacrifices of our beloved heroes. Who saved Pakistan with them lives Salut them Loved the place. This place takes you back ko 1965 when out army tigers have defended homeland and fought war like real men. Memorial is very well maintained by Army. Other then google maps you have no option to reach there as there is no board or sign for this historical place. Place has parking space and memorial is walled with Maj Shaheed photo engraved on stone and with history. Behind that is B.R.B Canal in its original form. Monument in memory of Major Raja Aziz Bhatti and his men who fought valiantly against overwhelming odds in the shape of invading Indian hordes. Major Aziz Bhatti had company strength troops and later on another company joined him, but they repulsed attack after attack by Indian forces who attacked in brigade strength using armour, artillery and Infantry. The Pakistani troops led by Aziz Bhatti defended the BRB canal entrenched on the home bank (where this monument is) and foiled Indian attempts to cross the canal and seize the city of Lahore. From 6th September to the 10th, Major Aziz Bhatti fought continously without sleep or rest and repulsed the Indians. Ultimately, while directing artillery fire upon Indian armour, he was targeted by an Indian tank which fired directly at him. The tank shell hit him in the left side of the chest and led to his instantaneous martyrdom on the spot. Major Raja Aziz Bhatti was awarded the highest gallantry award of Nishan e Haider posthumously. This monument was raised by the Northern Light Infantry of Pak army. This place is located in the Burki area on the outskirts of Lahore city and can be approached easily. Highly recommended. Its a beautiful and quiet place and attached to it is the holy memory of the martyrs who.laid down their lives in defence of Pakistan  Highly recommended place to visit and revisit the spot where Pakistani soldiers stemmed the tide of Indian attack.

combined_text: Masti Gate Historical Landmark One of the thirteen gates of the Walled City of Lahore, rich in historical significance. Masti Gate in Lahore is a historical gem that showcases the city's rich cultural heritage and architectural grandeur. Located in the heart of the Walled City, this gate is one of the original entrances dating back to the Mughal era. *Key Features:* - *Historical Significance*: Masti Gate has a rich history, with its construction attributed to the third Mughal ruler, Akbar, around 1566. The gate has been named after a royal guard called Masti Baloch, who served with dedication and commitment. - *Architectural Appeal*: The gate features intricate carvings and colorful tile work, showcasing the artistry that flourished during the Mughal period. - *Vibrant Markets*: The surrounding area is filled with bustling markets, including a wholesale shoe market and Moti Bazaar, offering a wide range of products. - *Local Cuisine*: Visitors can enjoy traditional Pakistani delicacies like biryani and nihari at nearby eateries. *Visitor Experience:* - *Best Time to Visit*: Early morning or late afternoon to avoid crowds and enjoy a quieter experience. - *Guided Tours*: Available to provide insights into the significance of Masti Gate and its role in Lahore's history. - *Shopping*: Explore the myriad of shops and food stalls lining the streets, perfect for food lovers and shoppers. *Rating:* 4.5/5 stars *Recommendation:* Masti Gate is a must-visit destination for history enthusiasts, culture lovers, and shoppers. With its rich history, vibrant markets, and delicious cuisine, it's an unforgettable experience that captures the essence of Lahore  reis gate was actually called Masjidi Gate but the name got altered to Masti. Stories also revolve around about a royal guard called Masti Baloch after whom this gate was named. We saw some amazing buildings here like the Mariam Zamani Mosque, the well restored Baroodkhana Haveli and some famous shrines. My daughters were really amused to see the wholesale shoe market in Moti Bazaar which was in operation at eight in the morning. This market runs all through the night because it's customers come from other cities during the night. We partook the wonderful "Rabri Milk" here. It tasted like ambrosia as the concoction had cream, almonds, pistachios, vermicelli and cardamoms added to the milk. Everyone was really thrilled to see the famous wrestler Shahiya Pehlwan's wrestling courts. We saw the mud wrestlers in action. It was an absolutely thrilling experience. nice visit...but all historical places need high maintainance...very devastating condition since last visit 20 years back.

combined_text: Fatima Jinnah Park (F-9 Park) Public Park One of the largest public parks in Islamabad, also known as F-9 Park. F-9 Park, officially known as Fatima Jinnah Park, is unequivocally the green heart of Islamabad and an essential visit for residents and tourists alike. Spanning a vast Areaeffectively an entire sectorit provides a crucial, expansive escape from the citys concrete jungle. Its sheer size means you can genuinely lose yourself in nature, a rare luxury in a modern capital. The parks primary strength lies in its excellent infrastructure for physical activity. The well-maintained, dedicated walking and jogging tracks are fantastic, making it the perfect spot for morning exercise, cycling, or just a leisurely evening stroll. With the picturesque Margalla Hills serving as a backdrop, the environment is both serene and motivational. Beyond the tracks, the park is a hub of varied activities. Theres a large, well-equipped children's play area that keeps families coming back, and open lawns are always filled with people picnicking or playing casual sports. Facilities like the outdoor gym stations and dedicated recreational complex (Leisure Arena/Gandhara Citizen Club) further enhance its utility. I also appreciate the efforts toward sustainability, including the visible solar power plant. While a few sections, particularly near the gates, can get crowded, the parks immense size allows for tranquility in its inner areas, which feel more like a wildlife sanctuary. It's truly a testament to Islamabad's planning and remains free of charge for general entry, making it accessible to everyone. F-9 Park is more than just a park; it's a vital community space that is essential for the citys well-being. Highly recommended for fitness enthusiasts, families, and anyone seeking fresh air. Nature all around (as much as a big city can have).. peaceful environment and wide area for a walk, stroll, jogging or even playing.. i love the calm of this place that doesnt matter how much crowd is there, theres still a silent side spent a number of birthdays, eids and regular evenings there and made a whole lot of memories there i hope they never convert it into a commercial area or whatever the rumours are saying.. its perfect the way it is I visited this park in my recent islamabad tour and i was amazed a huge lush greenery area for park is reserved in Islamabad that is covered almost a sector area. Walk track bicycle track are also available in park and many other healthy activities can be played in this park. Many monument built here to attract the people. Family and children area also available here. I wonder to visited this park and also happy. I recommend to all must visit the park once.

combined_text: Changa Manga Forest Park Forest / Wildlife Park One of the largest man-made forests in the world, featuring a wildlife park, train rides, and picnic spots. Changa Manga is a big man-made forest near Lahore, Pakistan. Its a peaceful place full of trees, birds, and fun activities. Its great for a one-day picnic with family or friends.  What You Can Do There: Mini Train Ride A small train takes you through the jungle. Fun for kids and gives you a nice view of the forest. Boating There is a lake where you can enjoy paddle boating. Very calm and relaxing. Picnic Areas You can sit, eat, and relax under big shady trees. Good place to bring homemade food and enjoy nature. Animals You might see deer, monkeys, and birds. There is a small zoo as well. Walking & Cycling You can walk or ride a bike on the paths in the forest.  Good Things: Quiet and peaceful place Good for kids and families Beautiful nature and fresh air Cheap or free to enter This is a dream like beautiful place, especially when the weather is cloudy. The rope bridge is not only fun but also adds to the esthetic beauty of the place. Now they have reduced the area, still it seems appealing. The admin could do very well but alas! The lake is too muddy, the boats are rotting, the birds have flown away, the trees are quite less, the vendors don't have proper system to sell any goods, the toilets have no doors, and at the entrance it says that camera is watching you but you have to keep an eye on your vehicle in the parking in case it gets stolen. It seems funny yet pathetic. The train timings are not mentioned and it leaves as soon as they think its full. No written instructions how much time it takes to complete a circle, but it is mentioned that you pay 100 rs per person till 1 corner to the other (then to return to the 1st corner from where you sat there is probably another 100 rs. per person, but we couldn't take the previlege to get a ride) we kept waiting for the train to get back on its station but there was nobody to tell how much wait was required. So after 20 min we left that place. The tram outside has no fee structure, that person said 1000 rs for a family, but a family could be 10 people or more, or less, but he couldn't justify. In short it can be made the most beautiful place by little bit of care but nobody cares. Even the public doesn't care to take away its litter after enjoying the food. There are cats in scarcity and no squirrels at all, which is the biggest flaw. It proves that there is no place for animals and birds to live in the forest. We should be so loving that birds get back there, that squirrels get abundant, that bees make hives, that butterflies dance in distance and make our young children aware how a forest looks. I wish someone local, who can, reads this all and brings improvement. Review: A Wonderful Visit to Changa Manga, Lahore Our recent visit to Changa Manga, located near Lahore, was an incredible experience filled with fun and relaxation. Known as one of the largest man-made forests in the world, this place offers a refreshing escape from the hustle and bustle of city life. From the moment we arrived, we were amazed by the lush greenery and the serene environment. The fresh air and scenic beauty made it a perfect spot for a picnic. We enjoyed walking through the forest trails, surrounded by towering trees and chirping birds, creating a peaceful atmosphere. One of the highlights of our visit was the famous Changa Manga train ride, which took us on a delightful journey through the forest. The boating area was another exciting experience, where we enjoyed paddling in the calm waters. The small zoo inside the park was a great attraction, especially for children. The park also has well-maintained picnic areas and food stalls, making it easy to relax and enjoy a meal with family and friends. The management has done a good job in keeping the place clean and safe for visitors. Overall, we had a fantastic time at Changa Manga. It is a must-visit destination for nature lovers and families looking for a peaceful getaway.

combined_text: Theme Park DHA Bahawalpur Amusement Park An amusement and theme park located in the Defense Housing Authority (DHA) of Bahawalpur. Theme Park DHA Bahawalpur is a beautifully designed recreational space with clean walking tracks, green lawns, kids' play areas, and a mesmerizing dancing fountain show in the evening. It provides a peaceful, secure, and family-friendly environment, ideal for leisure and relaxation. The atmosphere is refreshing, and it stands out as one of the finest public spots in South Punjab. Whether you're enjoying a walk, sitting by the artificial pond, or watching the lighted fountain, it's a great place to unwind with loved ones. I recently visited DHA Bahawalpur Theme Park, a family-friendly amusement spot in the city. While it offers some entertainment options, it falls short of being a top-tier attractions. However, given the limited attractions and maintenance issues, the value could be better. The park was not overly crowded on my visit, so waiting times for rides were short. However, on weekends and holidays, it likely gets busier, which could lead to longer.DHA Bahawalpur Theme Park is a decent place for a casual family outing, especially with younger kids. However, it lacks the excitement and polish of larger amusement parks. With better maintenance, more rides, and improved facilities. This a park in defiance housing authority (DHA) Bahawalpur. This green, neat and clean park . Swings are available for kids. Crowded place different types of swings available for children. One small tuck shop is also available in this park corner.

combined_text: Kohati Gate Historical Landmark One of the four main gates of the old Walled City of Peshawar, rich in historical and cultural significance. A historical place and one of the the gate of the old historic city peshawar. Peshawar wasfounded as the city of Puruapura, on the Gandhara Plains in the broad Valley of Peshawar in 100 CE. It may have been named after a Hindu raja who ruled the city who was known as Purush. The city likely first existed as a small village in the fifth century BCE, Peshawar is the heart of Pakistan and people of the region are so kind and loving. I recently visited a bustling spot in the heart of the city, where the aroma of local street food and the lively atmosphere create a delightful experience. From sizzling kababs to flavorful snacks, the variety is impressive. The vibrant mix of flavors, affordable prices, and the authentic local touch make it a must-visit for food enthusiasts. The lively street ambiance adds to the charm, making it a perfect spot to explore the diverse culinary offerings of the region. The district Kohti Gate of Peshawar in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa is located in Pakistan about 87 mi west of Islamabad, the country's capital. It is one of the many historical gates to enter Old Peshawar City, there are many bird shops nearby. This place is the meet and eat hub for many of people representing true culture of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Pashtoons. There are also many of the great food places here to enjoy traditional cuisine.

combined_text: Mori Gate Historical Landmark One of the historic gates of the Walled City of Lahore, leading into a bustling bazaar. Mori Gate  Walled City of Lahore Address: Qadimi Shehar, Inside Mori Gate, near Urdu Bazar, Kucha Baili Ram, Walled City of Lahore, Lahore, 54000 Mori Gate is one of the twelve historic gates of the old Walled City of Lahore  a humble yet deeply significant passage into centuries of history, trade, and tradition. Unlike the grander gates such as Delhi Gate or Bhati Gate, Mori Gate carries a quieter charm, representing the daily life and resilience of old Lahore. Its narrow streets open into vibrant bazaars, small shops, and the timeless rhythm of city life that continues much as it did hundreds of years ago. This area is especially known for its proximity to Urdu Bazar  the literary heart of Lahore  where booksellers, writers, and students fill the lanes with words and wisdom. Walking through Mori Gate, one feels the living pulse of Lahore: the aroma of desi food, the sound of conversation, the colors of old architecture blending with the simplicity of modern life. Though smaller in size, Mori Gate holds a large piece of the citys soul. It tells the story of ordinary people whose lives built the extraordinary spirit of Lahore  a city that has seen empires fall, cultures blend, and love endure through time.  Here, the past walks beside you  quietly, yet proudly. Mori Gate, nestled within Lahores historic Walled City, holds a unique position among the citys ancient gateways. Unlike the grand entrances like Delhi or Bhati Gates, Mori Gate was a modest openingits name Mori meaning small hole in Urdu. Historically, it served dual purposes: providing access to the city after the main gates were closed at dusk and acting as an outlet for the citys refuse.    Though not officially recognized as one of the original twelve gates, locals have long considered Mori Gate the unofficial 13th. Over time, the original structure was demolished during British colonial rule, leaving no physical remnants. Today, the area thrives as Lahores largest fish market and is also renowned for its surgical goods market, the most extensive in the city.    The vicinity of Mori Gate is rich in cultural and historical significance. Nearby lies the Haveli of Nau Nihal Singh, a splendid example of Sikh-era architecture that has been repurposed as a girls school. The area is also known for producing high-quality lakh, a traditional furniture polish, and boasts a vibrant kite market, especially lively during the Basant festival.   Just because Mori Gate was the smallest of the 13 gates, it was assumed as being a garbage disposal point. For people who live in the walled city, or once lived there, this is a bizarre insult of sorts. So let me narrate a few facts as they can be seen even today. First we must understand that the original walled city had just two gateways to the south, they being Lohari and Mori. To the west there were none, except when the wall that ran along to the east of todays Bazaar Hakeeman, it turned inward and then there were three gateways, them being Taxali, Khizri and Kashmiri. These three were located along the current Chowk Taxali that meets Rang Mahal at the mound top turning towards Shahalami Bazaar. In the middle of this old western side in the middle along the mound was the original Delhi Gate. Traces of it still exist. Now comes the important assumption. Lahore is built on high mounds and to the west they flatten out. Around the fort and the city the River Ravi flowed turning in near the fort and going around the city and heading southwards from after Mori Gate near where today is built Bhati Gate. Almost 150 to 200 yards away from all these original seven gateways, as also away from the present 13 gateways, a waste water outlet exists. It still has the old iron grills to prevent anyone slipping in. These dropped into the river the encircled the walls. When Akbar expanded the city, primarily to accommodate the fierce Rajput Bhat warriors, who use the surname Bhatti, to the west and to the east the Turkic-Qizilbash horsemen in todays Mochi Gate area, we see that the southern portion remained the same and the northern was pushed outwards to cater for the growing importance of a river port. This was originally called Khizri Gate and Ranjit Singh renamed it Sheranwala. Akbars wife Maryam Zamani built a mosque just opposite the forts Akbari Gate and was called Masjidi Gate, now called Masti Gate. Maryam Zamani herself built some massive ships to ply Hajis. To one side of each gateway ran that particular areas waste waterway. So it was with Mori Gate. Inside Mori Gate was a huge garden in which people collected to pray before Hindu corpses were taken outside to be cremated at the point where the river turned to the south. This is the place where also the great Lahore Hindushahi Rajput ruler Raja Jayapala committed Johar after being defeated by the Afghan invader Mahmud. So to assume that at such a holy point is a waste disposal area is not to understand the social history, let alone the geography, of Lahore.

combined_text: Haveli Nau Nihal Singh Historical Architecture A beautifully restored 19th-century haveli (mansion) in the Walled City of Lahore. Haveli Nau Nihal Singh stands as one of the finest and most well-preserved examples of Sikh-period architecture in Lahore. Hidden within the narrow lanes of the Walled City, this haveli is a masterpiece of artistry and royal taste. Built during the reign of Maharaja Ranjit Singh for his grandson, Nau Nihal Singh, the mansion still carries the elegance, color, and spirit of that golden age. Its faade is adorned with intricate frescoes, wooden jharokas, and delicately painted motifs  each wall telling its own silent story. The courtyard, surrounded by beautifully crafted balconies, reflects the architectural harmony of Mughal and Sikh styles blending into one. Despite the passage of time, the haveli retains its regal aura, whispering the tales of royal ceremonies, music, and laughter once echoing through its halls. Walking through this place feels like entering a forgotten world where art, history, and devotion met in perfect balance. It is a treasure not only for Lahore but for all of South Asia  a reminder of the citys timeless craftsmanship and grandeur.  In every painted wall, history breathes  and beauty never fades. The Haveli of Nau Nihal Singh, nestled within Lahores historic Walled City near Mori Gate, stands as a remarkable testament to Sikh-era architecture and the rich cultural tapestry of 19th-century Punjab. Constructed around 183637 by Maharaja Ranjit Singh for his grandson, Nau Nihal Singh, this haveli served as his private residence and remains one of the few surviving royal abodes from the Sikh period in Lahore.   Architecturally, the haveli is a harmonious blend of Sikh and Mughal styles, featuring a rectangular base with its western faade adorned in vivid Kangra-style frescoes. A prominent feature is the jharoka-e-darshana ceremonial balcony embellished with intricate brickwork and a small bulbous domeused by the Maharaja to address his subjects. The faade also showcases carvings of winged figures, parrots, and fish, reflecting a fusion of Islamic and Hindu artistic influences.  Inside, the haveli boasts over 40 rooms, including the Rang Mahal (Color Palace) or Sheesh Mahal (Mirror Palace) on the fourth floor, characterized by decorated wooden ceilings inlaid with glass and mirror work. The walls are adorned with false arches housing miniature paintings, and the color palette predominantly features blues, golds, reds, and oranges. A two-storied inner courtyard adds to the architectural grandeur, though the lower level has been whitewashed over time.  Haveli Nau Nihal Singh is a historical haveli located in the Walled City of Lahore, built during the reign of Maharaja Ranjit Singh. It was the residence of Nau Nihal Singh, the grandson of Ranjit Singh. The haveli showcases a beautiful blend of Mughal and Sikh architectural styles, with intricate woodwork, frescoes, and traditional designs. Over the years, the haveli has faced neglect, but its architectural charm still reflects the grandeur of the era. Its a significant example of Lahores rich cultural heritage, offering a glimpse into the regal lifestyle of the time.

combined_text: Derawar Cannon Historical Landmark Likely refers to the historic cannons at the Derawar Fort in the Cholistan Desert. That sounds lovely! Lal Suhanra National Park is a beautiful place to visit, with its lush greenery, fresh air and serene environment. It's a great spot to relax, unwind, and connect with nature.  **Derawar Cannon Review: A Historical Marvel** Located in the heart of Bahawalpur, Pakistan, the Derawar Cannon stands as a testament to the region's rich history and architectural prowess. Dating back to the 18th century, this imposing structure commands attention with its sheer size and intricate craftsmanship. Upon arrival, visitors are greeted by the awe-inspiring sight of the Derawar Cannon, standing tall against the backdrop of the Cholistan Desert. The cannon's imposing presence immediately transports visitors to a bygone era, where military might and strategic fortifications were paramount. The craftsmanship of the Derawar Cannon is truly remarkable. Carved from solid brass, its intricate design showcases the skill and dedication of the artisans who crafted it centuries ago. From the meticulously detailed patterns adorning its surface to the imposing barrel pointing skyward, every aspect of the cannon speaks to a rich cultural heritage. Beyond its aesthetic appeal, the Derawar Cannon holds significant historical importance. Built during the reign of the Abbasi dynasty, it served as a vital defense mechanism against external threats, safeguarding the region and its inhabitants. Its strategic location near the Derawar Fort further highlights its importance in the region's military history. Visitors to the Derawar Cannon are not only treated to a glimpse of the past but also have the opportunity to immerse themselves in the vibrant culture of Bahawalpur. Surrounding the cannon, the Cholistan Desert offers breathtaking vistas and the chance to explore the natural beauty of the region. In conclusion, the Derawar Cannon is a must-visit destination for history enthusiasts, architecture aficionados, and anyone seeking to delve into Pakistan's rich cultural tapestry. Its imposing presence, intricate craftsmanship, and historical significance make it a truly unforgettable experience. combined_text: Muhammad Ali Jinnah Mausoleum Mausoleum / National Monument The magnificent mausoleum of the founder of Pakistan, Quaid-e-Azam Muhammad Ali Jinnah. Mazar-e-Quaid: A Symbol of National Pride Mazar-e-Quaid, the final resting place of Pakistan's founder, Muhammad Ali Jinnah, is more than just a mausoleum; it is an iconic symbol of national identity and a must-visit landmark in Karachi. The striking structure, designed in a 1960s modernist style by architect Yahya Merchant, is a masterpiece of white marble, conveying a sense of serenity and dignity. The large, elevated cuboid mausoleum, topped with a pristine dome, stands proudly amidst expansive, lush green gardens. Approaching the tomb offers a solemn experience, reflecting the immense historical and cultural significance of the site. Visitors can appreciate the architectural details, including the elegant curved Moorish arches and copper grills. The complex also houses the tombs of Jinnahs sister, Fatima Jinnah, and Pakistans first Prime Minister, Liaquat Ali Khan, among other prominent figures. Beneath the mausoleum, a museum displays personal belongings of the Quaid-e-Azam, offering a tangible connection to his life and vision. The sight of the military guard changing ceremony is a powerful display of respect. Visiting Mazar-e-Quaid is a profoundly moving experience, inspiring a deep sense of national pride and reverence for the "Father of the Nation." Its a beautifully maintained, solemn space perfect for reflection and appreciating the enduring legacy of Pakistan's struggle for The Muhammad Ali Jinnah Mausoleum is one of the most iconic landmarks in Karachi and a symbol of respect for the founder of Pakistan. The white marble structure is breathtaking, and the peaceful atmosphere makes it a powerful place for reflection. The grounds are well-maintained, with spacious walkways and greenery. Visiting during weekdays is best since its less crowded, and you can truly appreciate the architecture and the history it represents. Not much decorated or managed as required Museum near the tomb was well managed One thing no one is allowed to visit grave of Quaid e Azam Must require special permission ( security office in side the building in special cases) without charges or fee

combined_text: Bukkur Fort Historical Fort A historical fort located on an island in the Indus River near Rohri. Great but Bukkar fort walls need to be rebuilt at many places,as it's a sand and soil ,tie with lime stone,marble pieces and utensils pieces and local rocks bounded by Small bricks, so if rain,land sliding is too quick at places where historical wall is broken. Nothing special inside Fort now, except a view points.beautiful views and Great climate. Please post your photographs of Bukkur (Bakhar) Fort. I am a specialist in medieval Islamic cartography and I believe that this is a really important site. I would like to see more pictures. It needs expert archaeological work and definitely that fort needs to be restored. It is a small island in River Indus located between the towns of Sukkur and Rohri. The island, which is irregular in shape, is about 2 furlong broad in the North-South directions and 4 furlong long in the East-West directions. The entire island falls within the Fort as the fortification wall runs on the outer periphery of the island, touching the Indus water around. The western portion is inhabited and has backs and parade ground devoid of any monument except for a shrine and ruined mosque, but there are indications that this part once contained many buildings, etc. as the whole area is littered with brick-bats, pottery shreds, and heaps of earth collected over, collapsed structures. The fortification wall, which used to go around the entire island, has disappeared except for a few portions here and there and on the southern and north-western side. It is made from burnt brick tiles of 12x12x21 size, though there are many different sizes of bricks that have been used in it, probably for repair purposes. A number of bastions of semi-circular and elliptical shapes are still standing there. Also, along with them can be seen gate-ways of different sizes that are now looked with rubble. The fortification wall is about 5 thick, but at places, it reduces to only 2 but at places, it is only 10 high. The railway line divides this into two equal parts. The western part has only two buildings, one modern shrine or tomb, and the other is a mosque built of burnt bricks in mud. The eastern part, however, only contains foundations of walls here and there. STDC

combined_text: Empress Market Historical Market A large, historic Victorian-era market in Karachi, known for its architecture and diverse goods. A must visit for everyone going to Karachi. It stands symbol for the colonial times and it is still used for its original purpose: a market. You will find spices, fruits and veggies, household items, meat. Empress Market in Saddar, Karachi, is more than just a market; it's a living piece of history. The grand, colonial-era building with its distinctive clock tower still stands proudly, a testament to its British Raj origins. While it has undergone significant changes in recent years, particularly with the removal of encroachments, its bustling spirit remains. Today, Empress Market is primarily a hub for wholesale and retail of fresh produce  fruits, vegetables, meat, and a dazzling array of spices that awaken the senses. You'll find vendors specializing in everything from exotic dry fruits to everyday condiments. It's a fantastic place to experience the raw, vibrant energy of Karachi's local commerce, with the constant chatter of vendors and the lively crowd. Though some of the informal stalls that once spilled out onto the streets are gone, the market continues to be an essential part of Karachi's daily life, offering competitive prices and a vast selection. It's a truly authentic Karachi experience, a place where history and commerce intertwine. Be prepared for a sensory overload in the best possible way! A Historic Landmark That Needs Better Maintenance Empress Market is one of Karachis most iconic landmarks, steeped in colonial history and bustling with activity. Built between 1884 and 1889, the market was constructed to commemorate Queen Victoria, the Empress of India, during British rule. However, its location has a deeper historical significancethis was the site where Mangal Pandey, along with other Indian soldiers, was reportedly executed after the 1857 War of Independence. Today, Empress Market remains a vital commercial hub, offering everything from spices and dry fruits to household goods. Walking through its grand arched entrance, you can still see remnants of its original British-era architecture, a reminder of its historical past. However, the market is now overcrowded, and while the variety of goods available is impressive, the overall cleanliness leaves much to be desired. The markets historic charm is overshadowed by litter, poor waste management, and encroachments. To truly restore Empress Markets former grandeur, there is an urgent need for better cleanliness and maintenance. Additionally, more greenery around the market would complement its historical aesthetics, making it a more pleasant space for visitors. Proper restoration efforts, along with stricter waste management policies, could transform this site into not just a shopping destination but also a well-preserved historical attraction. Despite these shortcomings, Empress Market remains a must-visit for those who appreciate Karachis rich history and vibrant street culture. A little more care and restoration could elevate it to a five-star landmark.

combined_text: Jukhar Historical Mound Archaeological Site An archaeological site associated with the ancient Indus Valley Civilization. Jhukar are situated on the right side of the road just opposite the Allied Textile Mills. The mounds at Jhukar of great Archaeological and Historical importance, which have yielded remains from the period of Moenjodaro down to the 5th Century A.D. These mounds however, are not so extensive as Mohenjodaro. In Union Council mithodero, of Larkana district, about 2 mile west of the larkana karachi indus Highway, N55, there is a Daro called jhokar jo daro. Jhukar historical mounds On Google maps, it lies almost at the centre of the beige swathe of nothingness between the Highway and the Indus Highway. Relegated to non-existence on Google, the village is made up of approximately 60 homes. Its residents, the only route leading to the village is a mud track along a canal bank. There are many such remote settlements in the taluka. However, there is something unique about this one. Right beside the village is a vast mound that covers more than twice the surface area of the settlement itself. The Sindhi word for mound is daro and this gives the settlement its name  jhokar jo daro; the Mound of the jhukar in the same manner as the daro in Mohenjo-Daro. The mound is about a mile in length, half a mile in width at one end and less than a quarter mile in width at the other end. With gradual ease, it rises to a height of approximately 30 feet. Locals are of the view that the mound may have been created by the debris of a village that stood here in the not-so-distant past. Although it is near impossible to locate records on past settlements in the area, the notion is questionable. Other sites of abandoned villages have no mounds in their midst. Some villages are built on high ground so as to provide protection from flooding, but Daro Labara is not located on the mound so much as at the foot of it. For such a mound to be created by the debris of a recent village, the village would have had to have unusually high buildings..... Best luck

_key: Archaeological Site of Mangrian Jo Daro
combined_text: Archaeological Site of Mangrian Jo Daro Archaeological Site An archaeological site associated with the ancient Indus Valley Civilization. Visiting Mohenjo-daro felt like stepping into a forgotten world  it was surreal. Walking through those ancient streets, I could almost imagine life thousands of years ago. The Great Bath especially amazed me; such engineering in that time blew my mind. What struck me most was how advanced and organized their city was. Its a place that makes you feel small but deeply connected to history. Mohenjo-Daro! One of the most fascinating ancient civilizations in history. Mohenjo-Daro (which means "Mound of the Dead" in Sindhi) was a major city of the Indus Valley Civilization, located in present-day Pakistan. It was built around 2500 BCE and abandoned around 1900 BCE. Here are some interesting facts about Mohenjo-Daro: - Sophisticated urban planning: Mohenjo-Daro had advanced drainage systems, public baths, and well-planned streets. - Architecture: The city featured impressive buildings, including the Great Bath, Granary, and Citadel. - Water management: Mohenjo-Daro had a complex system for water supply and drainage. - Trade: The city was a major center for trade, with connections to ancient civilizations in Mesopotamia, Egypt, and China. - Writing system: The Indus Valley Civilization had a unique writing system, which remains undeciphered. - Art and craft: Mohenjo-Daro is famous for its seals, amulets, and pottery. - Decline: The city was abandoned due to climate change, drought, or invasions. Mohenjo-Daro is a testament to the ingenuity and achievements of ancient civilizations. Its discovery has shed light on the history of human culture and urbanization. Would you like to know more? I recently had the privilege of visiting Mohenjo-Daro, one of the world's oldest cities. As I stepped into the ancient Indus Valley Civilization site, I felt a deep connection to history. The sheer scale of the ruins left me awestruck, with crumbling structures that whispered tales of the past. I wandered through the narrow alleys, imagining life in this 4,500-year-old metropolis. The sophisticated urban planning and architecture amazed me, showcasing the advanced civilization that once thrived here. The Great Bath, a massive ancient pool, stood out as a testament to the city's impressive engineering feats. As I explored the site, I noticed the intricate carvings and seals that adorned the walls and artifacts. The museum on site housed an impressive collection of relics, including jewelry, pottery, and sculptures. Visiting Mohenjo-Daro was a humbling experience that reminded me of the rich cultural heritage of the Indian subcontinent. The experience left an indelible mark on my mind, inspiring me to learn more about this fascinating ancient civilization.

combined_text: Jamrud Fort Historical Fort A historic fort located at the entrance of the Khyber Pass, built by the Sikh Empire. Although this fort is now under control of Pak Army but still you can have some beautifull photos outside. The scenary is good and the view of fort from a distance is also worth capturing. Its very near to khyber pass so if you visit khyber pass you can also be able to visit this fort form outside and as I said can capture beatifull picture of mounatins as well. Construction: The fort was built in just 54 days by the Sikhs to mark the western edge of their empire. Purpose: It was built to defend against Afghan forces and to control the Khyber Pass. Location: It is located at a strategic point at the entrance of the Khyber Pass, which is a historically important route between Pakistan and Afghanistan. Historical Significance: The fort was the site of the Battle of Jamrud in 1837, where Hari Singh Nalwa was killed.It also served as a British military base during the British Raj. Current Use: Today, the fort is the headquarters of the Frontier Corps, a branch of the Pakistan Army. The fort is a significant historical landmark and a popular tourist destination. Jamrud Fort: A Historical Marvel Located at the entrance of the Khyber Pass, Jamrud Fort is a historical fortress that has stood the test of time. Built in 1836 by Hari Singh Nalwa, the fort has played a significant role in the region's history, serving as a strategic military outpost and a symbol of power. *Key Features:* - *Historical Significance*: Jamrud Fort has witnessed numerous battles and sieges, including the famous Battle of Jamrud in 1837. - *Architectural Appeal*: The fort's design reflects the traditional Sikh architecture of the time, with thick walls and imposing bastions. - *Panoramic Views*: The fort offers breathtaking views of the surrounding landscape, including the Khyber Pass and the nearby mountains. *Visitor Experience:* - *Exploring the Fort*: Visitors can explore the fort's imposing walls, bastions, and gates, getting a glimpse into the region's rich history. - *Learning Opportunities*: The fort provides a unique opportunity to learn about the region's history, culture, and architecture. - *Photography*: The fort's picturesque surroundings and imposing architecture make it a photographer's paradise. *Challenges:* - *Preservation*: The fort's preservation is a concern, with parts of the structure showing signs of wear and tear. - *Accessibility*: The fort's location and terrain can make it challenging for visitors with mobility issues. *Rating:* 4.5/5 stars *Recommendation:* Jamrud Fort is a must-visit destination for history enthusiasts, architecture buffs, and anyone interested in exploring the region's rich cultural heritage. Visitors should be prepared for a moderate hike to reach the fort and take necessary precautions to ensure their safety. Overall, Jamrud Fort is an iconic historical landmark that offers a glimpse into the region's rich history and cultural heritage. With proper preservation and maintenance, the fort can continue to attract visitors from around the world, promoting tourism and cultural exchange.

combined_text: The Kartarpur Corridor Religious Site / Monument A border crossing and religious corridor allowing visa-free access to the Gurdwara Darbar Sahib in Pakistan. A divine and peaceful experience. The management is excellent and the atmosphere fills your heart with calm and devotion. Being a Muslim myself, I really enjoyed my trip. Highly recommended and MUST VISIT for history lovers and those who cherish heritage. A historic and spiritual landmark! The Kartarpur Corridor is a beautifully maintained and deeply meaningful place for Sikh pilgrims and all those interested in peace and history. The entire process  from security checks to crossing the border  is smooth and well-managed. The view of Gurdwara Darbar Sahib in Pakistan from the Indian side is both emotional and awe-inspiring. A symbol of faith, unity, and devotion. Hats off to the authorities for maintaining it so well. Truly a must-visit experience!   Bridging Borders, Not Breaking Them  Today, I stood at Kartarpur Corridor, where two nations stand apartbut faith, peace, and humanity bring hearts together. This place isn't just sacred for Sikhsit's a symbol of whats possible when we choose peace over politics. Here, there are no visasjust respect, devotion, and the feeling that we are all one under the sky.  #KartarpurCorridor #PeaceBeyondBorders #SpiritualJourney #HumanityFirst #PunjabToPunjab #PakistanIndiaUnity #GurdwaraDarbarSahib

_key: Western Mound of Lakhian Jo Daro
combined_text: Western Mound of Lakhian Jo Daro Archaeological Site An archaeological site associated with the ancient Indus Valley Civilization. The site of Lakhanjo-Daro, located beneath modern Sukkur, Pakistan is one of the most important urban centers of the Indus Civilization and yet it has not been properly studied due to its location under a modern city that is rapidly expanding. This site was first discovered in 1985 and small-scale excavations and surveys were carried out by the faculty and students of Shah Abdul Latif University, Khairpur (Kazi 1985). Larger scale excavations were carried out by the same department in 2006 and then again during 2009/10 (Shaikh et al 2006, Mallah et al 2012). Due to various factors, it has not been possible to carry out more intensive horizontal excavations or long-term research on any single part of the site. Nevertheless, based on excavations in three different areas, two locations in the central mound and one in the western mound, it is clear that the ancient settlement of Lakhanjo-Daro is extremely large and spread over a vast area. Furthermore the artifacts recovered from the excavations, such as pottery, inscribed seals and figurines, are very similar to those found at other major cities of the Indus Valley region.
