combined_text: Lahori Gate Historical Landmark One of the main entrances to the Walled City of Lahore, leading to the bustling Shahi Bazaar. Delhi Gate is one of the most iconic entrances to the Walled City of Lahore and a must-visit for anyone exploring the citys heritage. The gate itself is centuries old and full of character, giving you a glimpse of Mughal-era grandeur. Walking through it feels like stepping back in time. Inside, youll find a bustling bazaar with shops selling everything from fabrics, handicrafts, spices, to traditional food. The energy here is unmatched  its lively, colorful, and truly captures the essence of old Lahore. Its also home to some amazing historical landmarks nearby, like Masjid Wazir Khan and Shahi Hammam, which makes the visit even more worthwhile. The narrow streets, traditional architecture, and local culture make it a perfect spot for history lovers and photographers. The only downside is the traffic and crowd, but thats part of the authentic old-city experience. Highly recommended if you want to see the real heart of Lahore. Delhi Gate in Lahore is a remarkable historical landmark that beautifully captures the essence of the citys rich cultural heritage. The area around the gate is vibrant and full of life, with traditional architecture, local markets, and authentic street food that offers a glimpse into the old walled city of Lahore. Visiting Delhi Gate feels like stepping back in time, surrounded by centuries of history and charm. It's a must-visit spot for anyone interested in exploring the historical and cultural depth of Lahore. Truly a gem in the heart of the city Delhi Gate is one of the most amazing historical spots in Lahore. Its part of the old Walled City and has been nicely restored. When you walk through the gate, it really feels like youve gone back in time. The old streets, the atmosphere, everything gives a true Lahori vibe. Right nearby is the famous Wazir Khan Mosque  seriously beautiful and worth seeing! There are also old havelis, small shops, and tasty street food all around. Great place for history lovers, tourists, or anyone who wants to feel the real culture of Lahore. Do visit if you get the chance!

combined_text: Taxali Gate Historical Landmark One of the historic gates of the Walled City of Lahore, traditionally known as the gate for entertainers. Taxali gate is one of the thirteenth historical gates of Historical Lahore. It's now called Androon Lahore inside walled city. Taxali derived from Taxal means factory where Mughal stamps on coins where produced during Mughal era . This place also been famous for music & dance community. Taxali gate is no more present at this place. Some old buildings in Bazar can be seen only. Roads and street with new construction of buildings change the whole look of the area. There are many food points in Chowk Heera Mandi. Among specialist sweets stores are Taj Mahal Halwa Puri, Shahabuddin Halwai and Bhola Lassi Wala. Heera Mandi also called 'Shahi Mohalla', a defunct red light district, used to lie close to this gate,where Mughal Emperors used to house their royal consorts. Taxali Gate also serves as Union Council 30 (UC 30) in Tehsil Ravi Town of Lahore City District of Punjab, Pakistan. There is a sense of religious harmony that once was in this area. A gurdawara, mosque and a church are there in the same vicinity. it was an amazing experience Taxali Gate is one of the original 13 gates of the Walled City of Lahore, rich in history, culture, and old-world charm. Once a grand entrance to the city during the Mughal era, today it stands as a reminder of Lahores glorious past. While the actual gate no longer exists, the surrounding area is a vibrant mix of history, food, and traditional markets. The streets near Taxali Gate are famous for authentic Lahori cuisine, including legendary spots like Phajja Siri Paye and local halwa puri shops. The area also has deep cultural significance, with historic buildings, mosques, and remnants of Mughal and Sikh architecture. While the hustle and bustle add to its charm, the narrow lanes and heavy traffic can be overwhelming for visitors unfamiliar with the area. However, for those who love exploring Lahores heritage, street food, and historical sites, Taxali Gate is a must-visit!  Tip: Best visited early in the morning for breakfast or in the evening for an immersive cultural experience. Wear comfortable shoes, as the streets can be crowded and uneven.

combined_text: Qutb-ud-Din Aibak's Tomb Mausoleum The tomb of the first Sultan of the Delhi Sultanate, located in Anarkali Bazaar, Lahore. Qutab ud Din Aibak's tomb is a hidden gem nestled in the heart of Lahore's bustling Urdu Bazar, and it's a must-visit for anyone looking for a tranquil escape from the city's chaos. This small island of peace and tranquility is a testament to the rich history of the region, and the tomb itself is a stunning example of architectural beauty, with intricate marble grills and beautiful calligraphy adorning its walls. Qutab ud Din Aibak, the founder of the Delhi Sultanate and a renowned military commander, played a pivotal role in shaping India's medieval history, and his legacy continues to inspire awe and reverence. As you step into the tomb, you're surrounded by an eerie silence, punctuated only by the soft rustling of leaves and the whispers of the past. Despite being a lesser-known site, Qutab ud Din Aibak's tomb is an absolute gem that deserves to be explored, and its historical significance and serene ambiance make it a perfect spot for history buffs, architecture enthusiasts, and anyone seeking solace from the city's frenetic pace. Visited the tomb of Qutb-ud-din Aibak, the first Sultan of Delhi, located in Lahore. Its a historical landmark with great significance, but sadly it doesnt get the care and attention it deserves. The structure itself is small but holds immense value as part of our heritage. The tomb is tucked away in a busy area, so reaching it can feel a bit chaotic. Once inside, you get a sense of peace and history, but the surroundings and maintenance could be improved. Proper preservation and cleaner management would make it a much better experience for visitors. Still, for anyone interested in history and heritage, its definitely worth a visit. Standing there makes you feel connected to centuries of history. This was my first time visiting this tomb in lahore, architecture is very beautiful and there are Arabic writings on the front. Although the floor seems clean but it was extremely dirty.

combined_text: Astore Valley Valley A valley in Gilgit-Baltistan known for its dramatic landscapes, including the Deosai Plains and access to Nanga Parbat. "Astore Valley: Breathtaking scenery, rich history, and warm hospitality. A hidden gem in Gilgit-Baltistan, perfect for trekking, camping, and nature lovers." A journey you will never forget. Astore Valley is a stunning and peaceful destination in Gilgit-Baltistan, Pakistan. Surrounded by snow-covered mountains and green meadows, it's perfect for nature lovers and trekkers. The valley offers fresh air, clean water, and beautiful views all around. Places like Rama Lake and Deosai Plains are nearby and add more beauty to the area. Roads can be rough, but the experience is worth it. Astore Valley is a breathtakingly beautiful destination in Gilgit-Baltistan, Pakistan, known for its stunning scenery, diverse wildlife, and adventure activities. Here's what you can expect: Scenic Beauty The valley offers picturesque views of lush green meadows, towering mountains, and crystal-clear streams. The scenery is particularly breathtaking during the summer months when wildflowers bloom in vibrant colors. Places to Visit - *Rama Lake*: A popular spot with stunning views of Nanga Parbat, the world's ninth-highest mountain. - *Deosai National Park*: Home to a variety of wildlife, including the Himalayan brown bear and snow leopards. - *Minimarg*: A scenic town with breathtaking views of the surrounding mountains. - *Rupal Valley*: Known for its stunning scenery and trekking opportunities. Activities - *Trekking*: Explore the valley's vast wilderness and enjoy stunning views. - *Camping*: Set up camp by the river or in designated campsites. - *Fishing*: Try your luck at catching trout in the valley's streams. Tour Packages Rozefs Tourism offers a 4-day tour package to Astore Valley, including: - *Hotel Accommodation*: Stay in comfortable hotels with scenic views. - *Tour Guide*: Explore the valley with an experienced guide. - *Transportation*: Travel in comfort with transportation services. - *Breakfast*: Enjoy delicious breakfasts at hotels. Reviews Travelers have praised Astore Valley for its stunning scenery and warm hospitality. One reviewer mentioned that the tour exceeded their expectations, with breathtaking views of Nanga Parbat and excellent services from Rozefs Tourism . Essential Information - *Location*: Astore Valley is located in Gilgit-Baltistan, Pakistan. - *Best Time to Visit*: Summer months (June to September) are ideal for visiting. - *Getting There*: The valley is accessible by road, with the nearest airport in Gilgit. Overall, Astore Valley is a must-visit destination for nature lovers and adventure seekers. Its stunning scenery, diverse wildlife, and range of activities make it an unforgettable experience.

combined_text: Bilamik Scenic Area A scenic area in the Astore Valley, often a stop for trekkers and tourists. 2.5 hours of off road track and you get to this place, which is not even big enough that consumes your single day. Wouldnt recommend people to go here. Bilamik Valley - Heaven on Earth Bilamik/Thorchay is one of the most beautiful valley in the Subdivision Roundu of Skardu District. Its lush green landscapes  are adorned with crystal clear water streams. Flocks of sheep and cows  can be seen grazing in these green fields which makes the scene even more charming. The primary source of livelihood in this region revolves around agriculture, with potatoes being the foremost vegetable exported from this area. We saw only one guest house in this area known as "Summer Heaven Guest House".Its the only guest house in Bilamik but also very well maintained and cozy with breathtaking natural beauty, and mountain views. visited on 4 June 2024. The jeep ride up to the valley which is at an altitude of more than 3200 metres above sea level is an achievement in itself involves ascending above 1000 metres higher from Skardu on a dirt road with steep drops. It can be hair raising but a lot of fun and with amazing view. Thank you to Globetrotters Pakistan for suggesting this place

combined_text: Rush lake trek Trekking Route The trek to Rush Lake, the highest alpine lake in Pakistan, near Passu. Rush Lake The Rush lake is a beautiful high altitude lake in Gilgit-Baltistan. It is near Rush Pari Peak at an elevation of 5,098 metres (16,726 feet) above sea level. Since it is on the height of 4,694 meters (15,400 feet), Rush lake is 25th most highest lake of the world and highest in Pakistan The trek towards the Rush lake in Gilgit-Baltistan, is very rough and tricky with continuous ascending and descending while climbing up. It is not everyones cup of tea to reach there. Only a few determined and adventurous people can capture it. Tourists can over look the Spantik Peak, Malubiting Peak, Miar Peak, Phuparash Peak and Ultarsar Peak from the lake. After reaching at the lake, its mesmerizing beauty and splendeur, the tourists are alluring by the breath-taking scenery on such an elevation, which cannot describe in the words, but could feel only by heart. It is truly a heaven on the Earth. The most noticable feature of our expedition is that we didn't hire any porter and guide which is not recommended due to deadly crevasses on Hoper Glacier and difficulty level of trek Rush Lake is located in the Hoper Village of the former state of Nagar Valley, which is now a sub-division located in the Hunza-Nagar district of Gilgit-Baltistan. Situated around 4,500 meters above sea level, Rush Lake is one of the most beautiful water bodies found in Pakistan. It is believed to be among the highest alpine lakes of the country. The towering Miar Peak and Spantik (Golden Peak) are located at a distance of not more than 15 kilometers from the lake. Rush Peak is a mountain in the Karakoram mountain range of Central Asia. It is located in the Nagar District of Gilgit-Baltistan, Pakistan. While not a high peak by local standards, it is noteworthy as a remote trekking destination. It can be reached via Nagar Valley and Hoper Village. The peak can be accessed via Hoper Glacier (Bualtar Glacier) and Barpu Glacier. The peak is relatively easy to climb in the summer months and ascents have been made by amateur climbers without proper mountaineering gear. In winter, access to the mountain is made difficult by heavy snows. The top of the peak provides stunning views of Miar Peak (6,824 m), Miar Glacier and Phuparash Peak (6,574 m). On a clear day, one can look east and see some of the world's highest mountains, including K2 and Broad Peak. At the mountain's base lies one of the world's highest alpine lakes, Rush Lake (4,694m). Copied Rush lake is one the world's most beautiful and highest alpine lakes located in the lap of alluring Rush peak Hoper Nagar. It is surrounded by lush green meadows. Cattle graze in the meadow adds more charm to the tourists visiting that place.

combined_text: Chunda Valley Valley A scenic valley in Skardu, known for its apricot orchards and traditional culture. Incredible valley ~1hr from Skardu, high above the city with epic panoramic views of Skardu and the airport. Green meadows carpeted with spring blossoms and fruit orchards, with crystal streams flowing through. Easy to reach by jeep or a 30min hike. Peaceful, scenic and perfect for camping or a picniclocals are hospitable and welcoming. Best in spring and summer, but autumn foliage is stunning too. A must-visit spot! During our stay in Skardu, we had the opportunity to explore the breathtaking Chunda Valley. This hidden gem is a must-visit destination for nature lovers and adventure seekers. The valley's stunning natural beauty is characterized by its vibrant Cassia Nodossa tree flowers, lush green landscapes, and majestic snow-capped mountains in the background. The valley is a haven for those who appreciate the beauty of nature. The picturesque scenery, complete with flowery trees and rolling hills, is truly breathtaking. Visitors can spend 2-3 hours exploring the valley, hiking, and trekking through its winding trails. Very peaceful and mesmerising valley. We went in a jeep because the road is very rocky and bumpy so its better to take those cars. Its a small valley you can also hike on the mountains if you want to . But make sure to take your water and some snacks with yourself because there are not many shops available.

combined_text: Katora Lake (Kumrat) Alpine Lake A high-altitude lake in the Kumrat Valley, shaped like a bowl ("katora"). My journey to Katora Lake began from the beautiful Jahazbanda meadows. The trek was not easy, but the destination was worth every step. When I finally reached, the sight of the turquoise-blue lake left me speechless. The lake is surrounded by majestic peaks, adding to its charm. Boats are also available here, letting you sail and enjoy the calm waters. Katora Lake is truly a hidden paradise in the mountains. Katora Lake Pakistan Katora Lake Height (11,500 feet/3,500 m from Sea level) Kumrat Valley is a high frosty lake situated at the upper ranges of Jahaz Banda. The region of the Upper Dir District of KPK. Due to this, you will witness the crystal clear greenish climate of the lake. The word Katora signifies bowl in Pashto (bowl-shaped). Mostly people think about the Katora Lake hike in Pakistan. First of all, a 4 to 5-hour trek from Thal village to Jahaz Banda. After all, trekkers stay at camps under the billion stars of Jahaz Banda Meadows. The very next day, a 3 to 4-hour trek to the Lake one-sided. How to Reach Katora Lake: So just returned from one of the most hectic trips ever (mainly due to time shortage) I thought why not right some wrongs one might face while traveling there?Our target was to attempt the Katora Lake trek, Jahaz Banda, and its vicinity and after that explore the ever-beautiful Kumrat valley.  It takes you about 7 hrs. to reach near Upper Dir so if you have left it late your first stop should be in Upper Dir. (you can easily find hotels there for a reasonable night stay around 2000-3000).  Moreover, From Dir one must go back about 8.8Km precisely where you could find Bab-e-Kumrat which would take you to Sheringal Town. (approx. travelling time 3:00 hrs.) The road is in relatively good condition however there are a few bad patches though.  In Addition, From Sheringal it would take around 3-4 hrs. depending on the condition of your vehicle to reach Thal (a kind of base camp for everything in that valley). Road condition is also okay here.  From Thal one can hire Jeeps to do either Jahaz Banda or Kumrat Valley. It is advisable to leave your vehicles in Thal. Jeeps Fare from Thal to Jahaz Banda Lake: Thal Jeeps or 44 vehicles can take you to the highest point Taki Top from where the actual trek for Jahaz Banda starts. The jeeps fare or charges from Thal to Taki Top Jahaz Banda Meadows and back to Thal range between Rs.10000 to Rs.12000 with 1 or 2-night stays at Jahaz Banda. Katora Lake, Kumrat Valley, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan If theres a reflection of heaven on Earth, it surely lies in the heart of Katora Lake. Nestled deep within the majestic Kumrat Valley of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, this alpine glacial lake is a hidden gem that captures the soul of every nature lover. Location & Access: Location: Upper Dir District, Kumrat Valley, KPK Elevation: Approximately 11,500 feet (3,500 meters) above sea level Access Route: From Thal town, it requires a multi-day journey involving a jeep ride followed by a moderate to difficult trek  but every step is worth the breathtaking scenery. The Beauty of the Lake: Katora Lake, named after its bowl-like shape ("Katora" means bowl in Pashto/Urdu), is a mesmerizing body of turquoise-blue water surrounded by snow-capped mountains and lush meadows. The lake is crystal clear, reflecting the skies above like a mirror. It's the kind of view that makes you pause and simply breathe. Best Time to Visit: June to September is the ideal time  the paths are clear of snow, the weather is pleasant, and the valley is in full bloom. Travel Tips: Wear proper trekking shoes and warm clothing Carry water, light snacks, and a basic first aid kit Hiring a local guide is highly recommended for safety and navigation The Locals: The people of this region are incredibly warm-hearted and hospitable. Their simplicity and traditions add depth to the journey. Sharing a meal or tea with them becomes a story to remember. Final Thoughts: Katora Lake is not just a destination  its an experience. A spiritual escape, a scenic wonder, and a reminder of how stunning and untouched our world can still be. If you are a lover of mountains, lakes, and serene silence, visiting Katora Lake will be one of the most unforgettable chapters of your life.

combined_text: Rainbow Lake (Minimarg) Alpine Lake A lake in the Minimarg valley known for its stunning colors and reflections. Raw nature at its best. Breathtaking panoramic views all around. Best place to visit in Pakistan. Good facilities for dining and recreation. Plenty of parking. Only 4x4 vehicles allowed. Bikes over 150cc allowed. Overnight stay allowed for those who have booking in guest rooms or tent village only. Best time to visit is from April to September. Journey to the place is relatively tough but worth every second. Visiting Rainbow Lake near Minimarg was quite an adventure, its a bit of a mission to get there! The place itself is absolutely beautiful and would be perfect for a family outing, but the journey might be challenging for some. The road via Astore, Chillum, and Minimarg is mostly off-road and can be tough to navigate. That said, the stunning views and breathtaking scenery along the way make it worthwhile, though perhaps better suited for more adventurous travelers. There's also the historic Musharraf Hut nearby, named after General Musharraf, who reportedly stayed there during the Kargil conflict between the two neighboring countries. A beautiful lake nestled in probably the most beautiful valley in Pakistan, Minimarg. They allow tourists for a day visit in this beautiful valley now but you need a 4x4 vehicle or a motorcycle with minimum 150cc engine. Keep your NIC with you and dont travel with drones, camping equipment.

combined_text: Rakaposhi Mountain Peak The 7,788m mountain and its base camp viewpoints in the Nagar Valley. Rakaposhi Hunza Mountains Beauty, Height, Sunrise, and Roads, all stands at an impressive 7,788 meters (25,551 feet), is the 27th-highest mountain in the world and one of the most stunning peaks in the Karakoram Range of Pakistan. It is located in the Nagar Valley, in the Gilgit-Baltistan region, and is renowned for its striking beauty, especially when illuminated by the first light of dawn. The mountain's grandeur is further enhanced by the surrounding landscapes, making it a must-see destination for trekkers, mountaineers, and nature lovers. Its breathtaking scenery, along with the roads that lead toward it and the unforgettable sunrises, create an awe-inspiring experience for all who visit. -Rakaposhis Majestic Beauty Rakaposhi is not just known for its height but for the sheer beauty it exudes. The mountain is characterized by its steep slopes, massive glaciers, and sharp ridges. Its snow-covered peaks, towering over the lush green valleys below, make it look like something out of a dream. The surrounding environment, with its wild rivers, alpine meadows, and rugged terrain, adds to the allure. -Sunrise over Rakaposhi: A Spectacle of Colors One of the most magical experiences for anyone visiting Rakaposhi is watching the sunrise over its towering peaks. Early mornings at Rakaposhi are nothing short of breathtaking. As the first rays of sunlight hit the mountain, the snow-covered peaks catch fire, turning into shades of gold, pink, and orange. This spectacle, known as "Alpenglow," occurs when the sun casts its warm light on the high peaks, creating a glowing effect that makes Rakaposhi even more majestic. -Roads Leading to Rakaposhi: An Adventurous Journey The journey to Rakaposhi is an adventure in itself, as the roads leading to it wind through some of the most remote and rugged terrain in the world. Starting from Gilgit, travelers make their way through narrow, winding roads, passing through villages and picturesque landscapes. The route to Rakaposhi takes visitors along the Karimabad-Danyor road, which offers spectacular views of Rakaposhis snow-capped peaks, as well as other nearby mountains. The road from Gilgit to Hunza Valleywhere Rakaposhi is visible in the distanceis known for its breathtaking beauty. As the road curves through the steep hillsides, travelers can stop at various viewpoints to admire the mountains splendor. In addition, the Naltar Valley provides an alternative road to Rakaposhi, with equally scenic vistas, including lush forests, alpine lakes, and charming villages that dot the landscape. The journey is long, and the roads are often rough, but the scenic beauty and grandeur of Rakaposhi more than make up for the challenging drive. -The Road Ahead: Trekking to Rakaposhi Base Camp For those looking to get closer to Rakaposhis magnificent summit, trekking to the Rakaposhi Base Camp is an exciting option. The base camp trek is an extension of the journey to the mountain, starting from Minapin, a small village near Rakaposhi, and spanning approximately 8-10 days. The trail is a challenging but rewarding experience, taking trekkers through dense forests, meadows, and glacial landscapes while providing unparalleled views. The trek culminates at this Base Camp, where adventurers can witness the immense scale of the mountain up close and enjoy the dramatic views of the surrounding Karakoram Range. Rakaposhi, with its towering height, majestic beauty, and stunning sunrises, is a hidden gem in Pakistans mountainous landscapes. Whether youre admiring the mountain from the roads leading to it, trekking towards its base camp, or watching the sunrise light up its snow-covered peaks, the experience of being near it is unforgettable. The roads leading to this majestic peak are an adventure in themselves, offering travelers a chance to experience Pakistans natural beauty at its finest. The combination of stunning vistas, the awe-inspiring sunrise, and the challenging yet rewarding journey make it a must-visit destination for any mountain enthusiast or nature lover. A great view .Highly recommend. Must bring your camp and eating stuff Rakaposhi: A Majestic Experience Nestled in the heart of the Karakoram range, Rakaposhi stands as one of the most mesmerizing peaks in the world. With its towering height of 7,788 meters (25,551 feet), it is not only a sight to behold but also a significant challenge for mountaineers. Scenic Beauty Rakaposhi, meaning "Snow Covered" in the local language, lives up to its name with its pristine, glistening snow-capped peak. The mountain offers a breathtaking panorama, especially at sunrise and sunset when the golden hues dance on its icy surface. The view from Karimabad or the Hunza Valley is nothing short of spectacular, making it a paradise for photographers and nature enthusiasts. Climbing Experience For mountaineers, Rakaposhi presents both allure and challenge. The first successful ascent was in 1958 by a British-Pakistani expedition, and since then, it has drawn climbers from around the globe. The trek to the base camp itself is an adventure, passing through lush green valleys, traditional villages, and rugged terrains. Although it is considered one of the more accessible high peaks, the climb demands technical skills and thorough preparation due to its unpredictable weather and steep slopes. Cultural Encounter The region around Rakaposhi is rich in cultural heritage. The local communities are warm and hospitable, often inviting trekkers to experience their way of life. The unique blend of tradition and natural beauty offers a serene escape from the hustle and bustle of city life. Conclusion Whether you are an avid climber, a photographer, or someone seeking tranquility in nature, Rakaposhi has something to offer. Its majestic presence and the surrounding landscapes create an unforgettable experience, making it a must-visit destination in the Karakoram range.

combined_text: Babusar Top Mountain Pass A high mountain pass connecting Kaghan Valley with Gilgit-Baltistan. The place is wonderful with breathtaking views and majestic mountains. It could be maintained as an awesome tourist spot with proper amenities, but unfortunately, that is not the case. There are too many swings and zip lines installed in all directions, reducing the beauty of the place. Although the zip line on such height in itself is a thrilling experience for those who dare. The views are awesome, and they have a unique charisma to it. Babusar Top is one of the most stunning high-altitude mountain passes in Pakistan, located at 4,173 meters above sea level. It connects the Kaghan Valley with Chilas and Gilgit-Baltistan. The pass offers breathtaking views of snow-capped peaks, green meadows, and winding roads that make the journey unforgettable. The drive to Babusar Top is scenic and thrilling, especially during the summer months when the road is open. It's a favorite stop for tourists heading to northern areas, offering panoramic photo spots and a refreshing break from the lower valleys. However, the road can be dangerous in bad weather, so it's best to travel in daylight with a reliable vehicle. Babusar Top is ideal for nature lovers, photographers, and adventure seekers. It's peaceful, refreshing, and filled with natural beauty. A must-visit for anyone exploring northern Pakistan. Life's best experiences to reach and visit this Place . Alhamdu Lillah, worlds best and most Beautiful place in the world. Roads and place are safe. Its a Request to Pakistan govt and local govt KPK authorities to provide and avail basics need to improve like electricity, mobile facilities, Health facilities, road safety barrier and improve local people's.

combined_text: Burzil Top Mountain Pass A high mountain pass on the way to Astore and Minimarg from Gilgit. A strategic route located on the border of GB and AJK. Once an important trade route between Srinagar and GB is now a military controlled pass. Majestic views. Fully covered in snow with freezing winds and rapidly changing weather. Experienced snow blizzard . Children enjoyed a lot. Burzil Pass, standing tall at 13,491 ft, is a historic gateway connecting Astore Valley with Neelum Valley, Azad Kashmir. Once a vital part of the ancient trade route between Kashmir and Gilgit, it is now a seasonal wonderland, surrounded by snow-covered peaks, alpine meadows, and pristine wilderness. From Raikot Bridge, the distance is about 80 km, while Astore city lies just 40 km away. From Islamabad, the journey stretches nearly 400 km, while from Babusar Top, it is about 100 km via Chilas Zero Point. The pass also leads towards the enchanting Minimerg Valley and the famous Rainbow Lake Domail, located around 2025 km further, offering postcard-perfect scenery. Due to heavy snowfall, Burzil Pass remains open mainly in summer, making it a rare yet unforgettable adventure for nature lovers, photographers, and thrill seekers exploring the hidden treasures of Gilgit-Baltistan. Posted by Solasta Realtors and Builders Faisal Hills Taxila. Best highest stopover to Minimarg and Rainbow Lake.

combined_text: Shiger Fort Historical Fort A historic fort in the Shigar Valley, now a luxury hotel (Serena Shigar Fort).  United Pakistan Tours had the pleasure of hosting a group at Serena Shigar Fort, and it was truly an unforgettable experience. The fort perfectly combines history, culture, and comfort. Our guests were amazed by the royal architecture, peaceful ambiance, and warm hospitality of the Serena team. A true symbol of heritage preserved with care  we highly recommend it to all travelers visiting Skardu. The most scenic and historic location I have ever stayed at, surrounded by beautiful mountains and the Indus River. My family and I thoroughly enjoyed our time at this hotel, which featured excellent service and a fantastic staff. Highly recommended. Although the Fort is surrounded be beautiful mountains and great views, fort itself is very small. Half of it has been converted into hotel by Serena. Not worth visiting especially if you already have visited Baltit Fort (which is very rich in history and huge in size).

combined_text: Blind Lake (Shigar) Lake A lake in the Shigar Valley. Blind Lake is one of the best rustic camping spots for nature lovers. Tucked away in Pinckney Recreation Area, it offers peaceful lake views, clean basic facilities, and scenic trails. Site B3 is highly recommended for its stunning lakefront view. Ideal for hiking or paddling in, its quiet, remote, and perfect for a one-night escape into nature. Just bring your own firewood and be ready for a true back-to-basics camping experience! 200rs to enter for Pakistanis Only two places to sit and one is a broken bench. Rip off really for something which is natural. Didn't boat on the lake not really worth it Blind Lake, also known as Zharba Tso, is a beautiful and peaceful lake located in Shigar Valley near Skardu, Gilgit-Baltistan. Surrounded by mountains and situated between the Indus and Shigar Rivers, the lake has no visible water source, which is why its called Blind Lake. Its a perfect spot for nature lovers, offering activities like boating, camping, and photography. The calm water, scenic views, and peaceful environment make it an ideal place to relax. Though the road is rough, the lakes natural beauty makes the trip worth it for anyone visiting the Skardu region.

combined_text: Sarfaranga Cold Desert Desert A cold desert near Skardu, known for its sand dunes and stark landscape. Located about a 3035 minute drive (16 km) from Skardu, the Sarfaranga Cold Desert  also known as the Katpana Cold Desert  is a truly remarkable natural wonder. Perched at an altitude of around 7,500 feet (2,286 meters) near the Shigar Valley, its recognized as one of the highest cold deserts in the world. The landscape is breathtaking  endless stretches of golden sand framed by rugged mountains and clear blue skies. The contrast of desert dunes against the snow-capped peaks makes it a photographers dream and a must-visit destination for anyone traveling to Skardu. Visitors can enjoy several adventure activities, including:  Parasailing: around PKR 12,000 for a short 35 minute flight  Quad biking: approx. PKR 2,0003,000 for a few minutes or limited rounds  Jeep rides: up to PKR 10,000, ideal for exploring deeper into the desert  Horse rides and Jeep Wranglers are also available for a more leisurely experience While the adventure options are exciting, its worth noting that activity prices are quite high and may feel overpriced for short durations. However, the overall experience  the thrill, the scenery, and the peaceful vastness of the desert  makes it absolutely worth visiting. If youre planning a trip, set aside a few hours to soak in the views, enjoy a few activities, and capture the unique beauty of this high-altitude desert. I loved visiting the Sarfranga Cold Desert. Enjoyed paragliding, Desert safari and enjoyed a fresh cup of tea from the stalls. The views are breath taking with 360 degrees of snow capped mountains. Safranga has always been a treat. So many new activities to do there this time but a bit of a disclaimer regarding prices that they are on high side these days and I'll recommend visiting as groups not individual especially if you plan on doing jeep safari as it'll make it more affordable. Rest a great experience so far.

combined_text: Chaqchan Mosque Historical Mosque A historic mosque in Khaplu, over 700 years old, showcasing Tibetan architecture. Dating from 1370, this beautiful historical mosque with a rich history is one of the oldest. Entries for non-muslims were not allowed. This decision as per the residents' community. Lovely views of the Valleys from the halls. It features a blend of Tibetan, Mughal and Persian styles of architecture. A cute masjid built around 1370 when most of the population were converting from Tibetan Buddhism to Islam. We got told the history of the masjid whilst we we there . Beautiful location. So peaceful and with the most gorgeous of views.  "Chaqchan Mosque  one of the oldest and most beautiful mosques in Gilgit-Baltistan, standing gracefully since the 14th century a timeless masterpiece of wood and stone."

combined_text: Manthoka Waterfall Waterfall A famous waterfall in the Kharmang Valley. Just a 2.5-hour scenic drive from Skardu on a smooth, paved road lies a remarkable feat of engineering: a powerful artificial waterfall that mimics the raw beauty of a natural one. For an entry fee of PKR 200 per person, you can witness this spectacle. Be prepared for a commercialized atmosphere, with vendors and crowds that can challenge the tranquility. However, look past the hustle and bustlethe sight and thunderous sound of the water crashing down make it an unforgettable and highly recommended stop on your Skardu itinerary. My experience at Mantokha Waterfall was just amazing! The place is full of peace, natural beauty, and a refreshing vibe. The sound of water, the cool wind, and the view from that bridge were unforgettable. Especially that moment when I saw a foreigner lady standing on the bridge  she was smiling and enjoying the view, and for a second it felt like a movie scene! Truly, Mantokha is one of the most magical places Ive ever been to. Highly recommended for everyone who loves calmness and nature It is an artificial waterfall but still spectacular. Take some waterproofs with you so you can take an exhilarating walk through it. Go for a ride on the rapids too. Bit expensive as it only lasts a few minutes but worth it. Be prepared to get wet

combined_text: Shandur Pass Mountain Pass / Event Venue Host to the world's highest polo ground and an annual polo festival between Gilgit and Chitral. Shandur Pass is a breathtaking high-mountain pass located between Gilgit-Baltistan and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, at an altitude of around 12,000 feet. It is famous for hosting the annual Shandur Polo Festival, the highest polo ground in the world. Surrounded by snow-capped peaks and lush green meadows, the pass offers a unique mix of adventure, culture, and natural beauty. Summer is the best time to visit, as the roads are often blocked in winter due to snow. Visitors can enjoy camping, photography, and experience traditional mountain culture in a serene environment. A must-visit spot for nature and adventure lovers. World's Highest Pass is known as Shandur Pass is located Chitral & Gilgit Baltistan Border, The road Conditions are very difficult and Dangerous But Beauty Is End of World  This pass is a wonder itself... about 4/5 months this pass remains closed due to extreme weather & snowfall....

Phandar Valley, a hidden gem in Pakistan's Gilgit-Baltistan region, is renowned for its breathtaking landscapes and tranquil ambiance. Nestled amidst lush green fields and framed by snow-capped peaks, this valley is home to the serene Phandar Lake, where the water shifts in mesmerizing shades of blue and green. Known as "Little Kashmir," Phandar offers a perfect retreat for nature lovers, with opportunities for fishing, hiking, and peaceful boat rides. This picturesque valley has a rich cultural heritage and remains a peaceful escape for travelers seeking unspoiled natural beauty, making it a must-visit destination in northern Pakistan.

combined_text: Shounter Valley Valley A beautiful valley in Azad Kashmir, accessible from Kel, offering meadows and views. **Shounter Valley**, located in the Neelum District of Azad Jammu and Kashmir, Pakistan, is a picturesque and remote valley known for its rugged mountainous terrain and pristine natural beauty. The valley is surrounded by towering peaks, including those of the **Shounter Mountain** range, which form part of the greater Himalayas. Historically, the valley has been used as a key passage for shepherds and traders traveling between Neelum Valley and the Astore Valley in Gilgit-Baltistan via the Shounter Pass, which sits at an altitude of 4,420 meters (14,500 feet). The area is also home to the famous Shounter Lake, a glacial lake that adds to the valleys scenic charm. Despite its remote location, Shounter Valley attracts trekkers and adventurers looking to explore its untouched landscapes. The valleys harsh winters and rugged terrain make it a challenging destination, but its natural beauty and historical significance as a crossroads of ancient routes continue to draw visitors. Shounter Valley and shounter lake which also called SPOON LAKE is situtaed at shounter Valley. Main Attractions of Shounter Valleys are 1-Chitta Katha Lake 2-Spoon Lake 3-Hari Parbat 4-Shounter Water Fall 5-SarWaliTop (Highest Peat of AJK) There is camping site also available for tourist over all beautiful place with its original condition not destructive so far by the tourist. There is Track available for trekking lover from there they reach ASTORE from Shounter. Small but very uniquely shaped lake in middle of snowy gigantic mountains.

combined_text: Shayoka Waterfall Waterfall A spectacular waterfall in the Skardu region, known for its powerful cascade. Just a 2.5-hour scenic drive from Skardu on a smooth, paved road lies a remarkable feat of engineering: a powerful artificial waterfall that mimics the raw beauty of a natural one. For an entry fee of PKR 200 per person, you can witness this spectacle. Be prepared for a commercialized atmosphere, with vendors and crowds that can challenge the tranquility. However, look past the hustle and bustlethe sight and thunderous sound of the water crashing down make it an unforgettable and highly recommended stop on your Skardu itinerary. My experience at Mantokha Waterfall was just amazing! The place is full of peace, natural beauty, and a refreshing vibe. The sound of water, the cool wind, and the view from that bridge were unforgettable. Especially that moment when I saw a foreigner lady standing on the bridge  she was smiling and enjoying the view, and for a second it felt like a movie scene! Truly, Mantokha is one of the most magical places Ive ever been to. Highly recommended for everyone who loves calmness and nature It is an artificial waterfall but still spectacular. Take some waterproofs with you so you can take an exhilarating walk through it. Go for a ride on the rapids too. Bit expensive as it only lasts a few minutes but worth it. Be prepared to get wet

combined_text: Karambar Lake Alpine Lake One of the highest alpine lakes in the world, located on the border of Ishkoman and Chitral. We recently had an unforgettable trip to Karambar Lake  truly a masterpiece of nature. While the trek to the lake is challenging, the breathtaking scenery that awaits makes every step worth it. The moment you arrive, the stunning natural beauty instantly washes away all the exhaustion. A must-visit for adventure lovers and nature enthusiasts! Karamber Lake is one of the most breathtaking places I have ever seen. Reaching here was not an easy journey, but every step was worth it. The moment I caught the first glimpse of the lake, all my exhaustion faded away. Its crystal-clear water and peaceful surroundings felt like a dream. Standing there was the most beautiful moment of my life. Karamber Lake will always stay in my heart as a symbol of pure serenity Mastuj Bazar To Karamber lake distance total 125 km 97 km Jeep track and last 28 km bike track 14016 feet height above sea level 4 main point for stay guest house availability 1st zhupu. 2nd lasht. 3rd garam chashma. 4th Last lasher Gaz. combined_text: Broghil Valley Valley A remote high-altitude valley in Upper Chitral, bordering Afghanistan's Wakhan Corridor. Located way up north very close to Afghanistans Wakhan Corridor, Broghil Valley was formerly only accessible via trek or horseback. These days, the once-hidden locale can be reached by a treacherous jeep track  yet it still only receives a handful of visitors during the few months its not frozen under heaps of snow. Currently, whether or not foreigners are allowed to visit Broghil is iffy. (If youre insistent, make sure you check with the Deputy Commissioners Office in Chitral before making the trek up there.) But Pakistanis  please go see this beauty! The valley is home to numerous high-altitude lakes, yaks, and sprawling green pastures, all set against a dramatic mountainous backdrop that soars above 13,000 feet. Moreover, a days trek from Lashkargaz, the last village in Broghil, will lead you to Karambar Lake, one of the highest in the world! The area is mostly mountainous tracts. Elevations range from 3,280m at Kishmanjah village to 4,304m at Karamber Lake in northeast. The terrain is undulating, with steep mountains, wide stretch grassy plains and narrow valleys. The total area of peatlands and lakes is almost 3,400 ha. It was a remarkable journey and a best hidden place of pakistan, with adventure road.. Must visit place Off road out standing valley Must seen untouch beauty of life

combined_text: Makli Necropolis Archaeological Site / Necropolis One of the largest funerary sites in the world, a UNESCO World Heritage Site with tombs from 400 years. Makli Necropolis is a globally significant UNESCO World Heritage Site renowned for being one of the largest funerary complexes in the world. It serves as a monumental archive of Samma and Mughal architecture, distinguished by its superb sandstone masonry. The royal tombs feature intricately carved geometric and calligraphic friezes, offering a profound and visually stunning insight into the artistic zenith of historical Sindh. This site is an essential visit for anyone interested in monumental history and sophisticated craftsmanship. A must visit place if you like History. Really a surprise for me after visiting the site, About a 500 years of historic monument/ tombs,History, Resilience and everything else you want to know is there, a very small area is preserved, a lot of area should be further preserved, my request to "Culture tourism and antiquities department GOS" is to further emphasis on rehabilitation and preservation. We traveled from Karachi to visit Makli Graveyard and made a stop near the way before heading to Kenjhar Lake. The graveyard itself is massive and really impressive. So many old, beautifully carved tombs and monuments everywhere, some dating back hundreds of years. Walking around you can really feel the history and the effort that went into all this work. It is peaceful but also kind of overwhelming because of how huge it is. Took us a few hours just to explore a part of it. The site is pretty well kept considering its age. Definitely worth a visit if you like history or want to see something different on the way.

combined_text: Ranikot Fort Historical Fort The "Great Wall of Sindh," one of the largest forts in the world with a circumference of 32 km. Ranikot Fort, often referred to as the "Great Wall of Sindh," is one of the largest forts in the world, located in the Jamshoro District of Sindh, Pakistan. Spanning nearly 30 kilometers, its massive stone walls stretch across the rugged hills of the Kirthar range, creating a breathtaking sight. Though its origins remain unclear, it is believed to have been reconstructed in the early 19th century by the Talpur dynasty. Inside the outer wall are smaller forts like Mirikot and Shergarh, offering dramatic views and ancient architecture. The fort is popular among adventurers, photographers, and history lovers for its unique structure and natural beauty. Ideal for hiking, stargazing, and exploration, Ranikot is a hidden gem in Pakistan's heritage that offers a powerful blend of mystery and landscape. Rani Kot Fort, situated in Sindh Province, Pakistan, is the largest fort in the world, covering an impressive area of 32 square kilometers. Known as the "Wall of Pakistan" or the "Wall of Sindh," this historic site offers a blend of architectural grandeur and adventure. Visitors should make proper preparations before heading to the fort, as there is no continuous electricity supply. The Sindh government operates a guest house within the main fort, managed by the Aukaf department, guest house offers rooms with attached washroom but reservations and references must be arranged in advance and need to have your own dried food as well as backup or consultation with staff. Road conditions leading to the fort require a vehicle with good ground clearance. An overnight stay at Rani Kot is highly recommended for its serene environment and breathtaking stargazing opportunities. For an optimal experience, avoid visiting on nights with a visible moon to enjoy clearer skies. Bring mosquito repellent to ensure a comfortable stay. One of the unique features of Rani Kot is the absence of mobile network coverage, offering a rare opportunity for solitude and self-reflection away from modern distractions. Travelers seeking adventure can reach the fort by heading to Sann City and taking the off-road route from there. Rani Kot Fort is a must-visit destination for history enthusiasts and adventurers, promising a memorable experience of nature, history, and tranquility. ::An ultra, realistic 8k cinematic master pece ,Ayoung proud Sindhi doy standing inside the majstic Ranikot Fort, holding an old Sindhi book in his hand as if connecting with his roots, He gazes towards the vast breathtaking beauty of Ranikot, where massive golden stone walls stretch endlessly under adright blue Neelam sky filled with soft white drifng clouds, The morning sunlight shines gently on the ancient fort,

combined_text: Hingol National Park National Park The largest national park in Pakistan, known for its dramatic landscape, mud volcanoes, and the Princess of Hope rock formation. I visited Hingol National Park one year ago, and it was an unforgettable experience. The vast landscapes, rugged mountains, and natural beauty made it a perfect escape into nature. The peaceful atmosphere and unique wildlife added to the charm of the park. Not far from there, I also explored the stunning Princess of Hope, a naturally shaped rock formation that looks like a standing woman. It's truly a wonder of nature and a must-see if youre in the area. The view from there is breathtaking, especially during sunset. Both places showcase the hidden beauty of Balochistan and are highly recommended for nature lovers and adventure seekers. One of the most beatiful places in Pakistan, Nature's extraordinary gift to pakistan. Would 100% recommend all to visit. The road / the drive / the scenic view / the securiylty, Everything is amazing. Since it was public holiday the place was quite crowded. But in normal days it wouldn't be the case. The travel experience was, however, amazing. Coastal highway is such a fun to drive on. Huts are available. Families mostly arrive in evening and stay till next day.

combined_text: Kund Malir Beach Beach A pristine beach in Hingol National Park, known for its golden sand and clear blue water. Kund Malir Beachah, what a breathtaking destination! We traveled from Karachi to Kund Malir and spent a day there, but words cant do justice to its beauty. The sunrise and sunset views are so mesmerizing that you could spend years just watching them. The crystal-clear waters, the surrounding mountains, and the golden sand that glows in the morning create a scene straight out of a dream. Its a place youd want to visit a thousand times! Kund Malir  A Peaceful Beach Witnessed Natures Power Kund Malir is a beautiful and peaceful beach located along the Makran Coastal Highway in Balochistan, Pakistan. It is part of Hingol National Park and is known for its clean shore, mountains, and calm environment. Many people visit Kund Malir to enjoy the natural beauty and silence of the sea and desert. On the night of July 5, 2025, a rare thunderstorm hit the area. Heavy rain, strong winds, and lightning covered the sky. This was a surprising event because Kund Malir is usually dry and peaceful. The storm created a powerful and unforgettable scene, as the desert and sea came alive with natures energy. This thunderstorm has now become a part of Kund Malirs historya reminder that nature can be calm and wild at the same time. Ride on a bike enhanced the experience here. So relaxed atmosphere.

combined_text: Hanna Lake Lake A picturesque lake near Quetta, surrounded by hills and a popular spot for boating. Hana Lake is a beautiful and peaceful getaway, perfect for anyone looking to relax and enjoy nature. The scenery is calming, and it's a great spot to unwind. However, the authorities could invest more in its developmentbetter facilities, cleanliness, and infrastructure upgrades could really enhance the overall experience and help make this one of the top tourist attractions in the region. Hanna Lake is an incredibly beautiful place  truly a hidden gem in Balochistan. This is my first time witnessing such natural beauty in the region, and Im genuinely amazed. The serene blue water, surrounding mountains, and peaceful atmosphere make it a perfect spot for nature lovers and families alike. I absolutely loved this place and would highly recommend visiting it. A must-see destination if you're in or near Quetta! Hanna Lake is a scenic reservoir located near Quetta, Balochistan, Pakistan. It was constructed during British rule in 1894 as a water storage facility to supply Quetta with drinking water. The lake is formed by the Hanna Dam, which was built on the Urak Valley stream. Over time, it has become a popular tourist destination, known for its turquoise waters, surrounding mountains, and picnic spots.

combined_text: Lok Virsa Museum Museum A museum in Islamabad dedicated to the living traditions and cultural heritage of Pakistan. The Lok Virsa Museum in Islamabad is a wonderful place to learn about Pakistans rich culture and traditions. Located at Shakarparian Hills, the museum has many galleries that show our local crafts, colorful clothes, musical instruments, pottery, woodwork, and jewelry from all parts of the country. The section about Sufi saints is very special, with beautiful art and poetry that touches the heart. I really liked the life-sized displays of village homes and workshopsit felt like stepping into history. The museum is very family-friendly. There is plenty of parking space, and you can easily spend a few hours here with kids. There are food stalls nearby, lots of trees for shade, and benches where you can sit and relax. Sometimes there are cultural shows and festivals that make the visit even more fun. I didnt take photos inside because I wanted to respect the place and its rules. A great place for families, students, and anyone who loves our culture! We had a great experience visiting the Lok Visa Heritage Museum. The exhibits were fascinating and well-curated. However, the air conditioning inside the museum could be improved for better comfort. Additionally, the food available outside the museum could be of better quality, especially considering the relatively high prices. Enhancing both comfort and value would make the overall experience even better. It is a good place to visit especially on festive days. It has a huge museum and statues and artifacts showcasing Pakistan's rich culture and history. The museum sadly has no AC, so it's very hot. The place has bookshops and other merchants and artists as well. Overall a nice place. I feel that adding Pakistani scientists statues is important.

combined_text: Shah Allah Ditta Caves Archaeological Site Ancient caves on the outskirts of Islamabad, believed to be from the Buddhist era. A best place for an outing. The restaurants are nice. The horse stable and swimming pools are also good. Wild monkeys can be seen on trees, but one has to be careful as they come too close and seem to be aggressive. The caves have their own charm and nearby restaurants up the hill showcase the panoramic view of the city. Will love to visit this place again. A beautiful place with a historic and scenic views of mountains, caves, trees, wells etc. Teavelling through dera dari restaurant is scenic but road is not smooth, travelling through Shah Allah Ditta village main road is short and better. After main village, road is not fully carpeted but reasonably good to travel. 3km after caves, is a place, kanthla village, the road is under construction, but the views are beautiful and a good reataurant and a dera type place is there to stay for a few hours and take rest. Great historical site with added perks like swimming pool and horse riding! However, the excessive construction around the area is hindering its beauty. Would love to see more focus on preservation.

combined_text: Gadani Beach Beach A beach on the Arabian Sea near the Hub River and Cape Monze in Gadani, Balochistan. Known for its ship-breaking yard and beach picnics. It's a good spot if you're finding peace. Highly recommend in holidays. Otherwise, there are no people and you can enjoy the calmness of sea. However, there are no restaurants and cafes. So pack up your bags wisely. The beach is a hidden gem, with crystal clear water and surprisingly no plastic litter. We arrive early, just after sunrise, and appreciate the cleanliness and lack of entry or parking fees. There are no huts for rent, but the locals are helpful. Gadani Beah is a good place for an outing with family and friends. The view is beautiful, and the atmosphere is peaceful. However, there are no food stalls or facilities nearby, so it is important to bring your own food, water, and mats for sitting. If you come prepared, you will have a wonderful and relaxing time by the sea. must visit!

combined_text: Clifton Beach (Sea-View Beach), Karachi Beach A very popular Karachi beach known for camel & horse rides, evening strolls, food stalls, and sea views. I visited Sea View Beach in Karachi. The salty breeze hit my face as I walked barefoot on the wet sand. The horizon was painted in orange and pink, and the waves gently lapped at my feet. Families were flying kites, kids were laughing, and a few camels strolled along the shore offering rides. I was enjoying watching the city slowly turn golden in the evening light. It was peaceful, despite the noise and the crowd, there was something calming about the rhythmic sound of the waves. I had a fun and enjoyable time at Seaview Beach in Karachi! It's a great place to relax and spend time with family or friends. There are many fun activities available, like horse rides, camel rides, and more. The atmosphere is lively, especially in the evening, and the ocean view is beautiful. I really enjoyed my visit and would definitely recommend it to others looking for a fun beach experience in the city. The sea breeze feels amazing, and its a great spot for a casual walk, photography, or simply sitting and enjoying nature. There are food stalls and snacks available nearby, but its best to carry water and keep the beach clean. I wish the authorities paid more attention to cleanliness and proper waste management, but overall, its a beautiful and relaxing spot to spend time with friends and family.

combined_text: Keenjhar Lake (Karli Lake) Lake A large lake in Thatta District, Sindh. Ramsar site, habitat for migratory birds. Today, on 16th September 2025, I had the chance to visit the breathtaking Keenjhar Lake, and it turned out to be a truly memorable experience. The lake, stretching far and wide with its calm blue waters, looked incredibly refreshing under the clear sky. After the recent rains, the surrounding landscape was lush green, adding a cinematic touch to the whole scene. The cool breeze over the water and the reflection of drifting clouds created a peaceful and soothing atmosphere, making it a perfect escape from the hustle of daily life. Keenjhar Lake, also known as Kalri Lake, is one of Sindhs most enchanting natural treasures and a perfect escape for those seeking peace and beauty away from city life. Located near Thatta, the lake is the largest freshwater reservoir in Pakistan and holds immense cultural, historical, and ecological importance. When visiting, one is immediately struck by the vast stretch of calm blue waters blending seamlessly with the horizon. The recent rains have added a fresh charm to the scenery, with lush greenery sprouting around the lakes banks, creating a soothing and cinematic atmosphere. The reflection of clouds over the water, combined with the gentle waves, makes it an ideal place for relaxation and photography.  Keenjhar Lake (also known as Kalri Lake) is a magnificent destination, serving as Pakistan's second-largest freshwater body and a vital Ramsar Site for migratory birds. Its sheer scale and tranquil, blue waters offer a perfect retreat for picnics, boating, and swimming. What makes this site truly unique is the small tomb island at its center, which is the resting place of Noori, the heroine of the legendary Sindhi folklore, Noori Jam Tamachi. The lake thus provides a rare blend of stunning natural beauty and deep cultural heritage, making it a must-visit spot for both nature enthusiasts and those seeking a connection to the romantic history of Sindh. Keenjhar Lake, also known as Kalri Lake, is a breathtaking freshwater lake located near Thatta, approximately 130 kilometers from Karachi. As one of the largest lakes in Pakistan, it serves not only as a vital water reservoir for Karachi and surrounding areas but also as a premier tourist destination in Sindh. Whether you're a nature lover, a history enthusiast, or just someone looking for a peaceful getaway, Keenjhar offers an experience unlike any other. The serene blue waters stretching across the horizon create a picturesque setting ideal for relaxation and reflection. Visitors can enjoy boating, swimming, and jet skiing while soaking in the lake's natural beauty. There are shaded huts and sitting areas along the banks for families and groups, and the sunrise and sunset views here are truly mesmerizing. The lake holds spiritual and historical significance too. A shrine dedicated to Noori, the beloved character from the famous folklore "Noori Jam Tamachi", stands on an island in the middle of the lake and is visited by many devotees every year. The ambiance around the shrine adds a mystical charm to the overall experience. Food stalls and restaurants near the lake serve fresh fish and local delicacies, enhancing the days outing with traditional flavors. While weekends can get a bit crowded, weekdays are quieter and more peaceful for those seeking solitude. Basic facilities such as washrooms, seating, and parking are available, though they could be better maintained. Its recommended to bring essential items, especially if you plan to stay longer. Overall, Keenjhar Lake is a must-visit destination for those seeking nature, culture, and a break from urban life. Its tranquil environment and scenic beauty make it a perfect spot for day trips, photography, and picnics.

combined_text: Margalla Hills National Park National Park A national park near Islamabad; includes trails, picnic spots, viewpoints like Daman-e-Koh & Pir Sohawa. Margilla hills national park is one of the more well maintained national parks of Pakistan. It is also probably the most easily accessible one, too. Flaura and fauna of the park are so breathtaking. Wildfires do occur though, almost every year. The park is as safe as it gets, for a national park, since it is close to the city, data signals do appear from time to time, it is easy to call for help, animal encounters are also common but not dangerous. The park offers about 7 different trails. All of which are worth trekking through. Trail 5 is the most well maintained with proper markings throughout the trail. I also recommend trail 3 and new one, trail 7. Before travelling, you may need to confirm if they are open or not, as a local I know that trail 6 has been close for quite some time now to protect wildlife whereas trail 5 was also closed for a week in August 2025. There are different rock climbing spots across the parks, most famous of which is Beetle's nest located behind Saidpur Village. Then, there's different camping spots in the parks, most common of which is trail 5 camping spot. Furthermore, there are some historical spots in the Margilla hills as well, such as Shah Allah Dita caves. Overall, The whole park cannot really be visited in just a day. My recommendation is to stay at least a week in nearby Islamabad and explore it. To be fair, I have been living in Islamabad for 10+ years and I have not really been able to explore all of it so It is justifiable. There are many other spots that I have visited in the park, which are not really mapped on Google Maps, such as the plane crash site in margilla hills Really enjoyed Margalla Hills National Park, the environment, the trail, the water flowing down, the view from top, the species there and many more were fantastic and beyond my expectations. If you wanna go hiking and want some adventure, Margalla Hills is one of the best choices you can make. The Margalla Hills, located in Islamabad, Pakistan, are a stunning range of hills known for their breathtaking natural beauty and diverse wildlife. The area is home to wide, well-paved roads that wind gracefully through lush green mountains and dense clusters of tall, majestic trees. These scenic routes offer a peaceful and refreshing escape from the hustle and bustle of city life.

combined_text: Chaukhandi Tombs Necropolis / Historic Site A historic Islamic necropolis near Karachi, famous for its sandstone carvings and unique style of tomb architecture. The Chaukhandi Tombs are an ancient Islamic cemetery located about 29 km east of Karachi, near the National Highway. These tombs date back to the 15th to 18th centuries and are primarily associated with the Jokhio tribe, as well as Baloch chieftains. The site is renowned for its sandstone architecture and intricately carved graves, which showcase a unique blend of Islamic, Rajput, and Mughal artistic influences. The tombs are built in a step-pyramid style, often in family enclosures, and feature detailed engravings of weapons, horses, jewelry, floral patterns, and geometric motifs  each symbol reflecting the status, profession, or achievements of the deceased. Although the graves follow Islamic burial customs, the artistry reflects a cross-cultural heritage, making the site both architecturally and historically significant. Recognized for its cultural value, the Chaukhandi Tombs have been placed on the UNESCO Tentative List, though the site remains under threat from weathering and neglect. This site stands as a silent yet powerful reminder of Sindhs layered history and craftsmanship, echoing the stories of warriors, tribes, and the artistic soul of an era long gone. Nice place to visit if you like history. Interesting graves and carvings. No entrance fee but recommended to take the local guide with you that will explain more about the different graves. The Chaukhandi Tombs near Karachi are a stunning example of ancient Islamic architecture, featuring intricate stone carvings and unique funerary structures from the 15th to 18th centuries. Their historical and artistic significance make them a must-see for history enthusiasts and architecture lovers.

combined_text: Hussaini Suspension Bridge Suspension Bridge / Scenic Landmark A famous rickety suspension bridge over the Hunza River in Upper Hunza, known for its dramatic views and risk factor. A Thrilling Experience at Hussaini Suspension Bridge! Id seen the Hussaini Suspension Bridge countless times on YouTube, but nothing compares to seeing it in personits absolutely awesome. That first moment stepping onto the bridge was unforgettable. If youve got a fear of heights, this is definitely not the place for you. Crossing the bridge was both frightening and thrilling. It feels like the whole thing is moving, but its actually the water rushing beneath that messes with your senses. Just focus on the wooden planks and not the water. It took us around 30 to 40 minutes to get across one sideevery step required real nerves of steel. They do give you life jackets before crossing, which might sound reassuring at first. But we were bluntly told they wouldnt save usthe shock of falling into that freezing glacial water would likely be fatal. That definitely added to the intensity of the whole experience. Getting to the bridge isnt exactly easy either. Its a steep uphill climb with a lot of steps, so you need to be in decent shape. But once you're up there, the views are stunning and the adventure is totally worth it. And to top it all offwe zip-wired back across! It was the perfect adrenaline rush to end the journey. If youre ever in the area and looking for something unforgettable, this is one place you must experience. Hussaini Suspension Bridge in Hunza Valley is a unique and adventurous experience. Located over the Indus River in Hussaini Village, the journey starts by passing through the village itself, giving you a close look at local culture, lifestyle, and livelihood. Entry ticket is just Rs. 100, but its important to note that kids are not allowed to go far on the bridge due to safety concernsits genuinely dangerous and not for the faint-hearted. Theres also a zip line available at the site. However, during our visit, we saw someone get stuck midway while returning, which was enough for us to decide against trying it. One key thing to keep in mind is the extremely steep path on the way back. If you have difficulty walking on such inclines, its better to skip the hike. Carrying a water bottle is strongly recommended. The locals are incredibly friendly and welcoming. Most of the shops around the area are run by women, and their prices are surprisingly economical. I would sincerely encourage everyone to support them by purchasing somethingyou wont find such rates anywhere else. All in all, it was a wonderful and memorable experience. A must-try for anyone visiting Hunza Valley. One of the most beautiful suspension bridges I have ever been to. It's an adventurous place when you walk through the bridge you can get motion sickness you will feel like bridge is going away with water

The place was clean and the staff was friendly. The only downside was a slight delay in serving, so I give it 4 stars. Overall, worth the visit! combined_text: Khaplu Palace Historical Palace / Museum An old fort and palace located in Khaplu, Gilgit-Baltistan; restored heritage site now housing museum and guest accommodations. Khaplu Palace is a 19th-century royal residence and fort that served as the home of the Yabgo dynasty, the rulers of the Khaplu region. Unlike the more militaristic Skardu Fort, Khaplu Palace was designed as a fortified residential palace, blending elegance with defense. It is often called the "Taj Mahal of the Karakoram" due to its beautiful and serene setting. The palace has ancient vibes. It was quiet and peaceful. The staff was friendly and welcoming. We stayed there for two days and created good memories. In the night time I heard someone jumping on the top of my room. The noises kept coming all night long. May be there were kids staying in the hotel. Other than that it was beautiful all in all. As one would expect from the hotel group...very sympathetic conversion of the Royal Palace Reception area. Great bedrooms, modern shower rooms. Good food in the evening. Breakfast a touch indifferent. Place has bags of charm and is in a wonderful part of the world

combined_text: Banjosa Lake Lake A man-made lake and tourist resort near Rawalakot in Poonch District, Azad Kashmir; surrounded by pine forest and cold climate. Such a beautiful, attractive, serene, peaceful and full of calmness place! Lake itself isn't clean because it is not natural. However, I found this place magical. They have placed benches around the lake which seems dreamy and magical. We weren't really sure about this place but when we reached there. We were happy that we are not going to regret our decision. I visited in the first week of May, it was raining and weather was a bit cold. There are some guests houses for night stay but I couldn't get a chance to collect information about it. Apart from that, there are shops for tea, coffee, ice cream and burger. You can paddle boat there also. Highly recommended for families! Bajosa lake , an artificial lake,situated in district poonch Ajk. The lake's true charm lies not in its waters, but in the captivating surroundings, landscapes and delightful weather that transform the area into something special. The area is enjoyable year-round, with lush greenery and blooming trees making visits equally pleasant in summer, winter, and spring.  Banjosa Lake  Rawalakot, Azad Kashmir | Local Guide Review By: Muzammal Hussain  Google Local Guide  Banjosa Lake is a hidden gem nestled in the serene hills of Rawalakot, Azad Kashmir. Surrounded by tall pine trees and wrapped in a blanket of peace, this artificial yet stunning lake feels straight out of a fairytale. As a Google Local Guide, I highly recommend this destination for families, couples, and nature enthusiasts looking to escape the city and reconnect with nature.  What to Expect: Calm, glassy lake perfect for photography Boating (seasonal) and lakeside strolls Cold, fresh mountain air  even in summer Charming wooden cottages nearby  Local Guide Tips: Ideal visit time: May to September Try visiting early morning or sunset for magical light Dress warm  even summer evenings can be chilly Respect nature  no littering, please  Combine your trip with Rawalakot city and nearby sites like Toli Pir for a fuller experience. Banjosa isnt just a place, its a pause button for your soul. #BanjosaLake #Rawalakot #GoogleLocalGuide #KashmirDiaries #NatureInPakistan #ExploreKashmir #Google

combined_text: Chitta Katha Lake Lake A glacial lake in Shounter Valley, Azad Jammu & Kashmir; very high altitude; reached by challenging trek; very scenic and relatively less visited. A 9-hour trek that pushed us to our limits.. Steep, exhausting, and tough. But the moment we saw the lake, surrounded by majestic mountains, everything was worth it. Absolutely breathtaking. All the pain vanished. Nature at its purest. One the best trek Ive ever seen. This lake is existing in AJK Neelum Shounter Valley. Once you reaches Kel then from there u have to travel on 4*4, and it take almost 3 to 4 hours to reach Domel. From there you have to trek of almost 5 consecutive hrs to reach on top of lake. This is one the hardest trek and if you luv hiking you definitely going to luv forever. View is so fabulous of the trek. On the way u would finds streams, 2 Base Camp on the way. U can stay there and they provide you the meal as well but not free. Essentials: Carry hiking stick. Carry only the imp things on the trek. U must apply sun screen before trekking bcz at height ur skin could be damage from direct sunlight. Wear joggers. Chitta Katha Lake is an absolutely breathtaking destination in Azad Kashmir!  The crystal-clear turquoise water, surrounded by towering snow-capped peaks, makes it a paradise for nature lovers and adventure seekers. The trek is challenging but incredibly rewarding, offering stunning views along the way.  Pros:  Spectacular scenery with pristine alpine beauty  Perfect for trekking and photography  Peaceful and less crowded  Cons:  The trek is physically demanding and not for beginners  Limited facilities  bring your own food and camping gear  Weather can change suddenly, so plan accordingly If you're up for an adventure and love exploring untouched natural wonders, this place is a must-visit!

Phander Valley is one of the most beautiful valley in Pakistan..It offers spectacular scenic view.. It is very lush green and very pleasant place. A twisting road passes through lush green fields and forests with a view of flowing river and icy peaks lead to this charming valley. From springs of crystal clear waters to lakes and rivers of deep blue water, there are all colors of natures beauty in Phandar Valley. Peaceful deep blue waters of River Ghizer and surrounding lush green and golden fields are breathtaking. There is a lake at the eastern end of the valley named Phander Lake. Phander Lake is one of the most famous tourist spots in the entire region. . The Phandar Lake gives masmerizing views. The deep blue of Phander lake offers a magnificent view. Phandar Valley, a hidden gem in Pakistan's Gilgit-Baltistan region, is renowned for its breathtaking landscapes and tranquil ambiance. Nestled amidst lush green fields and framed by snow-capped peaks, this valley is home to the serene Phandar Lake, where the water shifts in mesmerizing shades of blue and green. Known as "Little Kashmir," Phandar offers a perfect retreat for nature lovers, with opportunities for fishing, hiking, and peaceful boat rides. This picturesque valley has a rich cultural heritage and remains a peaceful escape for travelers seeking unspoiled natural beauty, making it a must-visit destination in northern Pakistan.

combined_text: Khalti Lake Lake A cold lake in Khalti Village, Gupis-Yasin; flows from glaciers, freezes in winter; known for trout. Khalti Lake is situated in Tehsil Gupis of Ghizer District, the westernmost part of the Gilgit Baltistan, and northernmost territory of Pakistan.This lake is an important source of fresh water and has a stock of trout.The water is extremely cold which flows directly from surrounding glaciers. The lake usually freezes in winter season and people can easily walk on it. One of the most beautiful lakes in Ghizer district of Gilgit baltistan. Must visit in November This lake is formed on Ghizer river by mountain sliding. It is surrounded by Mountains.It located in few kilometers beyond Gopis a sub division of Ghizer division Gilgit-Baltistan. Its altitude is above 7000 feets. Beautiful lake with filled with clean chill water. It frozen in winter. It's has very beautiful natural views.

combined_text: Sheosar Lake Lake In the Deosai Plains, Gilgit-Baltistan; remote, very high altitude, unique plateau scenery. Beautiful place large meadows on high altitude, Deosai National Park. Breathtaking landscape after a 4 hour adventurous drive from Skardu! Most of the tourists visit deosai till chota pani only, some visit the next point Bara Pani, some go further to Kaala Pani, but most of the tourists miss the best point that comes after Kala pani, i-e the beautiful Sheosar lake. My advise to those visiting Deosai, bargain with the car rentals in clear way that you want to gi till Sheosar Lake, they will tell you the charges accordingly (july 2025 Prado Tx till Sheosar with fuel charges are 20k-25k). Leave early morning maximum till 8am no further than that. Reach deosai and do not stop at any point unless any emergency like using the restrooms that you will find at all camps. Reach Bara Pani that takes around hours from Skardu, its the best and only point to have lunch as other camps do not offer lunch, just fries and pakoras and tea. Leave Bara pani after lunch and reach Sheosar lake that will take further 1 and half hour from Bara pani. Stay at Sheosar lake for an hour and then leave back. On the way back you can stop for a moment at Kala pani and then stop again at Chota pani to enjoy evening tea with awesome pakoras and fries with awesome views. Reach back Skardu till 7 or 7:30 pm. A natural marvel. Coming from chillam choki into Deosai National Park. When you finally take the turn towards the lake; the first look, you get awestruck. The magnificence of the lake involuntarily makes you say SubhanAllah.

combined_text: Soon Valley Valley A scenic valley in Punjab, known for waterfalls, lakes, greenery; less crowded than more famous valleys. Soon Valley, located in Khushab, Punjab, is a peaceful and scenic destination known for its lakes, hills, and ancient temples. Famous spots include Uchhali Lake, Khabikki Lake, and Sakesar Peak.
