combined_text: Mushroom Lake (Swat) Lake A small alpine lake in Gabral Valley of Kalam, Swat; known for its mushroom-shaped structure; ~10-hour hike from Shahi Bagh Kalam. Adventure with Dr-Azeem It will take 10 hours from Shahi Bagh to reach Mushroom Lake. We offer services to Lakes adventures as well. A must visited place for adventure lovers. It was one of the toughest and tremendous adventures. Mahroom Lake Expedition: We start our journey from Kalam swat. Reaching Gubral, we move by foot towards the Shahai Bagh. On the way taking left we reach Shahai Bagh at evening. Staying overnight, we move towards the lake at around 6am in the morning. Moving continuously by foot around 13 hours we reach the middle base of the lake. Staying overnight and moving in next morning around two hours we reach the Mashrrom Lake. It was very huge lake. It has very unique landscape. It is located over the top of mountain with small mountain peaks around it. Second, there are small lakes over the top of mountain in this region however this lake is huge . Its shape is like an eagle. P.S: Climbing up to the lake is a bit risky. I would strongly recommend that you should carry professional hiking material like good boots and roof. It will help you u a lot. A hidden gem with crystal-clear waters and serene surroundings. Ideal for nature lovers and trekkers seeking peace, beauty, and breathtaking mountain views.

combined_text: Dudipatsar Lake Lake Alpine lake in Lulusar-Dudipatsar National Park in Kaghan Valley; encircled by snow-clad peaks; very scenic. Dudipatsar Lake, often referred to as the "Queen of Lakes," is a stunning alpine glacial lake nestled in the Lulusar-Dudipatsar National Park at the northern end of Kaghan Valley, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan. Situated at an elevation of approximately 3,800 meters (12,500 feet), the lake is encircled by snow-clad peaks averaging around 4,800 meters (15,700 feet) in elevation . It's still less explored & very less frequently visited lake located in Mansehra District, KP. It's scenic beauty, crystal clear greenish blue frigid water, abundant with Rainbow Trout, surrounded by lofty snow clad mountains and almost pin drop silence makes everyone crazy. One cannot absorb its beauty with naked eye. However, you have to be careful because security situation is not fine due to it proximity to Kohistan, which inhabits some criminals. Dudipatsar Lake is a beautiful lake located in the Kaghan Valley of Pakistan. The starting point is from Moon Restaurant, Besal a.k.a Besar. It is an 18 KM long hiking track which can be covered in 5-7 Hours. Daudipatsar Lake is surrounded by snow-capped and green mountains. The lake is a popular destination for hiking, camping, and fishing. The water in the lake is crystal clear and the views are breathtaking.

combined_text: Shounter Lake Lake A scenic lake in Shounter Valley in Neelum Valley, Azad Kashmir; fed by glaciers; lush surroundings. **Shounter Valley**, located in the Neelum District of Azad Jammu and Kashmir, Pakistan, is a picturesque and remote valley known for its rugged mountainous terrain and pristine natural beauty. The valley is surrounded by towering peaks, including those of the **Shounter Mountain** range, which form part of the greater Himalayas. Historically, the valley has been used as a key passage for shepherds and traders traveling between Neelum Valley and the Astore Valley in Gilgit-Baltistan via the Shounter Pass, which sits at an altitude of 4,420 meters (14,500 feet). The area is also home to the famous Shounter Lake, a glacial lake that adds to the valleys scenic charm. Despite its remote location, Shounter Valley attracts trekkers and adventurers looking to explore its untouched landscapes. The valleys harsh winters and rugged terrain make it a challenging destination, but its natural beauty and historical significance as a crossroads of ancient routes continue to draw visitors. combined_text: Rainbow Lake (Minimarg / Domel, Astore) Lake A lake with vibrant colours, reflections; located in Minimarg area of Astore; access restricted (military-controlled area). Raw nature at its best. Breathtaking panoramic views all around. Best place to visit in Pakistan. Good facilities for dining and recreation. Plenty of parking. Only 4x4 vehicles allowed. Bikes over 150cc allowed. Overnight stay allowed for those who have booking in guest rooms or tent village only. Best time to visit is from April to September. Journey to the place is relatively tough but worth every second. Visiting Rainbow Lake near Minimarg was quite an adventure, its a bit of a mission to get there! The place itself is absolutely beautiful and would be perfect for a family outing, but the journey might be challenging for some. The road via Astore, Chillum, and Minimarg is mostly off-road and can be tough to navigate. That said, the stunning views and breathtaking scenery along the way make it worthwhile, though perhaps better suited for more adventurous travelers. There's also the historic Musharraf Hut nearby, named after General Musharraf, who reportedly stayed there during the Kargil conflict between the two neighboring countries. A beautiful lake nestled in probably the most beautiful valley in Pakistan, Minimarg. They allow tourists for a day visit in this beautiful valley now but you need a 4x4 vehicle or a motorcycle with minimum 150cc engine. Keep your NIC with you and dont travel with drones, camping equipment.

This valley is quite cheap and economical as compared to hunza with respect room prices and food etc. Chapursan (Wakhi: ; also spelt Chipurson, Chipurson, Chaporsan, Chupurson) is a valley containing some eight scattered villages within the Hunza District of Gilgit-Baltistan, Pakistan. It is the most Northern part of Pakistan, bordering Afghanistan and China. Majority of the people in the valley speak the Wakhi Language, but the villagers of Raminj town speak Burushaski language and belong to the Ismaili sect of Islam.[citation needed] Chipurson Valley hosts over 500 households with 3000 population.

combined_text: Naqpo Rzingbo Lake A high-altitude lake in Baltistan; remote, rarely visited; glacial fed water, pristine surroundings. Amazing viewpoint of Rakaposhi mountain with its impressive snow cladded peak and glacier slowly moving down the mountain. Good place to have break and some food. A Majestic Mountain Experience Rakaposhi Viewpoint offers one of the most breathtaking views in the world. Standing tall at over 7,700 meters, Rakaposhis snow-capped peak looks absolutely stunning against the clear blue sky. The fresh mountain air and peaceful surroundings make it a perfect spot to relax and connect with nature. Whether you are a traveler, nature lover, or photographer, Rakaposhi Viewpoint is a must-visit destination that leaves you speechless with its beauty. Dont miss the chance to witness this natural masterpiece! Rakaposhi is a peak in the Karakoram Range in the Gilgit-Baltistan territory of Pakistan. It is listed 27th highest peak in the world and 12th highest peak in Pakistan. It is a point on Karakoram highway named as Rakaposhi Viewpoint, famous as one of the most visited tourist attraction of Hunza Valley. In the regional dialect, Rakaposhi implies shiny wall. Location:It is located in the midst of the Nagar and Bagrote valleys, roughly 100 km in the North of the Gilgit (semi-autonomous Gilgit-Baltistan region of Pakistan). Altitude: 7,788 meters Mountain range: Karakoram

combined_text: Lower Kachura Lake (Shangrila Lake) Lake Known also as Shangrila Lake; a beautiful lake with resort; very photographed, but parts still less crowded. Never Miss it in Skardu. Lower Kachura Lake, famously known as Shangrila Lake, is one of the most enchanting destinations in Skardu, Pakistan. Surrounded by rugged mountains and lush greenery, this heart-shaped lake feels like a piece of paradise tucked away in the Himalayas. The moment you arrive, the cool, crisp air and the breathtaking views immediately captivate your senses. The lake itself is incredibly clear, reflecting the dramatic peaks and colorful resort buildings that line its shores. Shangrila Resort, which sits right by the lake, enhances the charm with its unique architecture, including the famous restaurant built inside an old airplane. The vibrant flowers, well-maintained gardens, and winding pathways create a peaceful atmosphere thats perfect for a relaxing stroll or quiet reflection. Boating on the lake is a must-do experience. Gliding over the calm waters, surrounded by towering mountains and the whisper of the wind, feels almost surreal. Photographers and nature lovers will find endless opportunities to capture the beauty of this magical place, especially during sunrise and sunset when the light paints the landscape in golden hues. What makes Lower Kachura Lake even more special is its accessibility. Its just a short drive from Skardu city, making it ideal for both quick visits and longer stays. The resort offers comfortable accommodation and delicious local food, allowing visitors to fully immerse themselves in the serene environment. Whether youre seeking adventure, romance, or simply a break from the chaos of everyday life, Lower Kachura Lake offers a perfect escape. Its blend of natural beauty, rich culture, and warm hospitality leaves a lasting impression, making it a destination youll want to return to again and again. Truly, Lower Kachura Lake is a gem that lives up to its legendary reputation. Lower Kachura Lake, nestled in the majestic landscape of Skardu, Gilgit-Baltistan, Pakistan, is a serene and picturesque destination that offers breathtaking scenery and a tranquil atmosphere. Surrounded by towering mountains and lush greenery, the lake's calm waters reflect the stunning beauty of its surroundings, creating a sense of peace and tranquility. Visitors can enjoy a range of activities, including boating and fishing, while taking in the breathtaking views of the surrounding mountains. The lake's picturesque setting makes it an ideal spot for photography, relaxation, and unwinding amidst nature's splendor. With its stunning scenery and peaceful atmosphere, Lower Kachura Lake is a must-visit destination for nature lovers, photographers, and those seeking a tranquil retreat from the hustle and bustle of city life. The lake's proximity to Skardu city makes it easily accessible, and visitors can choose from a range of accommodation options to suit their needs and budget. One of the highlights of visiting Lower Kachura Lake is the opportunity to stay at the Shangri-La Resort, which offers comfortable rooms and stunning views of the lake and surrounding mountains. The resort's picturesque setting and excellent hospitality make it an ideal choice for visitors looking to unwind and relax in a beautiful setting. The resort also offers a range of amenities and services, including dining and recreational activities, to enhance the overall visitor experience. When planning your visit to Lower Kachura Lake, it's essential to consider the best time to visit, which is typically during the summer months when the weather is pleasant and the roads are accessible. However, the road to the lake can be challenging, so it's recommended to hire a 4x4 vehicle or take a guided tour to ensure a safe and enjoyable journey. Overall, Lower Kachura Lake is a breathtakingly beautiful destination that offers a unique and unforgettable experience. With its stunning scenery, peaceful atmosphere, and range of activities, it is a must-visit destination for anyone traveling to Skardu. Whether you're looking to relax, take in the views, or enjoy water activities, Lower Kachura Lake is a true gem of Pakistan's tourism industry that is sure to leave a lasting impression. A beautiful private resort on a beautiful, heart shaped lower kachura lake skardu. A must visit place once in a life.

combined_text: Kund Malir Beach Beach A remote, pristine beach along Makran Coast; golden sands, clear waters, scenic drive through Hingol National Park. Kund Malir Beachah, what a breathtaking destination! We traveled from Karachi to Kund Malir and spent a day there, but words cant do justice to its beauty. The sunrise and sunset views are so mesmerizing that you could spend years just watching them. The crystal-clear waters, the surrounding mountains, and the golden sand that glows in the morning create a scene straight out of a dream. Its a place youd want to visit a thousand times! Kund Malir  A Peaceful Beach Witnessed Natures Power Kund Malir is a beautiful and peaceful beach located along the Makran Coastal Highway in Balochistan, Pakistan. It is part of Hingol National Park and is known for its clean shore, mountains, and calm environment. Many people visit Kund Malir to enjoy the natural beauty and silence of the sea and desert. On the night of July 5, 2025, a rare thunderstorm hit the area. Heavy rain, strong winds, and lightning covered the sky. This was a surprising event because Kund Malir is usually dry and peaceful. The storm created a powerful and unforgettable scene, as the desert and sea came alive with natures energy. This thunderstorm has now become a part of Kund Malirs historya reminder that nature can be calm and wild at the same time. Ride on a bike enhanced the experience here. So relaxed atmosphere.

combined_text: Shandur Pass Mountain Pass / Plateau A high-altitude plateau between Chitral and Gilgit; famous for polo festival; lush meadows in summer, isolated during off-season. Shandur Pass is a breathtaking high-mountain pass located between Gilgit-Baltistan and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, at an altitude of around 12,000 feet. It is famous for hosting the annual Shandur Polo Festival, the highest polo ground in the world. Surrounded by snow-capped peaks and lush green meadows, the pass offers a unique mix of adventure, culture, and natural beauty. Summer is the best time to visit, as the roads are often blocked in winter due to snow. Visitors can enjoy camping, photography, and experience traditional mountain culture in a serene environment. A must-visit spot for nature and adventure lovers. combined_text: Tirich Mir Mountain Peak Highest peak of the Hindu Kush; remote, huge mountain; base camps for serious mountaineers. Mt.Terich Mir 7,708 m (25,289 ft).Terich Mir is the highest mountain of the Hindu Kush range, and the highest mountain in the world outside of the Himalayas-Karakoram range, located in Chitral Khyber Pukhtunkhwa Pakistan. Its the Highest peak out of Karakorum and Himalayas, its the highest peak of Hindu kush mountain ranges of Pakistan, standing close to Afghan border, tirch mir is a wakhi word means king of shadows, because around evening it spread shadow over upper chitral which is wakhi speaking area, and is also famous for its fairy tail stories, and common in khowar poetry, For travelers, Tirich Mir offers breathtaking views, especially from the town of Chitral. Visitors can enjoy the sight of this majestic peak from various vantage points, including the main bazaar of Chitral. The journey to the Tirich Valley, which lies in upper Chitral, takes approximately 6 to 7 hours by jeep from the main town. The region surrounding Tirich Mir is rich in cultural heritage and natural beauty. The mountain is visible from many parts of the Chitral region, making it a central feature of the landscape. Tirich Mir, standing at 7,708 meters, is the highest peak in the Hindu Kush mountain range, located in Chitral, Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan. It holds the distinction of being the highest mountain outside the HimalayasKarakoram range.

combined_text: Tirich Mir Mountain Peak The highest peak of the Hindu Kush, dramatic mountaineering destination. Mt.Terich Mir 7,708 m (25,289 ft).Terich Mir is the highest mountain of the Hindu Kush range, and the highest mountain in the world outside of the Himalayas-Karakoram range, located in Chitral Khyber Pukhtunkhwa Pakistan. Its the Highest peak out of Karakorum and Himalayas, its the highest peak of Hindu kush mountain ranges of Pakistan, standing close to Afghan border, tirch mir is a wakhi word means king of shadows, because around evening it spread shadow over upper chitral which is wakhi speaking area, and is also famous for its fairy tail stories, and common in khowar poetry, For travelers, Tirich Mir offers breathtaking views, especially from the town of Chitral. Visitors can enjoy the sight of this majestic peak from various vantage points, including the main bazaar of Chitral. The journey to the Tirich Valley, which lies in upper Chitral, takes approximately 6 to 7 hours by jeep from the main town. The region surrounding Tirich Mir is rich in cultural heritage and natural beauty. The mountain is visible from many parts of the Chitral region, making it a central feature of the landscape. Tirich Mir, standing at 7,708 meters, is the highest peak in the Hindu Kush mountain range, located in Chitral, Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan. It holds the distinction of being the highest mountain outside the HimalayasKarakoram range.

combined_text: Lower Kachura Lake (Shangrila / Shangrila Resort) Lake Scenic lake at Shangrila resort (Skardu area) with hotel/resort. We didnt stay in the hotel but visited the gardens and restaurant. You have to purchase a ticket to enter. The gardens and lake are absolutely beautiful. It is so well maintained and calm. We enjoyed sitting by the water and relaxing and exploring the garden. The restaurant food was not too good but you can eat looking out at the beautiful views of the water, mountains and water. Would recommend visiting the resort if you are passing through the area. Great location with lovely views. Hotel was one of the first upmarket hotels built 12 or 13 years ago. It's looking a little tired now. The external grounds are great. Nice restaurant menu. Quiet. Nice crowd of clientele. This resort is an icon, I took s trip to Skardu and asked my travel advisor to make sure he booked my stay at this resort. The setting of the cabins around the Shangri-la lake puts out a perfect vibe. Rooms are spacious and comfortable. Staff is courteous and friendly, I enjoyed the breakfast every morning with 360 degree views of the lake. Overall a very positive experience staying at Shangri-la Resort which I would recommend to all of my friends and family.

combined_text: Phander Lake Lake A clear, turquoise lake in Ghizer famed for reflections & fishing. It is heaven on earth. Its serenity and natural beauty cannot be described in words. Phander Valley is in Ghizer Gilgit-Baltistan Pakistan. Phander Valley is one of the most beautiful valley in Pakistan..It offers spectacular scenic view.. It is very lush green and very pleasant place. A twisting road passes through lush green fields and forests with a view of flowing river and icy peaks lead to this charming valley. From springs of crystal clear waters to lakes and rivers of deep blue water, there are all colors of natures beauty in Phandar Valley. Peaceful deep blue waters of River Ghizer and surrounding lush green and golden fields are breathtaking. There is a lake at the eastern end of the valley named Phander Lake. Phander Lake is one of the most famous tourist spots in the entire region. . The Phandar Lake gives masmerizing views. The deep blue of Phander lake offers a magnificent view. It is very famous for trout fish . The people of this valley are simple,hard working and very hospital. Best season to visit Phandar valley is between June and July Days stays fair and warm and nights are a little cold. Phandar Valley, a hidden gem in Pakistan's Gilgit-Baltistan region, is renowned for its breathtaking landscapes and tranquil ambiance. Nestled amidst lush green fields and framed by snow-capped peaks, this valley is home to the serene Phandar Lake, where the water shifts in mesmerizing shades of blue and green. Known as "Little Kashmir," Phandar offers a perfect retreat for nature lovers, with opportunities for fishing, hiking, and peaceful boat rides. This picturesque valley has a rich cultural heritage and remains a peaceful escape for travelers seeking unspoiled natural beauty, making it a must-visit destination in northern Pakistan.

combined_text: Sheosar Lake Lake A high-altitude lake on the Deosai Plateau, outstanding plateau scenery. Beautiful place large meadows on high altitude, Deosai National Park. Breathtaking landscape after a 4 hour adventurous drive from Skardu! Most of the tourists visit deosai till chota pani only, some visit the next point Bara Pani, some go further to Kaala Pani, but most of the tourists miss the best point that comes after Kala pani, i-e the beautiful Sheosar lake. My advise to those visiting Deosai, bargain with the car rentals in clear way that you want to gi till Sheosar Lake, they will tell you the charges accordingly (july 2025 Prado Tx till Sheosar with fuel charges are 20k-25k). Leave early morning maximum till 8am no further than that. Reach deosai and do not stop at any point unless any emergency like using the restrooms that you will find at all camps. Reach Bara Pani that takes around hours from Skardu, its the best and only point to have lunch as other camps do not offer lunch, just fries and pakoras and tea. Leave Bara pani after lunch and reach Sheosar lake that will take further 1 and half hour from Bara pani. Stay at Sheosar lake for an hour and then leave back. On the way back you can stop for a moment at Kala pani and then stop again at Chota pani to enjoy evening tea with awesome pakoras and fries with awesome views. Reach back Skardu till 7 or 7:30 pm. A natural marvel. Coming from chillam choki into Deosai National Park. When you finally take the turn towards the lake; the first look, you get awestruck. The magnificence of the lake involuntarily makes you say SubhanAllah.

combined_text: Khalti Lake Lake Cold lake in Gupis-Yasin, freezes in winter; known for trout. Khalti Lake is situated in Tehsil Gupis of Ghizer District, the westernmost part of the Gilgit Baltistan, and northernmost territory of Pakistan.This lake is an important source of fresh water and has a stock of trout.The water is extremely cold which flows directly from surrounding glaciers. The lake usually freezes in winter season and people can easily walk on it. One of the most beautiful lakes in Ghizer district of Gilgit baltistan. Must visit in November This lake is formed on Ghizer river by mountain sliding. It is surrounded by Mountains.It located in few kilometers beyond Gopis a sub division of Ghizer division Gilgit-Baltistan. Its altitude is above 7000 feets. Beautiful lake with filled with clean chill water. It frozen in winter. It's has very beautiful natural views.

combined_text: Dudipatsar Lake Lake Alpine glacial lake in Lulusar-Dudipatsar National Park (Kaghan). Dudipatsar Lake, often referred to as the "Queen of Lakes," is a stunning alpine glacial lake nestled in the Lulusar-Dudipatsar National Park at the northern end of Kaghan Valley, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan. Situated at an elevation of approximately 3,800 meters (12,500 feet), the lake is encircled by snow-clad peaks averaging around 4,800 meters (15,700 feet) in elevation . It's still less explored & very less frequently visited lake located in Mansehra District, KP. It's scenic beauty, crystal clear greenish blue frigid water, abundant with Rainbow Trout, surrounded by lofty snow clad mountains and almost pin drop silence makes everyone crazy. One cannot absorb its beauty with naked eye. However, you have to be careful because security situation is not fine due to it proximity to Kohistan, which inhabits some criminals. Dudipatsar Lake is a beautiful lake located in the Kaghan Valley of Pakistan. The starting point is from Moon Restaurant, Besal a.k.a Besar. It is an 18 KM long hiking track which can be covered in 5-7 Hours. Daudipatsar Lake is surrounded by snow-capped and green mountains. The lake is a popular destination for hiking, camping, and fishing. The water in the lake is crystal clear and the views are breathtaking.

combined_text: Chitta Katha Lake Lake Remote glacial lake in Shounter Valley; a strenuous, scenic trek. A 9-hour trek that pushed us to our limits.. Steep, exhausting, and tough. But the moment we saw the lake, surrounded by majestic mountains, everything was worth it. Absolutely breathtaking. All the pain vanished. Nature at its purest. One the best trek Ive ever seen. This lake is existing in AJK Neelum Shounter Valley. Once you reaches Kel then from there u have to travel on 4*4, and it take almost 3 to 4 hours to reach Domel. From there you have to trek of almost 5 consecutive hrs to reach on top of lake. This is one the hardest trek and if you luv hiking you definitely going to luv forever. View is so fabulous of the trek. On the way u would finds streams, 2 Base Camp on the way. U can stay there and they provide you the meal as well but not free. Essentials: Carry hiking stick. Carry only the imp things on the trek. U must apply sun screen before trekking bcz at height ur skin could be damage from direct sunlight. Wear joggers. Chitta Katha Lake is an absolutely breathtaking destination in Azad Kashmir!  The crystal-clear turquoise water, surrounded by towering snow-capped peaks, makes it a paradise for nature lovers and adventure seekers. The trek is challenging but incredibly rewarding, offering stunning views along the way.  Pros:  Spectacular scenery with pristine alpine beauty  Perfect for trekking and photography  Peaceful and less crowded  Cons:  The trek is physically demanding and not for beginners  Limited facilities  bring your own food and camping gear  Weather can change suddenly, so plan accordingly If you're up for an adventure and love exploring untouched natural wonders, this place is a must-visit!

combined_text: Rainbow Lake (Minimarg) Lake A vibrantly colored alpine lake in the Minimarg/ Astore area. Raw nature at its best. Breathtaking panoramic views all around. Best place to visit in Pakistan. Good facilities for dining and recreation. Plenty of parking. Only 4x4 vehicles allowed. Bikes over 150cc allowed. Overnight stay allowed for those who have booking in guest rooms or tent village only. Best time to visit is from April to September. Journey to the place is relatively tough but worth every second. Visiting Rainbow Lake near Minimarg was quite an adventure, its a bit of a mission to get there! The place itself is absolutely beautiful and would be perfect for a family outing, but the journey might be challenging for some. The road via Astore, Chillum, and Minimarg is mostly off-road and can be tough to navigate. That said, the stunning views and breathtaking scenery along the way make it worthwhile, though perhaps better suited for more adventurous travelers. There's also the historic Musharraf Hut nearby, named after General Musharraf, who reportedly stayed there during the Kargil conflict between the two neighboring countries. A beautiful lake nestled in probably the most beautiful valley in Pakistan, Minimarg. They allow tourists for a day visit in this beautiful valley now but you need a 4x4 vehicle or a motorcycle with minimum 150cc engine. Keep your NIC with you and dont travel with drones, camping equipment.

combined_text: Babusar Top Mountain Pass High mountain pass connecting Kaghan Valley and Gilgit-Baltistan. The place is wonderful with breathtaking views and majestic mountains. It could be maintained as an awesome tourist spot with proper amenities, but unfortunately, that is not the case. There are too many swings and zip lines installed in all directions, reducing the beauty of the place. Although the zip line on such height in itself is a thrilling experience for those who dare. The views are awesome, and they have a unique charisma to it. Babusar Top is one of the most stunning high-altitude mountain passes in Pakistan, located at 4,173 meters above sea level. It connects the Kaghan Valley with Chilas and Gilgit-Baltistan. The pass offers breathtaking views of snow-capped peaks, green meadows, and winding roads that make the journey unforgettable. The drive to Babusar Top is scenic and thrilling, especially during the summer months when the road is open. It's a favorite stop for tourists heading to northern areas, offering panoramic photo spots and a refreshing break from the lower valleys. However, the road can be dangerous in bad weather, so it's best to travel in daylight with a reliable vehicle. Babusar Top is ideal for nature lovers, photographers, and adventure seekers. It's peaceful, refreshing, and filled with natural beauty. A must-visit for anyone exploring northern Pakistan. Life's best experiences to reach and visit this Place . Alhamdu Lillah, worlds best and most Beautiful place in the world. Roads and place are safe. Its a Request to Pakistan govt and local govt KPK authorities to provide and avail basics need to improve like electricity, mobile facilities, Health facilities, road safety barrier and improve local people's.

combined_text: Rush Lake Lake Rugged alpine lake near Rush Pari Peak  one of the worlds highest alpine lakes. Rush Lake The Rush lake is a beautiful high altitude lake in Gilgit-Baltistan. It is near Rush Pari Peak at an elevation of 5,098 metres (16,726 feet) above sea level. Since it is on the height of 4,694 meters (15,400 feet), Rush lake is 25th most highest lake of the world and highest in Pakistan The trek towards the Rush lake in Gilgit-Baltistan, is very rough and tricky with continuous ascending and descending while climbing up. It is not everyones cup of tea to reach there. Only a few determined and adventurous people can capture it. Tourists can over look the Spantik Peak, Malubiting Peak, Miar Peak, Phuparash Peak and Ultarsar Peak from the lake. After reaching at the lake, its mesmerizing beauty and splendeur, the tourists are alluring by the breath-taking scenery on such an elevation, which cannot describe in the words, but could feel only by heart. It is truly a heaven on the Earth. The most noticable feature of our expedition is that we didn't hire any porter and guide which is not recommended due to deadly crevasses on Hoper Glacier and difficulty level of trek Rush Lake is located in the Hoper Village of the former state of Nagar Valley, which is now a sub-division located in the Hunza-Nagar district of Gilgit-Baltistan. Situated around 4,500 meters above sea level, Rush Lake is one of the most beautiful water bodies found in Pakistan. It is believed to be among the highest alpine lakes of the country. The towering Miar Peak and Spantik (Golden Peak) are located at a distance of not more than 15 kilometers from the lake. Rush Peak is a mountain in the Karakoram mountain range of Central Asia. It is located in the Nagar District of Gilgit-Baltistan, Pakistan. While not a high peak by local standards, it is noteworthy as a remote trekking destination. It can be reached via Nagar Valley and Hoper Village. The peak can be accessed via Hoper Glacier (Bualtar Glacier) and Barpu Glacier. The peak is relatively easy to climb in the summer months and ascents have been made by amateur climbers without proper mountaineering gear. In winter, access to the mountain is made difficult by heavy snows. The top of the peak provides stunning views of Miar Peak (6,824 m), Miar Glacier and Phuparash Peak (6,574 m). On a clear day, one can look east and see some of the world's highest mountains, including K2 and Broad Peak. At the mountain's base lies one of the world's highest alpine lakes, Rush Lake (4,694m). Copied Rush lake is one the world's most beautiful and highest alpine lakes located in the lap of alluring Rush peak Hoper Nagar. It is surrounded by lush green meadows. Cattle graze in the meadow adds more charm to the tourists visiting that place.

combined_text: Baltoro Glacier Glacier One of the longest non-polar glaciers; access to Concordia and K2 views. The Baltoro Glacier is one of the largest and most famous glaciers in the world, located in the Karakoram Range of Gilgit-Baltistan, Pakistan. Here are the key facts about it:  Location Situated in Baltistan, Gilgit-Baltistan region. Lies within the Karakoram mountain range.  Size Approximately 63 km (39 miles) long. Among the longest glaciers outside the polar regions.  Surrounding Peaks The glacier is surrounded by some of the highest peaks in the world, including: K2 (8,611 m)  worlds 2nd highest mountain. Gasherbrum I (8,080 m). Gasherbrum II (8,035 m). Broad Peak (8,051 m). Several other peaks above 7,000 m.  Rivers Meltwater from the glacier feeds into the Shigar River, a tributary of the Indus River.  Trekking The Baltoro Glacier trek is one of the most famous high-altitude treks in the world. Trekkers usually travel from Skardu  Askole  Baltoro Glacier  Concordia  K2 Base Camp. Concordia is the junction point of Baltoro and Godwin-Austen Glaciers, offering spectacular views of K2 and other giants.  Importance Vital freshwater source for Pakistan. A natural wonder attracting trekkers, mountaineers, and geologists. Famous for its rugged beauty, icy towers, and unique landscap. Beautiful glacier. Long and tiring route to Concordia and four 8000 m high peak base camps. Gasherbrum 1 and 2, Broad Peak and K2. On the route famous Masherbrum peak can be seen on right and Trango Towers initially on the left. Other famous peaks Chogolisa, snow dome, Sia Kangri, Baltoro Kangri, Virgin Peak and Muztag Tower are also in same area. One of the longest glacier outside polar region offering the world's most magnificent mountain scenery. The route to four 8000m mountain peaks.

combined_text: Concordia Mountainous / Campsite Campsite/trekking junction with spectacular views of K2 and other Karakoram peaks. Very well trained staff, with amicable nature. Calm, noiseless, clean place. The owner is knowledgeable about the locality, and helpful to provide tips. A must stay, especially for foreigners. The kittens at the reception are as nice... Family oriented place, I recently stayed at this hotel and couldn't be more pleased with my experience. Thelocationtruly is unbeatable... Whether you're in town for sightseeing, shopping, or dining, everything is just a short walk or quick ride away. Major landmarks, restaurants, and public transportation are all incredibly accessible.e.g Kharpocho fort, dewaane khas etc The hotel itself is clean, modern, and welcoming. My room was spacious, quiet, and had a great view . combined_text: Hussaini Suspension Bridge (Upper Hunza) Suspension Bridge / Landmark Famous (rickety) suspension bridge across Hunza River near Hussaini. A Thrilling Experience at Hussaini Suspension Bridge! Id seen the Hussaini Suspension Bridge countless times on YouTube, but nothing compares to seeing it in personits absolutely awesome. That first moment stepping onto the bridge was unforgettable. If youve got a fear of heights, this is definitely not the place for you. Crossing the bridge was both frightening and thrilling. It feels like the whole thing is moving, but its actually the water rushing beneath that messes with your senses. Just focus on the wooden planks and not the water. It took us around 30 to 40 minutes to get across one sideevery step required real nerves of steel. They do give you life jackets before crossing, which might sound reassuring at first. But we were bluntly told they wouldnt save usthe shock of falling into that freezing glacial water would likely be fatal. That definitely added to the intensity of the whole experience. Getting to the bridge isnt exactly easy either. Its a steep uphill climb with a lot of steps, so you need to be in decent shape. But once you're up there, the views are stunning and the adventure is totally worth it. And to top it all offwe zip-wired back across! It was the perfect adrenaline rush to end the journey. If youre ever in the area and looking for something unforgettable, this is one place you must experience. Hussaini Suspension Bridge in Hunza Valley is a unique and adventurous experience. Located over the Indus River in Hussaini Village, the journey starts by passing through the village itself, giving you a close look at local culture, lifestyle, and livelihood. Entry ticket is just Rs. 100, but its important to note that kids are not allowed to go far on the bridge due to safety concernsits genuinely dangerous and not for the faint-hearted. Theres also a zip line available at the site. However, during our visit, we saw someone get stuck midway while returning, which was enough for us to decide against trying it. One key thing to keep in mind is the extremely steep path on the way back. If you have difficulty walking on such inclines, its better to skip the hike. Carrying a water bottle is strongly recommended. The locals are incredibly friendly and welcoming. Most of the shops around the area are run by women, and their prices are surprisingly economical. I would sincerely encourage everyone to support them by purchasing somethingyou wont find such rates anywhere else. All in all, it was a wonderful and memorable experience. A must-try for anyone visiting Hunza Valley. One of the most beautiful suspension bridges I have ever been to. It's an adventurous place when you walk through the bridge you can get motion sickness you will feel like bridge is going away with water

combined_text: Ranikot Fort Historical Fort Enormous fortification known as the Great Wall of Sindh (huge circumference). Ranikot Fort, often referred to as the "Great Wall of Sindh," is one of the largest forts in the world, located in the Jamshoro District of Sindh, Pakistan. Spanning nearly 30 kilometers, its massive stone walls stretch across the rugged hills of the Kirthar range, creating a breathtaking sight. Though its origins remain unclear, it is believed to have been reconstructed in the early 19th century by the Talpur dynasty. Inside the outer wall are smaller forts like Mirikot and Shergarh, offering dramatic views and ancient architecture. The fort is popular among adventurers, photographers, and history lovers for its unique structure and natural beauty. Ideal for hiking, stargazing, and exploration, Ranikot is a hidden gem in Pakistan's heritage that offers a powerful blend of mystery and landscape. Rani Kot Fort, situated in Sindh Province, Pakistan, is the largest fort in the world, covering an impressive area of 32 square kilometers. Known as the "Wall of Pakistan" or the "Wall of Sindh," this historic site offers a blend of architectural grandeur and adventure. Visitors should make proper preparations before heading to the fort, as there is no continuous electricity supply. The Sindh government operates a guest house within the main fort, managed by the Aukaf department, guest house offers rooms with attached washroom but reservations and references must be arranged in advance and need to have your own dried food as well as backup or consultation with staff. Road conditions leading to the fort require a vehicle with good ground clearance. An overnight stay at Rani Kot is highly recommended for its serene environment and breathtaking stargazing opportunities. For an optimal experience, avoid visiting on nights with a visible moon to enjoy clearer skies. Bring mosquito repellent to ensure a comfortable stay. One of the unique features of Rani Kot is the absence of mobile network coverage, offering a rare opportunity for solitude and self-reflection away from modern distractions. Travelers seeking adventure can reach the fort by heading to Sann City and taking the off-road route from there. Rani Kot Fort is a must-visit destination for history enthusiasts and adventurers, promising a memorable experience of nature, history, and tranquility. ::An ultra, realistic 8k cinematic master pece ,Ayoung proud Sindhi doy standing inside the majstic Ranikot Fort, holding an old Sindhi book in his hand as if connecting with his roots, He gazes towards the vast breathtaking beauty of Ranikot, where massive golden stone walls stretch endlessly under adright blue Neelam sky filled with soft white drifng clouds, The morning sunlight shines gently on the ancient fort,

combined_text: Makli Necropolis Archaeological Site / Necropolis UNESCO-listed funerary complex near Thatta, with historic tombs & carvings. Makli Necropolis is a globally significant UNESCO World Heritage Site renowned for being one of the largest funerary complexes in the world. It serves as a monumental archive of Samma and Mughal architecture, distinguished by its superb sandstone masonry. The royal tombs feature intricately carved geometric and calligraphic friezes, offering a profound and visually stunning insight into the artistic zenith of historical Sindh. This site is an essential visit for anyone interested in monumental history and sophisticated craftsmanship. A must visit place if you like History. Really a surprise for me after visiting the site, About a 500 years of historic monument/ tombs,History, Resilience and everything else you want to know is there, a very small area is preserved, a lot of area should be further preserved, my request to "Culture tourism and antiquities department GOS" is to further emphasis on rehabilitation and preservation. We traveled from Karachi to visit Makli Graveyard and made a stop near the way before heading to Kenjhar Lake. The graveyard itself is massive and really impressive. So many old, beautifully carved tombs and monuments everywhere, some dating back hundreds of years. Walking around you can really feel the history and the effort that went into all this work. It is peaceful but also kind of overwhelming because of how huge it is. Took us a few hours just to explore a part of it. The site is pretty well kept considering its age. Definitely worth a visit if you like history or want to see something different on the way.

combined_text: Broghil Valley Valley Remote high-altitude valley in Upper Chitral, bordering Wakhan Corridor. Located way up north very close to Afghanistans Wakhan Corridor, Broghil Valley was formerly only accessible via trek or horseback. These days, the once-hidden locale can be reached by a treacherous jeep track  yet it still only receives a handful of visitors during the few months its not frozen under heaps of snow. Currently, whether or not foreigners are allowed to visit Broghil is iffy. (If youre insistent, make sure you check with the Deputy Commissioners Office in Chitral before making the trek up there.) But Pakistanis  please go see this beauty! The valley is home to numerous high-altitude lakes, yaks, and sprawling green pastures, all set against a dramatic mountainous backdrop that soars above 13,000 feet. Moreover, a days trek from Lashkargaz, the last village in Broghil, will lead you to Karambar Lake, one of the highest in the world! The area is mostly mountainous tracts. Elevations range from 3,280m at Kishmanjah village to 4,304m at Karamber Lake in northeast. The terrain is undulating, with steep mountains, wide stretch grassy plains and narrow valleys. The total area of peatlands and lakes is almost 3,400 ha. It was a remarkable journey and a best hidden place of pakistan, with adventure road.. Must visit place Off road out standing valley Must seen untouch beauty of life

combined_text: Garama Chashma (hot springs) Hot Springs / Scenic Retreat A hot springs site in Chitral region, used as a relaxation spot. Garam Chashmma is valley in Chitral offer scenic beauty,unique culture and one of the highest settlement. Due to Sulfur deposit beneath,temperature of water is usually hot (also known as as hot spring). This warm water is supplied to Mosques and Public places in order to lessen the need of geyser even in winter season. Garam Chashma is also an amazing spot to explore. Garam Chashma is a famous hot spring and picturesque valley located in the Chitral District of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan. Situated about 45 kilometers northwest of Chitral town, Garam Chashma is known for its natural hot sulfur springs, which are believed to have medicinal properties, attracting visitors seeking relief from ailments like skin diseases and joint pain. The valley is surrounded by the stunning Hindukush mountain range and offers spectacular natural beauty, with lush greenery, terraced fields, and rivers. Garam Chashma is also a gateway to many trekking routes and a popular spot for adventure tourists. In addition to the hot springs, the region has a rich cultural heritage, primarily inhabited by the Khow people, who speak the Khowar language. The area is also known for its traditional handicrafts, such as handwoven fabrics and Chitrali caps. Garam Chashma is a peaceful retreat for those seeking natural healing, relaxation, and scenic beauty away from the more crowded tourist destinations. Road is not good now a days. People are friendly and welcoming, I suggest to leave the car at Chitral and hire a car to travel. Although the Chasma ( spring) is not worth mentioning, I am really amazed by the natural beauty of the area. Could easily take one full day to go, relax, eat and come back to Chitral.Polo ground is a bonus watch.

combined_text: Shandur Pass (general) Mountain Pass The pass area beside Shandur Polo Ground (top of the plateau). Shandur Pass is a breathtaking high-mountain pass located between Gilgit-Baltistan and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, at an altitude of around 12,000 feet. It is famous for hosting the annual Shandur Polo Festival, the highest polo ground in the world. Surrounded by snow-capped peaks and lush green meadows, the pass offers a unique mix of adventure, culture, and natural beauty. Summer is the best time to visit, as the roads are often blocked in winter due to snow. Visitors can enjoy camping, photography, and experience traditional mountain culture in a serene environment. A must-visit spot for nature and adventure lovers. World's Highest Pass is known as Shandur Pass is located Chitral & Gilgit Baltistan Border, The road Conditions are very difficult and Dangerous But Beauty Is End of World  This pass is a wonder itself... about 4/5 months this pass remains closed due to extreme weather & snowfall....

combined_text: Nagarparkar Jain Temples Archaeological / Religious Site Ancient ornately carved Jain temples in the Thar Desert, sandstone, murals & architecture. The Old Jain Temple in Nagarparker, Interior Sindh, is a beautiful and historic site. Its old walls and detailed carvings tell stories of the past. Inside, it's peaceful and full of delicate sculptures. Beyond its beauty, the temple represents people living together peacefully despite differences in beliefs. It's a place that leaves a lasting impression of respect and admiration. One thing to keep in mind is that, there is no infrastructure for tourists, There is no availability of clean water and food, so you must carry these things with you in your car, and keep track of the fuel as there are no fuel stations there. The temple is a stunning masterpiece of art. Old Jain Temple at the corner of the Nagar Parkar City on road leads to Karunjhar hill range. This temple is under renovation but open for public.

combined_text: Princess of Hope Rock formation Famous wind-eroded rock formation in Hingol National Park that looks like a standing woman; visible from the Makran Coastal Highway. Good spot to visit. Don't forget to climb up to the top for a closer look. Place is very deserted, take all precautionary measures before visiting. It's part of Hingol National Park and Angelina Jolie named it princess of hope. It's a beautiful carved out mountain peak. Princess of Hope is a stunning natural rock formation located along the Makran Coastal Highway in Hingol National Park, Balochistan. Shaped like a standing woman, this unique structure was named by Angelina Jolie during her visit in 2002. Surrounded by rugged mountains and desert beauty, its a peaceful, scenic spot worth visiting. The journey along the coastal highway is equally breathtaking, with sights like Kund Malir Beach and the Balochistan Sphinx nearby. A must-see for nature lovers and adventure seekers traveling from Karachi. In mid-June, we decided to visit Kund Malir and then headed to the Princess of Hope, as we had heard a lot about it. However, June is a very warm month, making it difficult to step out of the vehicle for long. There were no canteens or cafeterias in sight, but there is a proper staircase leading up the hill. I didnt go because of the heat. Instead, I stayed with a friend inside the vehicle while the others went up. When I looked at the Princess of Hope and the surrounding hills, it felt like someone had been here thousands of years before us. The formations almost gave the impression of an ancient civilization that lived and worked here but left their work unfinished. Thats just the thought that came to my mind while observing the place. If you plan to visit, I recommend coming before sunset to avoid the heat.

combined_text: Karoonjhar Hills Hills / Cultural landscape Granite hill range near Nagarparkar famous for pilgrimages, ancient sites, medicinal plants and endemic wildlife. Karonjhar Mountain is one of the most beautiful and peaceful places in Sindh, Pakistan. The mountain is full of natural beauty, surrounded by rocky hills, small waterfalls, and a calm atmosphere. Its a perfect spot for nature lovers, photographers, and those who love exploring historical and spiritual sites. The weather here is pleasant, especially in spring, and the views from the top are simply amazing. You can also find ancient temples and cultural landmarks that show the deep history of this region. Highly recommended for anyone who wants to enjoy nature and peace away from the busy city life. Visited in 2016 Karoonghar Mountains are located small city of Nagar Parker near Pakistan and Indian Boarder, Just visited Karonjhar after the rain and it was amazing! The hills were lush green, waterfalls were roaring, and wildflowers were blooming everywhere. The fresh air and scenic views made it a perfect trip. A must-visit after a downpour.

combined_text: Shah Jahan Mosque (Thatta) Mosque 17th-century Mughal mosque famed for its exquisite tile and brick work; near Makli Necropolis. The Shah Jahan Masjid in Thatta is an architectural masterpiece, instantly recognizable by its spectacular and extensive display of blue glazed tile-work, which is arguably the most elaborate in the entire Indian Subcontinent. Built with distinct Timurid and Persian influences, the mosque's red-brick structure is crowned by 93 domes. Beyond its visual beauty, the mosque is an engineering marvel, boasting perfect acousticsa voice near the mihrab can be clearly heard throughout the entire hall. This unique combination of stunning tile artistry and advanced sound design makes it an essential cultural and historical monument to visit. Shah Jahan Mosque, Thatta  A Timeless Mughal Masterpiece . . . Architectural Grandeur & Design Acoustic & Environmental Ingenuity . . Historical Context & Conservation . peaceful but remote; bring water and shade Overall Impression The Shah Jahan Mosque in Thatta stands as a testament not only to Mughal artistry but also to human ingenuitymelding form, function, and faith in brick, tile, and dome. It offers a serene pilgrimage through history: a space that is at once celestial, acoustic, and culturally significant. For anyone traveling within the Sindh region, this mosque is a must-visit destination, resonating with beauty, complexity, and a timeless aura that transcends centuries. A historical and acoustic wonder. Built in the 17th century by Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan, it still serves as a place of worship today. The domes and archesan artwork of their ownremain mesmerizing. Designed with such precision that a sound made at the front of the building travels clearly to the far end of the mosque, leaving visitors inspired by the high level of knowledge and architectural skill of that era.

combined_text: Manchar Lake Lake/Social landscape Largest freshwater lake in Pakistan; home to Mohana 'boat people' and an important (but threatened) wetland. Manchar Lake is historically significant as the largest natural freshwater lake in Pakistan and one of Asia's great wetland ecosystems, once supporting an immense population of fisherfolk (Mohanas) and serving as a crucial stopover for Siberian migratory birds. Located near Sehwan Sharif, it is surrounded by ancient Harappan-era archaeological sites, underscoring its deep historical roots in the region. However, a responsible visitor must acknowledge the lake's current crisis; due to pollution from industrial and agricultural runoff, its water quality and biodiversity have been severely degraded. While the fluctuating size and the unique floating village lifestyle are compelling, the site currently requires urgent conservation efforts. It remains a powerful location for understanding Pakistans environmental challenges and its rich cultural past. At Manchar Lake I took an excursion to visit a small floating village of about 50 boats and 600 people. It was interesting but they certainly did a good job of asking for money at any opportunity. Very picturesque. It is the biggest lake of Pakistan ,but due to lack of interest of the previous governments in tourism, there is no designated picnic site at manchar lake, so you have to carry picnic stuff by yourself from home. But overall its an amazing place to visit, with all the natural beauty u can imagine . Its like a mini sea but with fresh water .

combined_text: Kirthar National Park National Park Large protected area in the Kirthar Range with desert landscapes, wildlife (Sindh ibex, wolves) and picnic points. Kirthar National Park is located in the Kirthar Mountains of Sindh, Pakistan. It covers an area of approximately 2,700 square kilometers, making it one of the largest national parks in Pakistan. The park is characterized by its rugged terrain, with a mix of arid desert landscapes, rocky hills, and sparse vegetation. ### Key Features: 1. **Geography:** The park features a variety of landscapes including mountainous areas, rocky outcrops, and arid plains. The Kirthar Mountains are the prominent geological feature, providing a dramatic backdrop to the parks scenery. 2. **Wildlife:** Kirthar National Park is home to several species of wildlife, including the Sindh ibex, chinkara gazelle, leopards, and a variety of bird species. The park serves as a crucial habitat for these species, many of which are adapted to the harsh conditions of the region. 3. **Flora:** The vegetation in the park is sparse, with hardy shrubs and grasses that can withstand the dry conditions. Some of the plant species include desert flora and various types of acacia and palm trees. 4. **Climate:** The climate is predominantly arid, with hot summers and mild winters. Rainfall is scarce, contributing to the dry and rugged nature of the landscape. 5. **Activities:** Visitors to Kirthar National Park can engage in activities such as wildlife observation, trekking, and photography. The park's remote and rugged environment provides opportunities for exploring its natural beauty and observing its unique wildlife. Kirthar National Park is important for conservation and offers a glimpse into the diverse ecosystems and wildlife of Pakistan's arid regions. The second largest national park in Pakistan after Hingol National Park. Khirthar National Park is a hidden gem in Pakistan, boasting stunning landscapes and rich biodiversity. Spread across the rugged Khirthar mountain range, this park offers an adventurous escape from the hustle and bustle of city life. The Kirthar National Park is situated in the Kirthar Mountains in Jamshoro District in Sindh, Pakistan. It was established in 1974 and encompasses over 3,087 km2 (1,192 sq mi), making it the third largest national park in Pakistan. Wildlife in the park comprises leopard, striped hyena, Indian wolves, honey badger, urial, chinkara gazelles and rare Sindh ibex. Blackbuck are kept in enclosures for a reintroduction project.

combined_text: Lal Suhanra National Park National Park / Biosphere Reserve UNESCO biosphere reserve combining desert, wetlands and scrub forest near Bahawalpur; notable wildlife and Patisar Lake. Lal Suhanra Park, Bahawalpur  A Brief Overview Lal Suhanra Park is a prominent national park located near Bahawalpur in southern Punjab, Pakistan. It spans a vast area that showcases a unique blend of arid desert landscapes, lush woodlands, and scenic wetlands, making it a truly diverse ecological haven. Key Highlights: Biodiversity & Conservation: The park serves as a sanctuary for a variety of wildlife species, hosting both indigenous fauna and exotic animals within its well-maintained zoo. It plays a vital role in regional conservation efforts. Recreational Facilities: Visitors can enjoy activities such as wildlife safaris, bird watching, and boat rides on the parks lakes. Its well-planned trails and picnic spots attract families and nature enthusiasts. Ecotourism & Education: Beyond recreational offerings, Lal Suhanra Park is an important center for environmental education and conservation awareness, drawing researchers and eco-tourists interested in the rich biodiversity of the region. Cultural & Historical Significance: Situated near the historic city of Bahawalpur, the park also reflects the regions cultural heritage and commitment to preserving natural landscapes. Overall, Lal Suhanra Park is a must-visit destination that provides insight into the ecological diversity of southern Punjab while offering a blend of leisure, education, and conservation initiatives. A beautiful and serene place to witness Allah's beautiful creations upclose. I haven't felt such calmness ever while I was there in the park. The habitat is huge and you can roam freely. The highlight of the tour is the evening feeding frenzy of the black bucks. A must visit place for all ages. Lal Suhanra is a national park of Pakistan situated in Bahawalpur district of Punjab province, which is one of the largest nationals parks in South Asia. Lal Sohanra is spread over 162568 acres and is notable for the diversity of its landscape, which includes areas of desert, forest and wetland. The park itself is situated some 35 kilometres east of Bahawalpur and presents a synthesis of forest and desert life. It occupies land on both sides of Desert Branch canal, and is spread over an area of 127,480 acres (51,368 hectares) - out of which 20,974 acres (8,491 hectares) are green land (irrigated plantations), 101,726 acres (40,942 hectares) are dry land (desert), and 4,780 acres are wet land (ponds and lakes). The park's terrain is generally flat, interspersed with sand dunes measuring between 1 and 6 meters in height and occupying as many as thousands of acres apiece.The national park was established on 77480 acres in 1972 for conservation and propagation of endangered fauna and flora in cholistan.An area of 50000 acres was further added in 1984 & 35088 acres was added in year 2000 making the total area of lal suhanra national park 162568 acres. Survey regarding transfer of an additional area of 28800 acres has been completed. The management objectives of the national park include; conservation of native fauna & flora species of Cholistan, particularly endangered one e.g. Chinkara, Blackbuck, Blue bull and others to ensure a sustained wildlife management of threatened wildlife species in the country. Encourage scientific studies on native flora and fauna species of Cholistan and to restore and improve native gene pool specially in Black buck, Chinkara and Blue bull. Copied

combined_text: Tomb of Shah Rukn-e-Alam Mausoleum / Shrine Major 14th-century Sufi mausoleum in Multan; iconic example of Tughluq architecture and important pilgrimage site. Shah Rukn-e-Alam (formally Sheikh Rukn-ud-Din Abul Fateh) was an extremely important 13th and 14th-century Punjabi Muslim Sufi saint from Multan (in modern-day Pakistan). Here are the key things to know about him and his legacy: The Saint and His Life * Title Meaning: His title, Shah Rukn-e-Alam, means "Pillar of the World." * Sufi Order: He belonged to the Suhrawardiyya Sufi order. * Family: He was the son of Pir Sadar-Al-Din Arif and the grandson and spiritual successor of another renowned saint, Baha-ud-din Zakariya. * Influence: He is revered as one of the most eminent saints of the region and dedicated his life to teaching and spreading the call to righteousness. The Tomb of Shah Rukn-e-Alam * Location: His mausoleum is located in the city of Multan, Punjab, Pakistan. * Architecture: The tomb is a stunning example of pre-Mughal and is considered the earliest example of Tughluq architecture in the Indian subcontinent. It was built between 1320 and 1324 CE. * Structure: It's a magnificent, towering three-tiered, octagonal structure, constructed of red brick and decorated with beautiful blue and white glazed faience mosaic tiles. * Pilgrimage Site: The shrine is a major site of pilgrimage, attracting over 100,000 pilgrims yearly from all over South Asia, especially for the annual Urs festival commemorating his death. Shah Rukn-e-Alam and his shrine remain a profoundly significant part of the historical, cultural, and spiritual landscape of Multan. Discover the Timeless Beauty of Hazrat Shah Rukn-e-Alam Tomb Located in the heart of Multan, Punjab, the Hazrat Shah Rukn-e-Alam Tomb is a breathtakingly beautiful and historic site that will leave you spellbound. This ancient mausoleum is not only a testament to the region's rich cultural heritage but also a masterpiece of architecture that showcases unique and intricate designs. As you step into the tomb, you'll be struck by the stunning artwork and craftsmanship that adorns the walls and ceilings. The intricate woodwork and ornate decorations are truly awe-inspiring, and you'll find yourself marveling at the skill and attention to detail that has gone into creating this magnificent structure. The tomb is also the final resting place of some revered spiritual figures, adding to its spiritual significance. The atmosphere is peaceful and serene, and the cool breeze provides a welcome respite from the scorching heat of Multan. One of the unique attractions here is a tree adorned with small pieces of cloth, tied by devotees as a symbol of their wishes. It's fascinating to see the vibrant colors and the hopes and prayers of the people. However, be cautious of pickpockets and some individuals within the shrine who might approach you for money. The surrounding gardens are beautifully maintained, and the nearby bird market adds to the charm of the place. Whether you're a history buff, an architecture enthusiast, or simply looking for a peaceful retreat, Hazrat Shah Rukn-e-Alam Tomb is an absolute must-visit destination. Recommendation: Plan your visit during the cooler hours of the day to make the most of your experience. Don't miss the stunning woodwork, artwork, and the vibrant gardens. Be respectful of the shrine and its surroundings, and enjoy the peaceful atmosphere that pervades this historic site. We were in Multan on a tour and our friend suggested to visit this tomb. There are few things thats must be improved but if we visit this tomb for historical reasons then this tomb has a significant historical value. This was a fun tour. Learnt a lot of new things, read some historical facts that were lost in the time. Overall a good experience would definitely recommend to others.

combined_text: Shigar Fort Fort / Heritage hotel Restored 17th-century fort in Shigar Valley, now a heritage hotel and cultural site near Skardu.  United Pakistan Tours had the pleasure of hosting a group at Serena Shigar Fort, and it was truly an unforgettable experience. The fort perfectly combines history, culture, and comfort. Our guests were amazed by the royal architecture, peaceful ambiance, and warm hospitality of the Serena team. A true symbol of heritage preserved with care  we highly recommend it to all travelers visiting Skardu. The most scenic and historic location I have ever stayed at, surrounded by beautiful mountains and the Indus River. My family and I thoroughly enjoyed our time at this hotel, which featured excellent service and a fantastic staff. Highly recommended. Although the Fort is surrounded be beautiful mountains and great views, fort itself is very small. Half of it has been converted into hotel by Serena. Not worth visiting especially if you already have visited Baltit Fort (which is very rich in history and huge in size).

combined_text: Babusar Top Mountain pass High mountain pass connecting Kaghan Valley to Gilgit-Baltistan (Babusar Top) with panoramic views and seasonal road. The place is wonderful with breathtaking views and majestic mountains. It could be maintained as an awesome tourist spot with proper amenities, but unfortunately, that is not the case. There are too many swings and zip lines installed in all directions, reducing the beauty of the place. Although the zip line on such height in itself is a thrilling experience for those who dare. The views are awesome, and they have a unique charisma to it. Babusar Top is one of the most stunning high-altitude mountain passes in Pakistan, located at 4,173 meters above sea level. It connects the Kaghan Valley with Chilas and Gilgit-Baltistan. The pass offers breathtaking views of snow-capped peaks, green meadows, and winding roads that make the journey unforgettable. The drive to Babusar Top is scenic and thrilling, especially during the summer months when the road is open. It's a favorite stop for tourists heading to northern areas, offering panoramic photo spots and a refreshing break from the lower valleys. However, the road can be dangerous in bad weather, so it's best to travel in daylight with a reliable vehicle. Babusar Top is ideal for nature lovers, photographers, and adventure seekers. It's peaceful, refreshing, and filled with natural beauty. A must-visit for anyone exploring northern Pakistan. Life's best experiences to reach and visit this Place . Alhamdu Lillah, worlds best and most Beautiful place in the world. Roads and place are safe. Its a Request to Pakistan govt and local govt KPK authorities to provide and avail basics need to improve like electricity, mobile facilities, Health facilities, road safety barrier and improve local people's.

combined_text: Lulusar Lake Lake High-altitude alpine lake near Naran (Lulusar-Sar)  prime scenic lake on the Kaghan circuit. Five stars bcz I visited it was first snow of the season. Its just at the start of Babusar, in terms of view its breathtaking. No need of anything special, just make sure to have decent shoes in case there is snow otherwise its very risky to go near the lake. I visited in snow, so I'm not sure if it's equally beautiful in normal days or not. Lulusar Lake - A Hidden Gem of Pakistan! Nestled at 11,200 ft above sea level in the Kaghan Valley, Lulusar Lake is a breathtaking alpine lake surrounded by snow-capped peaks and endless natural beauty. If you ever visit Naran-Kaghan, don't miss the chance to witness the serene charm of this lake perfect for photography, picnics, and simply soaking in nature. Lulusar Lake  Lulusar Lake is a stunning high-altitude lake located in the Kaghan Valley, about 48 kilometers from Naran, Pakistan. It sits at an elevation of around 11,200 feet (3,410 meters) above sea level and is surrounded by snow-capped peaks, making it one of the most scenic lakes in northern Pakistan. Highlights:  Breathtaking Beauty: Crystal-clear blue water reflecting the surrounding mountains.  Origin of the Kunhar River: The Kunhar River starts from Lulusar Lake and flows through Naran and Kaghan valleys.  Peaceful & Pristine: Less crowded than Naran, perfect for photography and relaxation.  Accessibility: Easily reachable by jeep or car via the NaranBabusar road during summer (JuneSeptember). Travel Tips: Best time to visit: June to early October Bring warm clothes  even in summer, it can be chilly.

combined_text: Passu Cones Viewpoint / Mountain peaks Iconic pointed granite peaks (Passu Cones) visible from Karakoram Highway  a famous photo viewpoint in Gojal (Upper Hunza). Passu cones in Gilgit-Baltistan are nothing short of a natural wonder. As soon as you lay eyes on them, the jagged, snow-capped peaks seem to pierce the sky, creating an awe-inspiring panorama that takes your breath away. The landscape surrounding the cones is just as stunning, crystal-clear rivers, and dramatic rock formations make it feel like you've stepped into a postcard. The journey to Passu itself is an adventure, winding mountain roads, with every turn revealing a more spectacular view than the last. It's a bit remote, but that only adds to its charm. The locals are incredibly friendly, always ready to share a smile and a story. Whether you're trekking, photographing, or just soaking in the serenity, there's a deep sense of peace and connection to nature here thats hard to find anywhere else. If youre an outdoor enthusiast, the hikes around Passu offer some truly unforgettable experiences. The area is rich in flora and fauna, and the panoramic views from the top are absolutely worth the climb. Its an ideal destination for anyone seeking both adventure and tranquility, with a touch of mystical beauty that stays with you long after you leave. In short, the Passu Cones are one of those rare places where nature's magnificence completely captivates you. If you're planning a trip to Gilgit-Baltistan, this is a must-see! Highly recommend it for anyone who loves mountains, stunning views, and a peaceful escape into the wilderness. Out of This World  A Dreamy Escape Passu Cones are truly a sight beyond words. The jagged peaks piercing the sky feel like something straight out of a dream. Its peaceful, majestic, and almost surreala place that makes you forget the world. I only wish I had the chance to camp here overnight and soak in the magic under the stars. If you're anywhere near Hunza, dont miss this breathtaking wonder. ### **Passu Cones  The Iconic "Cathedral of the Karakoram"** ** Location:** Near **Passu Village, Hunza Valley, Gilgit-Baltistan** (along the **Karakoram Highway**). #### ** About the Passu Cones:** - A **dramatic cluster of jagged peaks** rising to **6,106 meters (20,033 ft)**. - Nicknamed the **"Cathedral Peaks"** for their sharp, spire-like shapes. - Formed by **glacial erosion** over millions of yearspart of the **Tupopdan Mountain Range**. #### ** Why Visit?**  **Surreal Landscape**  Feels like another planet, especially at sunrise/sunset.  **Photography Heaven**  Famous backdrop for the **Karakoram Highway**.  **Adventure Hub**  Base for treks to **Passu Glacier & Batura Glacier**. #### ** How to Reach?** - **From Karimabad (Hunza):** 1-hour drive (~45 km) via KKH. - **From Passu Village:** Just a few minutes awaybest viewed from **Passu Suspension Bridge** or **Batura Glacier viewpoint**. #### ** Best Time to Visit:** - **MayOctober** (clear skies, accessible roads). - *Winter (NovApril):* Snow-covered but risky due to landslides. #### ** Top Things to Do:** 1. **Trek to Passu Glacier** (23 hours, moderate difficulty). 2. **Cross Hussaini Suspension Bridge** for a thrilling view of the cones. 3. **Stay in Passu Village**  Cozy guesthouses with cone views (e.g., **Passu Inn**). #### ** Tips:** - **Wear sturdy shoes**  Rocky, uneven terrain near glaciers. - **Carry water/snacks**  Limited shops in Passu. - **Respect local culture**  The area is home to **Wakhi people** (ask before photographing). The Passu Cones are **unmissable** on any Hunza tripwhether youre driving the KKH or trekking glaciers

combined_text: Hussaini Suspension Bridge Bridge / Adventure spot Dramatic hanging bridge over Hunza River near Hussaini  popular (and scary) crossing for visitors to upper Hunza. A Thrilling Experience at Hussaini Suspension Bridge! Id seen the Hussaini Suspension Bridge countless times on YouTube, but nothing compares to seeing it in personits absolutely awesome. That first moment stepping onto the bridge was unforgettable. If youve got a fear of heights, this is definitely not the place for you. Crossing the bridge was both frightening and thrilling. It feels like the whole thing is moving, but its actually the water rushing beneath that messes with your senses. Just focus on the wooden planks and not the water. It took us around 30 to 40 minutes to get across one sideevery step required real nerves of steel. They do give you life jackets before crossing, which might sound reassuring at first. But we were bluntly told they wouldnt save usthe shock of falling into that freezing glacial water would likely be fatal. That definitely added to the intensity of the whole experience. Getting to the bridge isnt exactly easy either. Its a steep uphill climb with a lot of steps, so you need to be in decent shape. But once you're up there, the views are stunning and the adventure is totally worth it. And to top it all offwe zip-wired back across! It was the perfect adrenaline rush to end the journey. If youre ever in the area and looking for something unforgettable, this is one place you must experience. Hussaini Suspension Bridge in Hunza Valley is a unique and adventurous experience. Located over the Indus River in Hussaini Village, the journey starts by passing through the village itself, giving you a close look at local culture, lifestyle, and livelihood. Entry ticket is just Rs. 100, but its important to note that kids are not allowed to go far on the bridge due to safety concernsits genuinely dangerous and not for the faint-hearted. Theres also a zip line available at the site. However, during our visit, we saw someone get stuck midway while returning, which was enough for us to decide against trying it. One key thing to keep in mind is the extremely steep path on the way back. If you have difficulty walking on such inclines, its better to skip the hike. Carrying a water bottle is strongly recommended. The locals are incredibly friendly and welcoming. Most of the shops around the area are run by women, and their prices are surprisingly economical. I would sincerely encourage everyone to support them by purchasing somethingyou wont find such rates anywhere else. All in all, it was a wonderful and memorable experience. A must-try for anyone visiting Hunza Valley. One of the most beautiful suspension bridges I have ever been to. It's an adventurous place when you walk through the bridge you can get motion sickness you will feel like bridge is going away with water

combined_text: Borith Lake Lake Small saline lake near Passu, known for still reflective waters framed by rugged peaks  a quiet spot off main KKH. ### **Borith Lake  A Hidden Gem in Hunza Valley** ** Location:** Near **Gulmit Village, Upper Hunza, Gilgit-Baltistan** (about **2 km from Passu**). #### ** About the Lake:** - A **glacial lake** formed by melting ice from **Ghulkin & Passu Glaciers**. - **Elevation:** ~2,600 meters (8,500 ft) above sea level. - Known for its **serene turquoise waters** and stark mountain backdrop. #### ** Why Visit?**  **Peaceful Escape**  Less touristy than Attabad Lake, perfect for solitude.  **Birdwatching**  Spot **migratory birds** like ducks and geese (best in **spring/autumn**).  **Trekking**  Connects to **Ghulkin Glacier** (23 hour hike).  **Photography**  Stunning reflections of **Passu Cones** at sunrise/sunset. #### ** How to Reach?** - **From Passu:** 30-minute **jeep ride** or 1.5-hour **hike** (moderate difficulty). - **From Gulmit:** 45-minute walk through scenic trails. #### ** Best Time to Visit:** - **MayOctober** (accessible; winters freeze the lake). #### ** Tips:** - Carry **water & snacks** (no shops nearby). - Wear **sturdy shoes** for rocky trails. - Respect the **fragile ecosystem** (no littering!). Borith Lake is a quiet retreat for nature loversideal after crossing the **Hussaini Bridge**! My visit was in mid of February, 2025, it was cold and the lake was frozen. But i believe the Borith Lake has been under-rated as did not heard of it from anyone. The place is serene in itself, the lake is covered by mountains and its 2 km approximately from the main KKH. A must visit lake once you are in GB and in summers it would be more attractive. Highly recommend Outstanding visit to Borith Lake. The lake is in Hunza, Pakistan. Its many steps downstairs followed by few meters of uneven way to reach to a lake which is completely frozen. Had a short walk with heart pumping. Amazing experience.
