combined_text: Keenjhar Lake Lake Large freshwater lake near Thatta, popular for boating and picnics; important birdlife area. Today, on 16th September 2025, I had the chance to visit the breathtaking Keenjhar Lake, and it turned out to be a truly memorable experience. The lake, stretching far and wide with its calm blue waters, looked incredibly refreshing under the clear sky. After the recent rains, the surrounding landscape was lush green, adding a cinematic touch to the whole scene. The cool breeze over the water and the reflection of drifting clouds created a peaceful and soothing atmosphere, making it a perfect escape from the hustle of daily life. Keenjhar Lake, also known as Kalri Lake, is one of Sindhs most enchanting natural treasures and a perfect escape for those seeking peace and beauty away from city life. Located near Thatta, the lake is the largest freshwater reservoir in Pakistan and holds immense cultural, historical, and ecological importance. When visiting, one is immediately struck by the vast stretch of calm blue waters blending seamlessly with the horizon. The recent rains have added a fresh charm to the scenery, with lush greenery sprouting around the lakes banks, creating a soothing and cinematic atmosphere. The reflection of clouds over the water, combined with the gentle waves, makes it an ideal place for relaxation and photography.  Keenjhar Lake (also known as Kalri Lake) is a magnificent destination, serving as Pakistan's second-largest freshwater body and a vital Ramsar Site for migratory birds. Its sheer scale and tranquil, blue waters offer a perfect retreat for picnics, boating, and swimming. What makes this site truly unique is the small tomb island at its center, which is the resting place of Noori, the heroine of the legendary Sindhi folklore, Noori Jam Tamachi. The lake thus provides a rare blend of stunning natural beauty and deep cultural heritage, making it a must-visit spot for both nature enthusiasts and those seeking a connection to the romantic history of Sindh. Keenjhar Lake, also known as Kalri Lake, is a breathtaking freshwater lake located near Thatta, approximately 130 kilometers from Karachi. As one of the largest lakes in Pakistan, it serves not only as a vital water reservoir for Karachi and surrounding areas but also as a premier tourist destination in Sindh. Whether you're a nature lover, a history enthusiast, or just someone looking for a peaceful getaway, Keenjhar offers an experience unlike any other. The serene blue waters stretching across the horizon create a picturesque setting ideal for relaxation and reflection. Visitors can enjoy boating, swimming, and jet skiing while soaking in the lake's natural beauty. There are shaded huts and sitting areas along the banks for families and groups, and the sunrise and sunset views here are truly mesmerizing. The lake holds spiritual and historical significance too. A shrine dedicated to Noori, the beloved character from the famous folklore "Noori Jam Tamachi", stands on an island in the middle of the lake and is visited by many devotees every year. The ambiance around the shrine adds a mystical charm to the overall experience. Food stalls and restaurants near the lake serve fresh fish and local delicacies, enhancing the days outing with traditional flavors. While weekends can get a bit crowded, weekdays are quieter and more peaceful for those seeking solitude. Basic facilities such as washrooms, seating, and parking are available, though they could be better maintained. Its recommended to bring essential items, especially if you plan to stay longer. Overall, Keenjhar Lake is a must-visit destination for those seeking nature, culture, and a break from urban life. Its tranquil environment and scenic beauty make it a perfect spot for day trips, photography, and picnics.

The desert have a people living very simple and traditional life with their animals(cows,goats,camels and dogs majorily). The forts like Derawar where Jeep rally held in winter is must visit place. It is also called Rohi in local language. The Lal Sohanra National park is located in Cholistan desert bank where you can see wild life especially rare black buck. "Cholistan Desert, located in the Sindh region of Pakistan, is a fascinating and vast desert that offers a unique blend of natural beauty and rich history. Known for its golden sands and expansive landscapes, Cholistan is famous for hosting thrilling car races like the Cholistan Jeep Rally, which attracts adventurers and tourists from all over the country. The desert holds a deep historical significance, with ancient forts like Derawar Fort standing as reminders of a bygone era. These historical sites offer a glimpse into the region's vibrant past. Despite being a desert, Cholistan has a certain charm that mesmerizes visitors, especially during the sunset when the sand dunes glow in the soft golden light. Whether you're a history enthusiast, adventure seeker, or just looking to experience the beauty of Pakistans deserts, Cholistan is an unforgettable destination." Cholistan desert is located in Distt. combined_text: Haramosh Valley Valley Remote valley near Skardu noted for dramatic peaks and access to Haramosh Peak; wild alpine scenery. I spent the weekend here. This is the best place I ever recently visited in Pakistan the landscape changes in every five minutes when youre hiking you can see all of different snow,Caped mountains and Greenlands with beautiful villages and you can witness have a launch really close Haramosh Valley is pure bliss. Home to fewer than 500 residents for generations, this remote area remains disconnected from major cities by road, preserving its untouched charm. The journey to Haramosh is nothing short of magical, with breathtaking scenery, majestic mountains, cascading waterfalls, and glaciers along the way that feel like a gateway to heaven. The meadows are a sight to behold, with a serene stream flowing on one side and towering mountain ranges on the other, creating a stunning contrast. Kutwal Lake, a 30-minute trek from the main Haramosh meadows, is absolutely mesmerizing. Once you reach this tranquil haven, its hard to imagine leaving. Surrounded by natures beauty and complete silence, you find a profound sense of inner peace. Visited Haramosh - beautiful scenery! The hike offered stunning views of the mountains and glaciers. A great place for a one-week trip the trek was a bit tough depending on your endurance. But its all worth it.

combined_text: Lok Virsa Museum Shop Museum Shop Excellent shop inside the museum selling authentic books, crafts, and traditional items. The Lok Virsa Museum in Islamabad is a wonderful place to learn about Pakistans rich culture and traditions. Located at Shakarparian Hills, the museum has many galleries that show our local crafts, colorful clothes, musical instruments, pottery, woodwork, and jewelry from all parts of the country. The section about Sufi saints is very special, with beautiful art and poetry that touches the heart. I really liked the life-sized displays of village homes and workshopsit felt like stepping into history. The museum is very family-friendly. There is plenty of parking space, and you can easily spend a few hours here with kids. There are food stalls nearby, lots of trees for shade, and benches where you can sit and relax. Sometimes there are cultural shows and festivals that make the visit even more fun. I didnt take photos inside because I wanted to respect the place and its rules. A great place for families, students, and anyone who loves our culture! We had a great experience visiting the Lok Visa Heritage Museum. The exhibits were fascinating and well-curated. However, the air conditioning inside the museum could be improved for better comfort. Additionally, the food available outside the museum could be of better quality, especially considering the relatively high prices. Enhancing both comfort and value would make the overall experience even better. It is a good place to visit especially on festive days. It has a huge museum and statues and artifacts showcasing Pakistan's rich culture and history. The museum sadly has no AC, so it's very hot. The place has bookshops and other merchants and artists as well. Overall a nice place. I feel that adding Pakistani scientists statues is important.

combined_text: Saidpur Village Pottery Shops Artisan Pottery Shops The pottery shops in this restored village sell beautiful handmade clayware. A hidden gem in the Saidpur Village that is a must-visit. The old man in this store is the son of the famous Pakistani rail-track builder who was responsible for building rail-tracks with mud foundation. The store is very small and involves going downstairs. Inside the store are a few items molded from mud. Each item on display took months of hard work. The old man will do the tour for you, and explain things. One is recommended to pay a small fee as a token of appreciation for the work and history. The store is right after the temples, and is inside an ally. It is recommended to ask. Worth spending 15-30 minutes here. Great pottery artwork. The owner is very kind and humble. Highly recommended if you want to see great pottery artwork. The owner is very cooperative if you want to shoot films their as well. The entry ticket is Pkr 20/- but try to give as much tip and motivate him to make more awesome artwork.

Very Beautiful Bazaar in Khaplu Ghanche District Khaplu Bazar is a bustling market located in the district ghanche Gilgit Baltistan of Pakistan. This market is one of the main attractions of the area, known for its traditional architecture, handicrafts, and local food. The market is home to a wide variety of shops selling everything from traditional textiles and handicrafts to fresh fruits, vegetables, and spices. The market is a great place to experience the local culture and interact with the friendly locals who are always eager to share their stories and traditions with visitors. One of the standout features of Khaplu Bazar is its beautiful traditional architecture, which is a blend of Tibetan and Balti styles. The buildings are made of locally sourced materials, including wood, stone, and mud, giving them a rustic, earthy charm. Visitors to Khaplu Bazar will also find a variety of local food stalls offering traditional Balti cuisine. These dishes are made using fresh, locally sourced ingredients and are bursting with flavor. Overall, Khaplu Bazar is a must-visit destination for anyone traveling to the Skardu district of Gilgit-Baltistan. _key: Lahore Fort ALI Gate Souvenir Shops
combined_text: Lahore Fort ALI Gate Souvenir Shops Souvenir Market Small shops near the fort entrance sell miniature paintings, camel skin lamps, and replicas. Craft Ghar at Lahore Fort is a fantastic place to find souvenirs and decorations that capture the spirit of Lahore and its famous fort. They have a great variety of items, from beautiful traditional crafts to unique home decor pieces. Everything is well-made and reflects the rich culture of Lahore. The staff is friendly and helpful, making the shopping experience enjoyable. If youre at Lahore Fort, be sure to check out Craft Ghar and take home a piece of Lahores heritage! The Shah Burj Gate, which forms part of the famous Picture Wall in the Lahore Fort, is the principal entrance to the Fort complex. The gate was constructed by Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan in 1041 A.H. (1631-32) under the supervision of architect Abdul Karim Mamur Khan. The inscription on the gateway describes a Divine Throne that is superior in height, elegance, and purity. The structures 2,300 square feet exterior surface area consists of recessed panels covered with fine Kashikari (tile-mosaic) work. WCLA and Agha khan trust done renovation work recently and they pressed the main gate and picture wall and nou lakha pavilion now its look very beautiful. Appreciated to all departments who involved in this preservation work and who do effort for this. Lahore Fort is a magnificent historical site that showcases the rich and diverse culture of the Mughal Empire. The fort is located in the heart of the old city of Lahore and covers an area of 20 hectares (50 acres). It contains 21 monuments, each with its own unique architectural style and artistic beauty. The fort was built and expanded by various Mughal emperors, starting from Akbar in the 16th century to Aurangzeb in the 17th century. The fort also witnessed the rise and fall of the Sikh Empire and the British colonial rule. The fort is a must-see for anyone.

combined_text: Empress Market Historical Market The historic market has sections for spices, dried fruits, and traditional items. A must visit for everyone going to Karachi. It stands symbol for the colonial times and it is still used for its original purpose: a market. You will find spices, fruits and veggies, household items, meat. Empress Market in Saddar, Karachi, is more than just a market; it's a living piece of history. The grand, colonial-era building with its distinctive clock tower still stands proudly, a testament to its British Raj origins. While it has undergone significant changes in recent years, particularly with the removal of encroachments, its bustling spirit remains. Today, Empress Market is primarily a hub for wholesale and retail of fresh produce  fruits, vegetables, meat, and a dazzling array of spices that awaken the senses. You'll find vendors specializing in everything from exotic dry fruits to everyday condiments. It's a fantastic place to experience the raw, vibrant energy of Karachi's local commerce, with the constant chatter of vendors and the lively crowd. Though some of the informal stalls that once spilled out onto the streets are gone, the market continues to be an essential part of Karachi's daily life, offering competitive prices and a vast selection. It's a truly authentic Karachi experience, a place where history and commerce intertwine. Be prepared for a sensory overload in the best possible way! A Historic Landmark That Needs Better Maintenance Empress Market is one of Karachis most iconic landmarks, steeped in colonial history and bustling with activity. Built between 1884 and 1889, the market was constructed to commemorate Queen Victoria, the Empress of India, during British rule. However, its location has a deeper historical significancethis was the site where Mangal Pandey, along with other Indian soldiers, was reportedly executed after the 1857 War of Independence. Today, Empress Market remains a vital commercial hub, offering everything from spices and dry fruits to household goods. Walking through its grand arched entrance, you can still see remnants of its original British-era architecture, a reminder of its historical past. However, the market is now overcrowded, and while the variety of goods available is impressive, the overall cleanliness leaves much to be desired. The markets historic charm is overshadowed by litter, poor waste management, and encroachments. To truly restore Empress Markets former grandeur, there is an urgent need for better cleanliness and maintenance. Additionally, more greenery around the market would complement its historical aesthetics, making it a more pleasant space for visitors. Proper restoration efforts, along with stricter waste management policies, could transform this site into not just a shopping destination but also a well-preserved historical attraction. Despite these shortcomings, Empress Market remains a must-visit for those who appreciate Karachis rich history and vibrant street culture. A little more care and restoration could elevate it to a five-star landmark.

Saddar Bazar in Peshawar is a vibrant area offering a wide range of products, including mobiles, clothing, and more. Its a great place to find almost anything you need. Saddar Bazar: A Mixed Bag Saddar Bazar offers a mixed shopping experience. I found the area to be generally clean and accessible, with ATMs conveniently located throughout. You'll find a good selection of locally made clothing for women, men, and children. However, if you're looking for used clothing (londa), shoes, or a wide variety of clothing, this might not be the place. The londa available is limited and, in my experience, of very low quality. While some brand outlets exist (like Limelight, Edenrobe  though the men's western collection is limited , Bata, Ndure, Service, Urbansole, and Saya), the selection is not as extensive as in larger cities like Karachi or Lahore. The food options are also limited. There are no major national or international restaurant chains. A word of caution to juice lovers: I would strongly advise against buying juice here. I experienced severe stomach pain for 24 hours after drinking pineapple juice. Overall, Saddar Bazar is good for everyday clothing needs, especially local brands. But for a wider selection of brands, used items, or diverse food choices, you might need to explore other areas.

In Lahai Bazar, you can find household goods, kitchenware, hardware, general stores, and many other daily-use products under one roof. The market is always full of activity and attracts both locals and visitors looking for reliable products at reasonable rates. For anyone searching for a trusted shopping destination and local market in Sialkot, Lahai Bazar is highly recommended for its convenience, variety, and traditional shopping experience. Lahai Bazar in Sialkot is a lively market known for its variety of goods and affordable prices. Open daily from 6:00 AM to 9:00 PM, it's conveniently located but often crowded, with limited parking. combined_text: Bamboo Crafts (Changa Manga) Bamboo Craft Workshop Workshops selling baskets, furniture, and crafts made from local bamboo. Changa Manga is a big man-made forest near Lahore, Pakistan. Its a peaceful place full of trees, birds, and fun activities. Its great for a one-day picnic with family or friends.  What You Can Do There: Mini Train Ride A small train takes you through the jungle. Fun for kids and gives you a nice view of the forest. Boating There is a lake where you can enjoy paddle boating. Very calm and relaxing. Picnic Areas You can sit, eat, and relax under big shady trees. Good place to bring homemade food and enjoy nature. Animals You might see deer, monkeys, and birds. There is a small zoo as well. Walking & Cycling You can walk or ride a bike on the paths in the forest.  Good Things: Quiet and peaceful place Good for kids and families Beautiful nature and fresh air Cheap or free to enter This is a dream like beautiful place, especially when the weather is cloudy. The rope bridge is not only fun but also adds to the esthetic beauty of the place. Now they have reduced the area, still it seems appealing. The admin could do very well but alas! The lake is too muddy, the boats are rotting, the birds have flown away, the trees are quite less, the vendors don't have proper system to sell any goods, the toilets have no doors, and at the entrance it says that camera is watching you but you have to keep an eye on your vehicle in the parking in case it gets stolen. It seems funny yet pathetic. The train timings are not mentioned and it leaves as soon as they think its full. No written instructions how much time it takes to complete a circle, but it is mentioned that you pay 100 rs per person till 1 corner to the other (then to return to the 1st corner from where you sat there is probably another 100 rs. per person, but we couldn't take the previlege to get a ride) we kept waiting for the train to get back on its station but there was nobody to tell how much wait was required. So after 20 min we left that place. The tram outside has no fee structure, that person said 1000 rs for a family, but a family could be 10 people or more, or less, but he couldn't justify. In short it can be made the most beautiful place by little bit of care but nobody cares. Even the public doesn't care to take away its litter after enjoying the food. There are cats in scarcity and no squirrels at all, which is the biggest flaw. It proves that there is no place for animals and birds to live in the forest. We should be so loving that birds get back there, that squirrels get abundant, that bees make hives, that butterflies dance in distance and make our young children aware how a forest looks. I wish someone local, who can, reads this all and brings improvement. Review: A Wonderful Visit to Changa Manga, Lahore Our recent visit to Changa Manga, located near Lahore, was an incredible experience filled with fun and relaxation. Known as one of the largest man-made forests in the world, this place offers a refreshing escape from the hustle and bustle of city life. From the moment we arrived, we were amazed by the lush greenery and the serene environment. The fresh air and scenic beauty made it a perfect spot for a picnic. We enjoyed walking through the forest trails, surrounded by towering trees and chirping birds, creating a peaceful atmosphere. One of the highlights of our visit was the famous Changa Manga train ride, which took us on a delightful journey through the forest. The boating area was another exciting experience, where we enjoyed paddling in the calm waters. The small zoo inside the park was a great attraction, especially for children. The park also has well-maintained picnic areas and food stalls, making it easy to relax and enjoy a meal with family and friends. The management has done a good job in keeping the place clean and safe for visitors. Overall, we had a fantastic time at Changa Manga. It is a must-visit destination for nature lovers and families looking for a peaceful getaway.

Our trip to Chitral and Kalash Valley (Bamburet) was absolutely magical. The scenic beauty of the mountains, lush greenery, and the peaceful rivers left us speechless. The Kalash culture was truly uniquecolorful, welcoming, and rich in tradition. Locals were incredibly hospitable and always greeted us with a smile. The wooden houses, traditional clothing, and warm hospitality made us feel like we were part of something special. We stayed in a cozy guesthouse surrounded by nature and had delicious local food. The road to Kalash was a bit rough in some areas, but the views made it all worth it. Highly recommended for anyone looking to explore the hidden gems of Pakistan! combined_text: Hunza Mineral Collectors Mineral Shop Shops selling collector-grade mineral specimens from the Karakoram mountains. Nice place having beautiful lakes, sceneries, history and rich culture. Also the local fruits l, dry fruits and food over here are very good and there are lot of options as well. Worth a visit but you have to come prepared as atmosphere here is very dry and the people with asthma or having lung issue or breathing issue should come prepared If you want to explore a rich culture and traditional touch representative of Gilgit-Baltistan, Hunza Valley is one of the best places to give you all that. **Hunza Valley  The Crown Jewel of Pakistans North** Nestled in the **Gilgit-Baltistan** region, **Hunza Valley** is a breathtaking paradise surrounded by the **Karakoram and Himalayan mountain ranges**. Known for its **stunning landscapes, rich culture, and hospitable people**, its often called *"Heaven on Earth."* ### ** Key Highlights:**  **Majestic Peaks**  Views of **Rakaposhi (7,788m), Ultar Sar, and Ladyfinger Peak**.  **Ancient Forts**  **Baltit Fort & Altit Fort** (centuries-old UNESCO-nominated sites).  **Turquoise Lakes**  **Attabad Lake** (famous for boat rides) & **Borith Lake**.  **Charming Villages**  **Karimabad, Passu, and Gulmit** with terraced fields & apricot blossoms.  **Cultural Richness**  Home to the **Burusho people**, known for longevity and vibrant traditions. ### ** Must-Visit Spots:** - **Eagles Nest**  Panoramic sunrise/sunset views over the valley. - **Passu Cones & Glacier**  A surreal, moon-like landscape. - **Hussaini Suspension Bridge**  One of the worlds most thrilling bridges. - **Khunjerab Pass**  Gateway to China (highest paved border crossing). ### ** Local Delicacies:** - **Hunza Apricots & Walnuts** - **Chapshuro** (meat-stuffed bread) - **Diram Fitti** (traditional buckwheat cake) ### ** Best Time to Visit:** - **AprilJune** (spring blooms) - **SeptemberOctober** (autumn golden hues) - *Avoid winters (heavy snow blocks roads).* ### ** How to Reach?** - **By Air:** Fly to **Gilgit Airport**, then drive (2.5 hrs). - **By Road:** Via **Karakoram Highway (KKH)** from Islamabad (~14-16 hrs). ### ** Travel Tips:**  Carry **warm clothes** (even summers get chilly at night).  Respect **local customs** (modest dress, no public drinking).  Get a **NOC for foreign tourists** if visiting restricted zones. Hunza is more than just a destinationits an **experience of awe and serenity**. Whether youre an adventurer, photographer, or culture lover, this valley will leave you spellbound!

combined_text: Gawadar Seashell Crafts Seashell Artisan Artisans creating decorative items from local seashells and marine materials. Gwadar port is one of the world deepest and Pakistans main operating port after Qasim Port Karachi. It is key element of Cpec that connect kashgar to gwadar. It has few berths operational and a lot of work is being done to expand and make it one of the worlds largest port in the world. Worth seeing place. Gwadar is the most beautiful city in Pakistan .if want a plan for travel so traveling on road to GWADAR its a best place for tourism. Gwadar is strategically situated on the southwestern coast of Pakistan, overlooking the Arabian Sea. It's positioned near the Strait of Hormuz, a vital chokepoint for international oil trade. Gwadar facilitates the transport of energy resources, including oil and natural gas, making it an essential component of energy supply chains in the region. The depth of water at Gwadar Sea Port is 14.5 m (outer channel)/13.8 m (inner channel), significant and ranks among the deeper sea ports worldwide. Gwadar Port's depth allows it to accommodate large vessels and deep-draft ships, making it a crucial maritime hub for international trade and shipping. Its deepwater capabilities contribute to its strategic importance in the region.

combined_text: Multani Glass Bangles Glass Artisan Artisans creating colorful glass bangles using traditional glassblowing techniques. Hussain Agahi Market in Multan is one of the busiest shopping areas in the city. Located within the inner streets near the shrine, this market is known for offering a wide range of products. Womens clothing, ready-made dresses, bridal outfits, and decorative accessories for wedding ceremonies are available here. Additionally, childrens items, sweets shops, mens clothing, and modern electronic goods such as TVs, air conditioners, and room coolers can also be found. In recent days, encroachments have been removed, making shopping even more convenient. At night, the market is beautifully illuminated with lights, creating a vibrant and charming atmosphere. Women from surrounding and remote areas prefer to shop here due to the markets variety and affordability. The market also offers a great selection of traditional and delicious food, making it a complete shopping and dining experience. Very congested bazaar. Unable to move safely with car like vehicle. Better option is either by walk or a bike. Rates are better than other city markets. Absolutely amazing experience! Everything exceeded my expectations. Highly recommended!

Haveli offers a truly memorable dining experience. The service was excellent  attentive, polite, and efficient throughout. The atmosphere was vibrant and full of life, with a stunning view overlooking the old city of Lahore that adds a special charm to the evening. We ordered the BBQ platter, which came with a generous variety of kebabs, mutton, chicken, fish, and more. Each item was cooked beautifully  tender, flavorful, and free from any strong smell, showing how well they handle their meats. Overall, a perfect mix of great food, warm service, and breathtaking ambiance. A must-visit spot for anyone wanting to experience the spirit of Lahore in one meal. A Perfect Blend of Taste & Heritage Visited Haveli yesterday and had a wonderful experience. I tried their tea, kulfi ice, and gulab jamun all were delicious, fresh, and full of authentic flavor. The tea was perfectly brewed, the kulfi had that rich, creamy texture, and the gulab jamun melted in the mouth with just the right sweetness. What made the experience truly special was the view from the rooftop, you can see the magnificent Badshahi Mosque in all its glory. The entire place has an old heritage touch that takes you back in time, giving you a true taste of Lahores cultural charm. Highly recommended for anyone looking to enjoy great food with an unforgettable view. Haveli Restaurant offers delicious food and excellent service. Highly recommended! I loved my experience at Haveli Restaurant  great taste, friendly staff, and a beautiful ambiance. If you want traditional and tasty food, Haveli Restaurant is the best choice! Amazing food quality and quick service. Haveli Restaurant never disappoints! Haveli Restaurant has a wonderful environment and mouth-watering dishes. A must-visit place!  Medium-Length Reviews Haveli Restaurant is one of the best dining spots in town. The food was fresh, flavorful, and beautifully presented. The staff was polite and attentive. Ill definitely be coming back again! Had a great experience at Haveli Restaurant. The traditional dcor, soothing atmosphere, and excellent food made my evening perfect. Highly recommend this place for family gatherings. The food at Haveli Restaurant was amazing  rich in flavor and perfectly cooked. The service was quick, and the staff made sure everything was perfect. Truly a five-star experience!  Long Review I recently visited Haveli Restaurant with my family, and it was a fantastic experience. The restaurants ambiance gives a true cultural vibe, and the staff were very welcoming. Every dish we ordered was delicious, especially the barbecue and handi. The presentation and taste exceeded our expectations. Haveli Restaurant is definitely one of the best places to enjoy traditional food in a comfortable and family-friendly setting. Highly recommended!

combined_text: Freddie's Walled City (Heera Mandi) Nihari / Paye Renowned for its rich, creamy paye (trotters) and nihari, a legacy of the old Heera Mandi. Finally got the chance to try Waris Nihari in Anarkali  its been on my list for a long time since theres so much hype around it and food bloggers seem to go crazy for it. Honestly, I found it a bit overhyped. First of all, the price is quite high  a small nihari costs Rs. 900. Yes, the portion is enough for two people, but still feels expensive compared to other places. The taste was good but not something out of this world or worth the massive hype. Service was another downside. I was expecting quick service for such a famous spot, but it was really slow  felt like it took forever just to get our order. Overall, its worth trying once for the experience and to see what the hype is about, but in my opinion, it doesnt fully live up to the reputation. Recently visited waris nehari with my friend. Overall experience was good. We ordered their nali nehari. If we talk about taste, I would say it was one the best nehari i ever tried. Although the environment and sitting arrangement was not well, but the taste and food quality was very good. If you want to feel old Androon Lahore vibes and taste authentic nali nehari in Lahore, Pakistan, Waris is one the best option. Ill go again for sure. It tasted pure, sumptuous...almost spiritual. The server was quite helpful. Atmosphere at the Anarkali market branch was average- I was on the ground floor (not the family lounge) and expected a little better. You need air conditioner to consume that much fat! All in all, the place deserves its fame. Highly recommended.

combined_text: Phajja Siri Paye, Lakshmi Chowk Siri Paye A legendary establishment, famous for its siri paye (beef head and trotters stew) since 1940. Visited Pajja Paye in Androon Lahore for lunch. The paye here are consistently delicious and full of authentic flavor  definitely one of the best in town. However, the overall hygiene and upkeep of the place need attention. Cleanliness is not up to the mark, and the service from the staff feels inattentive. If they improve the maintenance and customer service, this place could easily stand out as a top choice for traditional food lovers. It used to be good but new generation totally messed up, average taste like simple salan and paya was also undercooked. Phaja Siri Paye is a legendary establishment and one of the oldest shops in the Siri Paye business, renowned for its rich history and authentic flavors. This iconic eatery has stood the test of time, offering a delightful culinary experience that keeps locals and visitors coming back for more. Specializing in traditional Siri Paye, a dish made from tender trotters cooked in a rich, flavorful gravy, the shop serves up a hearty and satisfying meal that is perfect for breakfast or any time of the day. What sets Phaja Siri Paye apart is not just its delicious food but also its commitment to maintaining a clean and welcoming environment. The shop takes pride in its hygiene standards, ensuring that every dish is prepared with care and served in a spotless setting. The warm and friendly staff add to the overall experience, making you feel right at home. For food enthusiasts and those looking to explore authentic local cuisine, Phaja Siri Paye is a must-visit destination. Whether you're a fan of traditional dishes or simply curious to try something new, this place promises a memorable dining experience. Dont miss out on their signature Siri Paye, paired with freshly baked naan or roti, for a breakfast that will leave you craving more. A true gem in the heart of the city, Phaja Siri Paye is a testament to timeless flavors and culinary excellence.

combined_text: Burns Road Food Street, Karachi Street Food Hub A historic street bustling with stalls offering Karachi's best bun kebabs, nihari, and BBQ. Very diverse range of food available, the only issue you will face is parking and too much traffic Burns Road is truly the heart of Karachi's food culture!If you're a food lover, this place is a must-visit. From traditional kebabs specially dhaga kabab of delhi kabab house ,haleem, and bun kebabs to mouthwatering desserts like rabri and falooda,icecream, you'll find everything here in one street. The food is rich in flavor, authentic, and represents Karachi's heritage perfectly. The atmosphere is always lively, full of families, friends, and tourists enjoying late-night meals. It's busy and bustling, but that's part of the charm. The prices are very reasonable compared to the quality and variety you get. Parking can sometimes be tricky, and the area can get crowded, but the taste and experience are absolutely worth it. Burns Road is not just food, it's a complete Karachi experience. Highly recommended! If you like a rushy area with a variety of food restaurants, then you must visit this place. The taste and spices are in perfect condition.

combined_text: Kulfi Falooda at Anarkali Bazaar Kulfi / Falooda Historic stalls in Lahore's Anarkali Bazaar serving traditional kulfi (dense ice cream) and falooda. Their falooda is rich, creamy, and full of authentic flavor  a perfect mix of kulfi, vermicelli, and rose syrup. The hygiene isnt great, as its a typical street-style spot. But if you can overlook that, the taste makes it totally worth it. Highly recommended for those who value flavor over fancy surroundings! Yousaf Falooda in Purani Anarkali has earned its reputation for a reason. Their Rabri Milk (Rabri Doodh) is rich, creamy, and perfectly sweetened, making it a refreshing treat on its own. The Falooda is the highlight, loaded with flavor, smooth textures, and always served fresh  truly one of the best in Lahore. And their famous Kulfi (Kulfi) is simply irresistible, with a traditional taste that brings back old memories and makes it a must-try for visitors. The service is generally attentive and efficient, though it can slow down a little during rush hours. The atmosphere is lively and carries the old Anarkali charm, but it often feels crowded, especially in peak times. Overall, Yousaf Falooda is a classic stop for anyone looking to enjoy authentic traditional desserts with unforgettable taste. combined_text: Charsi Tikka, Namak Mandi, Peshawar Chicken/Mutton Tikka A world-famous street for its massive portions of perfectly grilled Charsi tikka and lamb chops. Located in the heart of the historic Namak Mandi in Peshawar, Nisar Charsi Tikka is one of the most iconic places to experience authentic Peshawari BBQ and traditional cuisine. For those unfamiliar, Namak Mandi has been a famous food street for decades, known for its rich culinary heritage, especially lamb dishes cooked in desi ghee and simple spices  letting the meat speak for itself. Its a must-visit area for anyone who wants a true taste of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa. At Nisar Charsi Tikka, the food absolutely lives up to the hype. The Patta Tikka, Mutton/Lamb Tikka, and the Peshawari Lamb Karahi are the standout dishes  juicy, tender, and full of flavor. Everything is cooked fresh, with meat brought out for your approval before grilling or karahi preparation begins. That said, be prepared for a no-frills, old-school setup. The service can feel a bit rushed, and the owner is known to be slightly rude or blunt, which can catch first-time visitors off guard. But if you go in for the food and not the pampering, youll likely have a great time, just like I did. Overall: A must-visit for meat lovers. The flavors are unforgettable, and the food is a true reflection of Peshawars culinary culture. Just go with a bit of patience  and a big appetite. If you want taste and good value for your it is for you. I appreciate the taste of this restaurant at Namak Mandi and the weight exactly according to your order. Sometimes the service is not according to the expectations as expectations always hurt. If I could recommend it would be taste and weight the cuisine served. If I could suggest it would be service. Sometimes, it may take an hour or two to be served. Food was slow but worth the wait. Karahi sauce was very very good and the shinwari was super. They only sell shinwari by the kg so if you are one person, this may be too much.

combined_text: Dhamthal Halwa Shop, Dhamthal Sohan Halwa A legendary roadside stop on the GT Road famous for its irresistible, piping hot sohan halwa. This is the go-to spot for me as my Nana's apartment is right on that street so whenever I visit I eat there, and I have to say that the quality has not changed much it still has a very nice taste and honestly dhamtal has adapted quite well to staying competitive. There is a lot more cleanliness now then last time I visited. Staff is helpful and nice even though the bakery is quite busy all the time. Atmosphere is a little bit of negative point for the bakery dine in is very difficult, it's quite rushy and it is not even worth it. My recommendation is to take-out. Another thing that i am quite surprised about is the prices. Prices have not changed much and i admired that 8bje ye cake inki shop se lia tha aik dum bassi or boosa hua complain krne pr kehdia k aisa he hta he fridge me rkh k khalain pathetic service , 0 quality food must try their cake before purchase to safe yourself from wasting your money video review coming soon on fb, yt ans insta on Ather_k_vlog Visited on a Sunday morning with friends for breakfast. This place is quite hyped for its traditional halwa puri in Karachi, but I found it just average compared to other options like DilPasand (Nazimabad) or Hafiz (Malir). We sat on the roadside footpath , which gave a very basic vibedefinitely an area that could use some improvement for more comfortable outdoor seating. We ordered the classic halwa with puri, along with channay, aaloo tarkari, and achaar. While the service was fine, the puri was overly oily and the halwa could have been better in taste . Prices are moderate at around 300-500 per head, and breakfast is available until about 12 PM on weekends. They do offer separate seating for families inside, but we didn't get to try that out. Overall, if you're looking to try a popular spot, it's worth a visitbut don't expect it to exceed your expectations.

combined_text: Khalifa Nihari, Chitral Qila, Lahore Nihari Another giant in the nihari world, known for its rich, slow-cooked beef stew served with naan. A timeless masterpiece of Mughal architecture  a must-visit for anyone who truly wants to experience the heart of Lahores history and culture. The Lahore Fort, locally known as Shahi Qila, is one of those rare places where you can genuinely feel the layers of history come alive around you. Located at the northern end of Lahores old walled city, right beside the majestic Badshahi Mosque, this fort is not just a tourist attraction  its a journey through centuries of art, power, and empire. I visited the fort on a calm afternoon, and it turned out to be one of the most memorable experiences Ive had in Lahore. The entrance through the Alamgiri Gate immediately sets the tone  grand, imposing, and filled with Mughal charm. As you walk in, you cant help but imagine how emperors like Akbar, Jahangir, and Shah Jahan once walked these same pathways. Every corner tells a story. The fort isnt a single building but a whole complex  with palaces, courtyards, gardens, and beautifully decorated halls that reflect different eras of Mughal and later Sikh influences. The Sheesh Mahal (Palace of Mirrors) is without doubt the highlight. The mirror work inside is breathtaking  thousands of tiny glass pieces reflect light in such a mesmerizing way that it feels almost magical. Even after centuries, the craftsmanship remains stunning. The Naulakha Pavilion is another gem  elegant white marble, intricate floral carvings, and a peaceful balcony view overlooking the city. You can easily spend hours admiring the details and still find something new every time you look closer. What I really appreciated was the forts restoration and preservation efforts by the authorities and UNESCO. Although some parts are still under maintenance, its heartening to see that the forts glory is being carefully revived rather than modernized. Information boards around the complex provide historical context, which makes the visit educational as well as visually fascinating. The museum section inside is worth a visit too. It houses ancient coins, Mughal armory, paintings, manuscripts, and artifacts that give you an even deeper insight into how life must have been during the Mughal era. The staff were polite and helpful, and the ticketing process was smooth. If youre planning to visit, Id recommend coming in the late afternoon when the light softens  its the perfect time for photography, especially when the sun hits the marble and red sandstone walls. The fort is right next to the Badshahi Mosque, Hazuri Bagh, and Minar-e-Pakistan, so you can make it part of a full-day heritage tour. In short, Lahore Fort isnt just a monument  its a living story of art, culture, and resilience. Whether youre a history lover, a photographer, or simply someone seeking inspiration, this place will leave you speechless. A must-see landmark that captures the true soul of Lahore and the golden age of the Mughal Empire. Its boring, we were done after getting some pictures. The government should work hard to preserve the originality of fort, as I saw most people ruining walls. Plus there is nothing other than the walls to see. There should be libraries, monuments. Some kind of of theme, to build public interest. Lahore Fort, also called Shahi Qila, is a magnificent Mughal monument built mainly by Emperor Akbar in 1566 and later expanded by Jahangir, Shah Jahan, and Aurangzeb. Located beside the Badshahi Mosque, it is famous for its grand gates, Sheesh Mahal (Palace of Mirrors), Naulakha Pavilion, and beautiful marble work. The fort has witnessed the rule of Mughals, Sikhs, and the British, making it a symbol of rich history and culture. Today, it is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a popular tourist attraction where visitors can experience the royal glory of the past.

combined_text: Famous Rabri & Lassi, Lakshmi Chowk Lassi / Rabri Stalls famous for their thick, creamy lassi served in clay pots and rich, sweet rabri. Great taste. . . . Butt Karahi is a renowned restaurant famous for its traditional Pakistani chicken karahi dish, with its origin in Lahore, Pakistan. The original establishment, founded in 1953, is known for its authentic flavors and a busy, no-frills atmosphere, particularly in the Lakshmi Chowk area. Its success has led to multiple branches in Lahore claiming to be the original and many imitators, as well as international franchises in places like Canada and the UK. History and origin Butt Karahi was founded in Lahore in 1953 and is considered a culinary icon in Pakistan. The original restaurant is located in the bustling Lakshmi Chowk area. The restaurant's success has led to numerous copycat restaurants and franchise locations appearing in Lahore and other parts of the world. The dish The restaurant is most famous for its "desi" (traditional) chicken karahi. Karahi is a dish named after the wok-like pot it is cooked in, and the Butt Karahi version is known for its rich, spicy, and tomatoey base, often finished with ginger, black pepper, and butter. Recipes have been passed down through generations, and while they use high-quality ingredients, the specific spice blend is a closely guarded secre Taste of food is good but they only take cash payments to avoid tax. I don't know why they are not ready to pay taxes. Butt karahi, The moment the sizzling hot karahi arrived, the aroma had me drooling. And the flavors? Absolutely divine! The meat was tender, juicy, and cooked to perfection. The spices were balanced, with just the right amount of heat. The quarter portion was not so generous for a single person though size. The service was average but friendly, attentive, and accommodating. But took me an over an hour to receive my order. The ambiance was okayish. If you're a karahi lover, Scrumptious Butt Karahi is a MUST-TRY! If you have parience to wait. Be prepared for an explosion of flavors that'll leave you craving more. Recommended for: Karahi enthusiasts, spice lovers, and anyone seeking an unforgettable dining experience!

Bundu Khan is a timeless gem of Karachi! Revisiting it after 10 years was like a nostalgic trip to my childhood. The mutton kebabs remain mouthwatering, and the paratha chicken tikka combo still stands out as an unbeatable classic. This place has been serving BBQ excellence for decades, and their consistency is remarkable. While the quality is still top-notch, I did notice that the portion sizes, like the chicken tikka, have become smaller, and the seekh kababs are priced higher (Rs. 1,200 for 12 small pieces). Considering the current economic challenges, its understandable. The staff is courteous and attentive, and though the ambiance isn't extraordinary, the outdoor seating adds a nice touch. It's also wheelchair accessible, making it inclusive for all diners. Sindhi Muslim Society itself is a vibrant food street, and Bundu Khan remains its shining star. It may not be a fancy dining spot, but its flavor, heritage, and heart make it worth every visit. Highly recommended for anyone craving authentic BBQ with a touch of nostalgia! combined_text: Okra Restaurant, Lahore Fine Dining Mughlai A fine-dining establishment known for its modern take on traditional Pakistani and Mughlai dishes. Wow, just wow! Okra is an outstanding French restaurant in Karachi. I had heard from colleagues that it was truly excellent food, but I was skeptical as I find that my taste is my discerning that most people I know. However, I was truly amazed by the quality of the food, the beauty of the presentation, and the overall excellent service. I was with a group of colleagues and we shared some appetizers, two were fig based and were amazing! One was a mushroom dish that almost resembled meat  excellent flavor. I had a scallop dish for my main course, which was executed perfectly. The breads are also all made in-house. Overall, a truly gourmet experience  highly recommend that you try it. Note that the venue is small, and reservations are hard to come by so I recommend planning ahead (like months) if you want a reservation. Every visit to Okra is an experience of flavors. Love the fresh ingredients of dishes. And thank you to cheerful waiters staff who always take great care of us. For years, I avoided Okra, dismissing it as another overhyped spot. But curiosity got the better of me on my wedding anniversary, so I secured a lunch reservation after learning dinner was booked weeks in advance. The experience was, unfortunately, underwhelming. While Okra thrives on its exclusivity and reputation, the food does little to justify its price tag. We arrived at noon, and the staff promptly welcomed us. The hospitality, Ill admit, was flawlesswarm, attentive, and professional. However, the ambiance left much to be desired. The restaurant, though cozy with a Mediterranean touch, felt oppressively cramped. It seemed as though every square inch had been maximized, evoking the claustrophobia of a Tokyo eatery. Seating, too, was uncomfortable. Within 15 minutes, my back and legs began protesting, a sentiment taller patrons would echo. The complimentary bread basket turned out to be the highlight of our meal. Fresh, aromatic, and inviting, it hinted at the culinary finesse I had hoped for. Yet the accompanying condiments were bland and uninspired, setting the tone for what was to follow. We started with the crab on toast, which was, frankly, a disappointment. Despite a herby topping, it lacked flavor and was inexplicably salty. The crab itself was dry, streaky, and texturally off-putting. I struggled to take more than two bites. The "Steak and Eggs" followeda dish that felt like a misstep on every level. The eggs, served sunny-side up, were a disaster: whites undercooked and almost rubbery, yolks raw and unpleasantly fragrant. My wife couldnt finish hers due to the off-putting smell. The steak, meanwhile, consisted of two overcooked, bite-sized medallions that were tough, charred, and utterly joyless. At nearly Rs. 3,000, the dish felt not only overpriced but also insultingingredients that likely cost a fraction of the price failed to deliver even basic satisfaction. Desperate for redemption, I opted for the cheeseburger, hoping it would be a safer bet. What arrived was an ordinary beefburger with a charred, chewy patty and little else to commend it. While the patty was juicy, it lacked the tenderness and seasoning expected at this price point. The accompanying fries, soggy and bland, were no better than what one might find at a roadside stall for a fraction of the cost. The meals saving grace, surprisingly, came in the form of a drink: the Campagna with a hint of chocolate. Silky, well-balanced, and indulgent, it reminded us of what the restaurant is capable of if it pays attention to detail. Okra, I understand, thrives on exclusivity, with months-long reservations, at times, and an air of prestige. For some, dining here may be more about bragging rights than culinary substance. But for those who value flavor, creativity, and quality over mere appearances, Okra is likely to disappoint. In a city where dining out is one of the few leisure activities, this restaurant trades too heavily on its reputation and fails to deliver the kind of experience its price tag demands.

I had an absolutely amazing experience dining at Kolachi in Karachi! From the moment I walked in, everything was perfectthe warm atmosphere, the beautiful setting, and above all, the incredible food. Every dish was prepared to perfection, full of flavor, and truly exceeded my expectations. My sincere gratitude goes to the chef for creating such a memorable meal. The real highlight of the evening was our waiter, Mahmoud. His service was nothing short of outstanding. He was incredibly attentive, constantly checking in to make sure everything was exactly to our liking and ensuring the food was served just the way we wanted it. Mahmoud went above and beyond with his care, patience, and attention to detail. He truly elevated the entire dining experience and made us feel valued and well taken care of. Its rare to find someone so dedicated and passionate about service, and Mahmoud is a true gem at Kolachi. The food was decent and service was excellent. The best time to go is around sunset hours and you should be ready to expect a queue before receiving a table unless you reserve it before hand.

combined_text: Charsi Tikka BBQ / Grill The most famous street in Peshawar for its massive, perfectly grilled lamb chops and tikka. Located in the heart of the historic Namak Mandi in Peshawar, Nisar Charsi Tikka is one of the most iconic places to experience authentic Peshawari BBQ and traditional cuisine. For those unfamiliar, Namak Mandi has been a famous food street for decades, known for its rich culinary heritage, especially lamb dishes cooked in desi ghee and simple spices  letting the meat speak for itself. Its a must-visit area for anyone who wants a true taste of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa. At Nisar Charsi Tikka, the food absolutely lives up to the hype. The Patta Tikka, Mutton/Lamb Tikka, and the Peshawari Lamb Karahi are the standout dishes  juicy, tender, and full of flavor. Everything is cooked fresh, with meat brought out for your approval before grilling or karahi preparation begins. That said, be prepared for a no-frills, old-school setup. The service can feel a bit rushed, and the owner is known to be slightly rude or blunt, which can catch first-time visitors off guard. But if you go in for the food and not the pampering, youll likely have a great time, just like I did. Overall: A must-visit for meat lovers. The flavors are unforgettable, and the food is a true reflection of Peshawars culinary culture. Just go with a bit of patience  and a big appetite. If you want taste and good value for your it is for you. I appreciate the taste of this restaurant at Namak Mandi and the weight exactly according to your order. Sometimes the service is not according to the expectations as expectations always hurt. If I could recommend it would be taste and weight the cuisine served. If I could suggest it would be service. Sometimes, it may take an hour or two to be served. Food was slow but worth the wait. Karahi sauce was very very good and the shinwari was super. They only sell shinwari by the kg so if you are one person, this may be too much.

combined_text: Shinwari Village Restaurant Shinwari Cuisine Offers an authentic Shinwari tribal feast, often featuring whole lamb or giant plates of roasted meat. It is well-known for its rice and meat dishes (especially the pulao style dishes). One reviewer: One of the best kabuli pulao in the town though very heavy but still too yummy Many mention the flavour of the meat + the rice is very good. For example: The quality and quantity of meat were impressive, and the taste was great. Good for meat lovers looking for a hearty meal, and the location (University Rd, near Liberty Mall) is convenient. The overall review rating is decent: around 4.1/5 in one listing. This restaurant completely exceeded my expectations! The decor is elegant and modern, the lighting perfect, and the music subtle enough to allow good conversation. The menu had a fantastic range of dishes, and everything we ordered exceeded our expectations. The chef clearly knows how to balance spices and textures perfectly. The staff went above and beyond to make us comfortable, knowledgeable, and genuinely caring. The food came out quickly, and each course was better than the last. The dessert was a showstopper! Its rare to find a place that delivers excellence in food, service, and atmosphere all at once, but this restaurant does it effortlessly This restaurant sets a high standard for quality dining. A restaurant that truly knows how to impress its guests I highly recommend it for date nights, family dinners, or any special occasion! A must-visit! This is one of my favorite places in Peshawar. I regurlay visit for best of best kabli pulao, and never gets dissappointed. If You are pulao lover you should must visit this restaurant. The quantity of beef in plate will surprise you. None of the restaurant can beat them in quality of Pulao. Staff is also very good and co oporative. A good place to bring guests too.

combined_text: Cafe de Hunza Local Hunza Cuisine Famous for its organic apricot juice, local buckwheat dishes, and stunning views of Rakaposhi. Stopped by this cafe and was genuinely impressed! The views were absolutely stunning  a perfect backdrop to a relaxing meal. The staff was friendly and efficient, and the place itself was spotless and neatly kept. I had a sandwich and a milkshake, both were delicious. Now I totally get why this spot comes so highly recommended whenever youre in Hunza Delicious breakfast with a view! Had breakfast at the much-anticipated Cafe de Hunza, and it lived up to the hype! Its a self-service cafe and usually a bit crowded, but we went early right after opening and got a cozy spot. We ordered their famous walnut cake, pancake with Nutella, brownie, Pakistani complete breakfast, cheese & mushroom omelette, regular tea, and the refreshing Hunza tea with honey. Everything was superb! The pancake was freshly baked, the omelette was creamy and flavorful, and the walnut cake truly deserves its reputationmoist, rich, and unforgettable The Hunza tea had a light, herbal punch with honey that was both refreshing and unique. It cost us Rs. 5,600 for 9 people, which is quite reasonable for such quality food and ambience. Highly recommended for anyone visiting Hunza! I found the famous walnut cake good but not exceptional. It was quite dry and the texture wasnt soft and moist like a cake, but more like a biscuit. The rose tea was great though, highly recommend that. And the decor is cute.

combined_text: Hidden Paradise Restaurant Fresh Trout Fish Known for its trout fish, taken fresh from the river and served with a view of the Kunhar River. The best place to try local Hunza food. The food is very filling and the service is excellent since our server suggested good options for us to order and patiently explained each and every dish. It is best to order a platter if you are many persons. It is expensive but it is totally worth it. Clean, fresh organic food. The Chupshoros are amazing both the Yak Meat ones and the cheese ones. The meal is very filling since they use apricot oil. A must try! I have mixed opinions about this restaurant. When I visited, they had power outage and offered candle light dinner, which was odd. I only ordered for take away. They offered a free taste for their stake too, which was great. The issue is with the actual order I placed, I ordered Chap Shoru, their traditional pizza, it was pathetic and extremely expensive. I have had the same dish from other place with one tenth the price and good taste. So if you visit, only order the stake! i am glad i found this place while walk on Karim Abad road. i visited number of restaurant but all of them has same food to offer and hardly offer traditional hunzai food. the place is so quiet with best view of Altit and ultar peak. they offer all kind of local cuisine specifically uniquely tailored to your taste nd i must say they have great chef and friendly staff...if visit hunza again will definitely visit this place with frds

combined_text: Shangrila Resort Restaurant Balti Cuisine While a hotel, its restaurant is famed for its ambiance and local Balti dishes like Harissa. We didnt stay in the hotel but visited the gardens and restaurant. You have to purchase a ticket to enter. The gardens and lake are absolutely beautiful. It is so well maintained and calm. We enjoyed sitting by the water and relaxing and exploring the garden. The restaurant food was not too good but you can eat looking out at the beautiful views of the water, mountains and water. Would recommend visiting the resort if you are passing through the area. Great location with lovely views. Hotel was one of the first upmarket hotels built 12 or 13 years ago. It's looking a little tired now. The external grounds are great. Nice restaurant menu. Quiet. Nice crowd of clientele. This resort is an icon, I took s trip to Skardu and asked my travel advisor to make sure he booked my stay at this resort. The setting of the cabins around the Shangri-la lake puts out a perfect vibe. Rooms are spacious and comfortable. Staff is courteous and friendly, I enjoyed the breakfast every morning with 360 degree views of the lake. Overall a very positive experience staying at Shangri-la Resort which I would recommend to all of my friends and family.

combined_text: Hunza Food Pavilion Local Hunza Cuisine Offers a taste of traditional Hunza cuisine, including their famous barley bread and dried apricots. The best restaurant in this area! Every dish we tried was incredible and felt like someones home cooking. We especially loved the holio garma and the mulida. The staff was super sweet and explained every item on the menu to us. The seating area was also so cosy. And do try their apricot juice! Enjoy your experience here  Its a tourists trap The food is terrible and the portions are small. Even my guide agreed with me that thats not the right taste for local cuisine. Theyre using cheap ingredients as fillers. Neither my local guide or myself could finish our plates. I highly do NOT recommend this place. And definitely not returning back. You CANNOT go to Hunza and not eat here! Restaurant owner by an enterprising local woman, with her family helping as her staff. Most delicious local dishes, each one scrumptious! Comfy sitting area with a marvellous view. Friendly and quick service, always with smiles. Don't miss it!

combined_text: Pamir Restaurant Local Food with a View Known for its simple, hearty meals and the incredible view of the Passu Glacier from its windows. Amazing taste and quality pizza. The sauce, the dough and the toppings, everything was excellent. I usually lower my standards for such foods in northern areas, however its quality matches that which are available in our cities. Absolutely recommended for anyone craving pizza Visited Pizvaan, with my wife and kid, on a friend's recommendation. I was a bit sceptical over having pizza , but was I in for a surprise. We had the 13inch Pizvaan special. The thin crust was an absolute delight. The unicorn of pizzas I will say. The lady who was attending (and perhaps the owner) was very well spoken, warm, and welcoming. Had an absolute pleasure there. Thank you for making our evening special. Pizvaaan in Passu serves the best pizza in all of Gilgit-Baltistan. Run by the talented and welcoming Ms. Jahan, the caf offers not only incredible flavors but also a truly memorable experience. Her passion for pizza-making shines through in every bite. Highly recommended for anyone visiting the region!

combined_text: PTDC Motel Restaurant Pakistani Cuisine A reliable spot for traditional Pakistani meals amidst beautiful mountain scenery. A neat and clean place, that too on the bank of river Indus. Pleasantly welcoming staff. Though there is a lot of room for improvement but considering the other options available in that area, it is probably one of the best if not the best. They should install air conditioning and heating systems in all the rooms though. Nice Place. Very good place for stay in Besham. There is place for parking in side the Motel. Air Conditioning rooms TV, cable Wide open huge room Very cooperative staff Beautiful river view Every thing is perfect But the problem is the weather it's very hot place one can't survive without AC. Over all very nice, cool and calm place. Besham is a lovely place and I have stayed at the PTDC often over many years. The staff is very cooperative and the VIP rooms clean and comfy. Can't say anything about the other standard rooms but in general the motel has a lovely view of the Indus River and the valley

Kalam Valley is a stunning gem in Pakistan's Swat district, known for its breathtaking landscapes, lush green meadows, and crystal-clear rivers. Surrounded by towering mountains, it offers visitors a serene escape into nature. Popular for hiking, camping, and exploring picturesque spots like Mahodand Lake and Ushu Forest, Kalam Valley is a haven for adventure seekers and nature lovers alike. Its cool climate and scenic beauty make it a top travel destination in northern Pakistan. Boyun, Kalam Swat. A small village on the top of the cliff that can be seen from the bazar of Kalam. Mesmerizing place to visit for its lush green meadows and farming fields. You can reach there after a trek/hike of about 1.5 hours from Kalam. You will be getting aerial view of kalam Valley and ushu forest from the very top.

combined_text: Swat Serena Hotel Restaurant Upscale Local Cuisine The finest dining in Swat, offering high-quality local Pashtun and Pakistani cuisine. The team at Swat Serena is very welcoming and responsive. We were greeted with drinks immediately on arrival, and then escorted to our rooms. The overall architecture and design aesthetic of the facility is warm and vintage. Fresh fruit was awaiting in a pleasantly fragrant room. We spent the evening by the pool, where the kids enjoyed their time, and in the evening we went out for a walk in the lush green and beautifully landscaped lawns of the facility. At dinner we were greeted by very hospitable staff, and the food was fresh and according to our taste. Enjoyed our stay a lot, will visit again. My recent stay at the Swat Serena Hotel was absolutely excellent, and I can't recommend it enough. This place is more than just a hotel; it's a piece of history, a beautiful former palace set on stunning, lush grounds. From the moment we arrived, the staff was incredibly courteous and welcoming. The service was top-notch throughout our visit, with every member of the team going out of their way to make us feel comfortable. The rooms are spacious, clean, and beautifully maintained, blending a vintage aesthetic with modern comfort. It was the perfect place to relax after a day of exploring. The hotel's location is ideal, with easy access to major sights in Swat. The grounds themselves are a destination, with beautiful gardens and views of the surrounding mountains. We particularly enjoyed the outdoor pool and the serene atmosphere. While the breakfast buffet was good, the a la carte menu was fantastic, offering a great selection of local and international dishes. The food was delicious and the dining experience was wonderful. Overall, the Swat Serena Hotel provided a peaceful, hospitable, and truly memorable experience. It's a place where every detail is taken care of and you feel genuinely valued as a guest. I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a high-class, peaceful retreat in the heart of Swat Valley. It's truly a place of peace, hospitality, and privacy. A Slice of Heaven in Swat! "I recently had the pleasure of staying at the Swat Serena Hotel, and I must say, it was an unforgettable experience! Nestled in the breathtakingly beautiful valley of Swat, this hotel truly is a slice of heaven on earth. The hotel's architecture and design seamlessly blend with the natural surroundings, creating a sense of harmony and tranquility. My room had a stunning view of the surrounding mountains, and I felt like I was waking up in paradise every morning. The staff at Swat Serena Hotel were warm, welcoming, and attentive to every need. From the moment I arrived, I felt like I was part of the family. The hotel's hospitality is truly exceptional, and it's clear that the staff take immense pride in their work. The food at the hotel was exquisite, with a range of local and international options to suit every palate. I particularly enjoyed the traditional Kalam cuisine, which was expertly prepared and presented. But what truly sets Swat Serena Hotel apart is its commitment to sustainability and community development. The hotel's initiatives to support local communities and preserve the environment are truly commendable, and it's clear that they genuinely care about making a positive impact. If you're looking for a luxurious getaway in the midst of nature's splendor, look no further than Swat Serena Hotel. The hotel's stunning location, exceptional service, and commitment to sustainability make it a truly unique and unforgettable experience. I would highly, highly recommend it to anyone seeking a luxurious and responsible travel experience."

Nestled in the heart of the majestic Hunza Valley, the h otel offers stunning panoramic views of the surrounding mountains  especially Rakaposhi and Ultar peaks. The balcony view was simply breathtaking  waking up to snow-capped mountains and crisp morning air was a true delight. I stayed there for a night. The rooms Was clean, well equipped with necessities such as hygiene kit, prayer mat etc. I paid PKR 8000/- for a single window room with double bed. The allied restaurant is on the opposite side of the road and the guys there are nice, welcoming but the food is average. The hotel parking is very small (2-3 cars) and access road to parking is bit steep. Second issue is the location, its on main road so you have to bear the noise of car all the night.

combined_text: Deosai Cafe Cafe / Basic Meals A seasonal cafe at the edge of Sheosar Lake, serving basics in an epic, high-altitude location. Deosai National Park is an alpine plateau of exceptional beauty and ecological value located in the western massif of the Himalayas, east of Nanga Parbat Peak and in close proximity to the Central Karakoram Range. The plateau, with an altitude of 3500 to 5200 m., is an area of 358,400 ha. of flat but undulating plains broken by gently rolling hills and surrounded on all sides by mountains. It forms a stark contrast to much of the surrounding landscape which is made up of narrow valleys between steep mountains. Best time to visit: Peak season: The best time to visit is during the summer months, from June to October, when the park is open. Best for wildflowers: July is often recommended for peak wildflower blooms. Mosquitoes: Be prepared for a large number of mosquitoes during the summer, especially near water sources. At around 4000 m, the plateau is home to a diverse fauna and flora. A jeepable track from Skardu takes one to Seosar Lake point, passing Bara Pani and other attractions. Marmoth on the way greets you. With make-shift hotels & tenst cropping up, the place may soon become a dump. The forest/wildlife staff is doing a good job in controlling people, and stopping them from polluting. Best. Worth it. On you way to sheosar lake in deosai, you will view only window 2007 XP wallpaper. Worth it. Must visit. take umbrella as mostly it rains there, headcap. night camping is recommended. second largest plateau on earth, so yeah definitely worth it. there are 3-4 spots of Worth while way to deosai. you will love it.

Namak Mandi is Famous for Their Delicious Foods And also Gemstones Market is Here Heres Namek mandi food street ** I had a wonderful experience at this restaurant! The ambiance was cozy and inviting, the staff was incredibly friendly, and the service was quick. The food was fresh, flavorful, and beautifully presented. Every dish we tried was delicious, especially the grilled chicken and the chocolate lava cake for dessert. I highly recommend this place to anyone looking for a relaxing and satisfying dining experience. Will definitely be coming back! I recently visited Namak Mandi, Peshawar, and dined at Nisar Charsi Tikka. Finding a parking spot there was a challenge in itself. The food was absolutely delicious, especially the Chicken BBQ and Chicken Karahi, and the prices were quite economical. However, the experience had its downsides. We waited nearly an hour for our turn, the staff was uncooperative, and they charged an undefined amount for service and starters. Overall, if you're looking for amazing food, it's worth a visit, but dont expect much beyond the taste.

combined_text: Hunza Deck Cafe with a View A cafe with a stunning wooden deck overlooking the Hunza River, perfect for coffee and light meals. Stopped by this cafe and was genuinely impressed! The views were absolutely stunning  a perfect backdrop to a relaxing meal. The staff was friendly and efficient, and the place itself was spotless and neatly kept. I had a sandwich and a milkshake, both were delicious. Now I totally get why this spot comes so highly recommended whenever youre in Hunza Delicious breakfast with a view! Had breakfast at the much-anticipated Cafe de Hunza, and it lived up to the hype! Its a self-service cafe and usually a bit crowded, but we went early right after opening and got a cozy spot. We ordered their famous walnut cake, pancake with Nutella, brownie, Pakistani complete breakfast, cheese & mushroom omelette, regular tea, and the refreshing Hunza tea with honey. Everything was superb! The pancake was freshly baked, the omelette was creamy and flavorful, and the walnut cake truly deserves its reputationmoist, rich, and unforgettable The Hunza tea had a light, herbal punch with honey that was both refreshing and unique. It cost us Rs. 5,600 for 9 people, which is quite reasonable for such quality food and ambience. Highly recommended for anyone visiting Hunza! I found the famous walnut cake good but not exceptional. It was quite dry and the texture wasnt soft and moist like a cake, but more like a biscuit. The rose tea was great though, highly recommend that. And the decor is cute.

combined_text: Skardu Balti Restaurant Balti Cuisine Specializes in the hearty, warming stews and breads of traditional Balti cuisine. I loved every second of being here. It felt like visiting an old friends homewarm, welcoming, and full of heart. The food was absolutely amazing: the Tras Balay was comforting and full of flavor, the Mamto were juicy and delicious, and the Payo Chaa was soothing and unlike anything else. They even shared fresh cherries picked straight from their trees! What made it even more special was the hostso kind and genuine, explaining each dish and chatting with us like family. This wasnt just a meal, it was a memory. Truly one of the best experiences Ive had in Skardu. Had an absolute incredible time dining at Balti Cuisine. The food was very healthy and I really enjoyed the apricot oil. The soup was probably my favorite and I highly recommend the platter. Added bonus, your host sits with you as per cultural standards, and helps guide you through your food and its origins. Definitely a stop you cant miss when going through Skardu City. Amazing experience - Kaneez presented us with some delicious local homemade food and told us about the cooking process and ingredients. All the food was delicious and we felt incredibly welcomed in her home. Deeply recommend to anyone visiting Skardu!

combined_text: Kaghan Valley Corn Vendors Street Food (Snack) Roadside vendors selling roasted corn on the cob, a simple and classic mountain snack. Kaghan Valley is a breathtakingly beautiful destination in the Mansehra District of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan. Known for its lush green mountains, crystal-clear lakes, flowing rivers, and scenic villages, its one of the top tourist spots in northern Pakistan. From the charming town of Balakot to the alpine lake Saif ul Maluk, the entire valley is filled with natural wonders. Places like Naran, Siri Paye, Lulusar Lake, and Babusar Top offer unforgettable views and cool weather, especially during summer. The valley is perfect for family trips, nature photography, hiking, and relaxing away from city life. Local hospitality, fresh trout fish, and jeep rides to highland areas add to the experience. Roads can be rough in some parts, so careful planning is advised. Kaghan Valley is a true gem for nature lovers and a must-visit destination for anyone exploring northern Pakistan. The fresh air, stunning views, and peaceful surroundings will refresh your soul. Kaghan Valley is one of the most beautiful places I have ever visited. Surrounded by lush green mountains, flowing rivers, and breathtaking landscapes, this valley is a true paradise for nature lovers. From the moment I entered the valley, the cool, fresh air and picturesque views made me feel at peace. One of the highlights of my trip was visiting Lake Saif-ul-Mulook. The emerald-green lake, set against the backdrop of snow-covered peaks, was absolutely mesmerizing. A boat ride on the lake was a magical experience. I also explored Babusar Top, which offered panoramic views of the entire valley and was perfect for photography. The hospitality of the locals made my trip even more special. They were incredibly kind and welcoming, always ready to share their culture and traditions. I also enjoyed the local food, especially Trout fish from the Kunhar River, which was fresh and delicious. Driving through the winding roads of Kaghan Valley, surrounded by waterfalls and dense forests, was an adventure in itself. Whether you love hiking, sightseeing, or just relaxing in nature, Kaghan Valley has something for everyone. I highly recommend visiting this stunning destination  I cant wait to go back
